The reason why the phone flips about an axis different from the initial axis of rotation is more involved.  It is not due to variation in density of the phone's mass distribution.  The same trick will work with a book (held shut with a rubber band), a claw hammer, or any object where its three principal moments of inertia are all different.  Let's call them Ix, Iy and Iz and  Ix < Iy < Iz.  Here, "I" is the upper case, first letter in the word 'Inertia'.  Consider a set of x, y and z axes that run through the phone.  Before the phone is flipped, the x-axis aligns with the longest dimension of the phone and passes through its center.  The z-axis  aligns with the vertical axis, or parallel to the thinnest dimension of the phone.  The y-axis aligns with the middle or intermediate dimension of the phone.  Due to the phone's (more or less) constant mass density, Ix < Iy < Iz.  Rotations about the x and z axes are stable.  Rotations about the axis that corresponds to the intermediate (or middle value) of the phone's moment of inertia (Iy) is inherently unstable.  Unconstrained rotation about the y-axis picks up some rotation about the x-axis.  Why?  Some may not like this explanation, but here it is.  Solving Lagrange's equation for a rotating rigid body leads to a set of three equations called Euler's equations.  Applying small perturbations to the object's angular velocity and substituting that into Euler's equations gives a 2nd order differential equation in the perturbation parameter.  Solving that differential equation shows the perturbation will oscillate with an angular frequency.  In a manner of speaking, this isn't so "bad" as long as the oscillations don't grow.  However, the expression for the angular frequency when the object rotates about the axis that has the intermediate moment of inertia, involves (among other things) the square root of (Iy-Iz).   Iz is the largest moment of inertia, and Iy minus Iz is a negative number.  The square root of a negative number is an imaginary number.  Physically, this means the amplitude of those perturbing oscillations will grow without limit leading to an unstable rotation.  See section 12 in chapter 11 in "Classical Dynamics of Particles and Systems" 5th edition by Thornton and Marion.  That book contains a paragraph describing how NASA and its astronauts overcame the same instability when they tried to grapple a communications satellite with the Space Shuttle in 1992.

The reason why #1 works isn’t just because of the method, but because in the first case you only have one finger; the center of mass is always a point, and since you’ve only got one point of contact where your finger touches the cane, there is effectively a 0% chance the center of mass is exactly on that contact point, and thus starts leaning towards one side or another.

If you use the second method, there’s two points of contact, and thus as long as the center of mass is in-between, it cannot tilt. You can try finding the center of mass on your own, with two fingers together, without using the special method, and just doing it normally, and you’ll see it works fine.

TL;DR: You don’t need a special method to balance on the center of mass, you just need two fingers so that there are two contact points for the center of mass to be between.

Lots of commentators say that #3 is due to impurities in the water. It is wrong. It works even with pure water. Every water molecule orients itself (not 100%, but preferably) along the electric field. It means that everywhere in the volume "+" heads of some dipoles are neutralized with "-" tails of other dipoles. But not on the surface! On the surface you have heads (or tails) only, so a surface charge is accumulated, just like in a capacitor. (Any dielectric does that, not just water, but water's very good at it - its dielectric constant is unusually high.)
In a perfectly uniform field that wouldn't matter, but that's where gradient comes in. One side of the water jet is much closer to the cup than the other, and attracts to it stronger than the other side repulses.



So when the video says "you need a really strong gradient for this", it's not true. Anything polarizable is pulled along any gradient in electric field.

This is an OLD video and I see you've posted the explanations above SEVEN years ago.  Nonetheless, I'm going to take an intuitive stab at explaining the phenomena:  1) The cane:  It's difficult to see the center of gravity with your eyes, but you can feel it with your body or in this case, the balance of the cane on your arms. It's not dissimilar to our sense of balance allowing us to walk, stand and/or run without falling over.  When you start out with your hands apart and move them together, you're continually balancing the cane and making adjustments  accordingly. 2) phone flipping:  I couldn't quite see how you were flipping the phone but I gather you were flipping the phone along its narrowest dimension - like a discus-- which I guess would be its depth. This way all of the phone's mass would stay within a narrow plane.  Flipping it width wise or length wise would introduce a much wider plane and more instability. 3) Cup bending a stream of water:  I think the running water might have been creating a weak magnetic field which was attracted to the static cup. 4) Magnetic cereal: Somewhat similar to the previous.  The strong magnet created a mini-dimple in the surface of the water just in the middle of that cheerio which dragged it along 5)  Tea Bag Rocket:  As you lit that tea bag rocket as it burned down it was heating a column of air. Hot air rises (e.g. a hot hair balloons).   When the flame finally hit the plate, an elevator of hot air had been created sweeping up the remnants of the tea bag almost like suction.  I'll look later to see how wrong I've been.  I'm too tired after writing this at 4AM.....;-)

The phone flipping is a problem I solved in my College Physics course.  The math is somewhat complicated, but essentially it shows that there is no stable spinning about that axis for a rectangle shaped object.  Sorry I can't be more specific, but suffice to say, it's in the math.  It has to do with the moment of inertia tensor. and gravity.  The cane trick is, as far as I can figure, due to you.  As you move your fingers closer together you move the fingers so the cane does not tip. and as you get closer you must move your fingers to the center of mass or the cane will fall.  So it is a result of your carefully moving your fingers so the cane does not flip. The tea bag rocket takes off when the tea bag is at the end of the burn.  As it burns it creates an upward current of air, and when there is sufficiently little mass left, the currents carry it off.  For the cereal, there is iron in most cereals and this is attracted to the magnet.  Take total cereal (high iron content). 1. When we move our fingers from the ends towards the centre of the hammers or stuff like that, we are essentially heading towards the centre of mass by keeping an equal value of mass* displacement from the centre of mass if we keep balancing simultaneously. Thus, no matter what our speed is or from where we start, we end up at the centre of mass.
2. The phone rotates asymmetrically because inside the phone the chips are inserted on one side and most of the stuffs like motherboard are the on one side that makes it heavier on one side and thus a shift of COM(Centre of Mass) happens. This can also be realised by observing the phenimenon of heating in mobile phones which is more inclined on one side.
3. Water in itself is diamagnetic as all the electrons are paired(considering the MOT(Molecular Orbital Theory) model), which indicates that it should not be affected by electric or magnetic fields. But the water that runs through our taps are not simply distilled water. It has some added minerals which induces magnetic behaviour in tap water. Thus, the plastic cup that is charged by rubbing against hair, results in accumulation of electrons on the surface of the cup away from the positive kernels that makes it charged, capable of producing its own small electric fields and moving charges produces magnetic fields attracting tap water.
4. What happened to the cereal is what I don't know exactly, but still I can predict that might be charges are induced onto the cereal by the strong magnet by the process of induction that makes behave as a magnetic system of like charges.
5. The flying off of the tea bag is a very interesting phenomenon. When it was burning and it reaches the end, due to burning, the air above it got lighter and a low pressure region is created above it. When the fire reached its last phase, the weight of the tea bag that was left was unable to balance the force that was pulling it above due to the low pressure region and thus flew off.

1. You end up at the center of mass because your finger slides more distance in the lighter side (less normal force/ less frictional resistance) and when it gets heavier, the other side now becomes ligher and your other finger then moves more distance. This process repeats at the left and right self correcting each other until you reach the center of mass. Summation of moments here is kept approximately zero. Your fingers should have the same frictional coefficients, otherwise you can't reach the center of mass.

1) you have two points of contact with the cane. When you move your fingers toward each other, there will be opposing forces of friction on each end. The end with the higher force of friction will move inwards slower than the end with the lower force of friction. The end with more mass results in more friction since it's proportional to the weight.

Imagine moving your fingers slowly such that only one moves at a time. The one that moves will always be the one with the smaller force of friction which is the side with the less weight. Once it moves, the weight of that side increases. The side that moves will switch if one side becomes heavier than the other.

1: as you move your fingers along the staff, the side that's heavier wants to move downward, applying more pressure, ergo, friction to the corresponding finger, stopping its progress along the staff, then the other finger begins to slide until IT goes out of balance. This continues until the fingers meet at the center of gravity.
2: Not sure about the phone, but I know most of them have gyroscopic sensors in them nowadays. It could be the gyroscope that forces the phone to follow an alternate axis.
3: The water deflects because the electrostatic field it is being exposed to is stronger than the molecule's own es field. This results in the attractive force of the charged object to greatly overpower the repulsive force of the water molecule. So when exposed to a charged object, regardless of it being a negative or positive one, the water will always deflect towards it. also, the closer the charged object is, the more powerful the effect of its field becomes.
4: Most cereals are fortified with Iron, typically in the form of nearly microscopic Iron dust. This small amount of Iron allows a STRONG magnet to have a very weak pull on the cereal.
5: As the teabag burns, it begins to weigh less. eventually, it weighs so little that it gets caught up in the convecting heat and air currents the flame is creating and being fed by, causing the remnants of the tea bag to rise.

On #3, whoever “told” you that the reason the water’s positive side is pulled toward the electromagnetically charged side of the cup is wrong because if that were so, there would be a much straighter line of water running toward the negatively charged area. And it makes sense as to why the water only moves slightly toward the cup. Like this man said, it is rather instead of being pulled positively to the cup, the negative side of the molecule has equal force going in the opposite of its counterpart, keeping it in place. So In theory, all that would happen is the molecule will only rotate positively in the direction of the cup. This causing all the other water molecules to move toward their polarized sides, thus making the water appear to shift toward the cup.

Cane: you actually were not centre mass, and the position of the handles weight is counter balanced on the finger furthest away from the heavier weight, which is the handle. You only think it is centre because of the positioning of your fingers, but the centre mass is slightly further to the handle. Take the rubber foot off and it will be obvious. If you had just a solid wood cane, it still would be further to the handle to counter balance (absorb the weight of greater mass).

For the first one, it is all in terms of moments. The two fingers act as supports and the upward reaction force from each finger and the centre of mass of the rod are equal, hence no movement. As one finger moves, the reaction force at the other decreases, and as a result so does the friction between this finger and the rod. This finger will then move a bit and the same occurs but in the opposite direction. This repeats until your fingers are at the CoM, at which point no moments are acting and thus you have equilibrium.

1: As you move your fingers in, the cane does get off a bit, but that side ends up heavier than the other side since there is more mass on that side. Because it's heavier, it increases the friction with that finger, but decreases it with the other finger, allowing the finger with less weight to move closer to the center. That continues until your fingers are together under the center of gravity. Put on a sticky glove on one of your hands and it won't work anymore.

2: You don't flip it well because it it's spinning around the center. It's off a big because of the longer distance you're trying to flip it around.

3: That happens because you're using tap water and not pure water. That tap water is full of minerals, including iron, which is magnetic. It's those magnetic particles that are attracted and they just happen to pull the water with it.

4: Pretty much all cereals are fortified with iron. You're attracting the iron in the cereal.

5: The fire generates air flow upwards. Once the paper becomes light enough, it gets caught in the air current and is pushed with it. Also, aliens like tea, so they are trying to get the tea bags up in their spaceship. Why'd you burn it? Don't you want the aliens to have tea?

1. Cane
As you move your fingers together, the side tending to be heavier creates more friction with that finger then the other one, allowing the other one to move more easily. When the weight shifts, the more friction changes sides and allows the other finger to 'catch up', eventually meeting at the centre of mass.
2. Flip phone
Erm... not sure. I'm guessing if you open up the phone, you'll find the heavier components are off centre both vertically and horizontally? Or, it's far more difficult to precisely spin a rectangular object along it's longest length... but not sure why. (Making it up as I go...)
3. Attractive cup
When you rub the cup on your head, I would guess electrons (free electrons?) get transferred to your hair, leaving the cup with... wait, I was just about to say what you said was wrong. Yeah, ok, I don't know...
4. Magnetic cereal
I've heard it told that everything has a magnetic field, it's just very weak. The cereal in water has only the water to hold it in place, and water fails in that one job. So even a seemingly magnetic-less piece of cereal will be pulled along by a sufficiently strong magnetic force. Sure, let's go with that!
5. Tea bag rocket
The unburned portion of the tea bag is much heavier than the burnt part. And, of course, heat rises. As the bag burns, it gets to the point where the unburnt part is actually lighter than the burnt part, but they're still physically connected. And the rising heat elevates the remainder of the bag. I'm actually convinced I'm close to being right here!

1 Static friction becomes greater when one of your supports comes closer to the center of mass. So one finger moves until it's sliding friction is > the static friction of the other finger and the roles reverse.

2 The insides of the phone are not symmetrical in weight. The battery on the left side of the phone has more mass than the circuitry on the right side. It's only apparent on the axis he's talking about because the phone is more symmetrically spread out about them. It has a lot to do with rotational momentum and moments, which is more than I want to go into at the moment...ha.

3 Tap water is quite conductive and it is electrically connected to ground. The charge on the cup is creating a capacitive effect on the charges in the water (not necessarily the water itself) and pulling the water stream, which stays cohesive due to surface tension, towards the cup.

4 Many cereals are fortified with iron for health reasons, iron is magnetically conductive, so viola.

5 The fire creates a plume of heated air going upward, sucking air from below. The tea bag is turned into ash, ash is very light and so the leftover airflow from the fire propels the light ash upward.

But when fingers are at unequal distance from C.G the torque acting on the closer finger by the rod about the farther finger is greater than the torque acting on the farther finger by the rod about the closer finger. so normal reaction force b/w the rod and closer finger is greater and so is the frictional force and it sticks to the rod and only the farther finger moves towards C.G till both are at equal distance from the centre. The first one is actually very easy to explain.
When you have a lengthy object like a cane, the amount of force applied to your hands depends on where your fingers are placed. If you place them exactly 10cm from each end, the end with the most weight will apply most force, and the other hand will easier move towards the middle. When that happens, there is a loss of force at the other end, and when it becomes small enough, the hand at that end will start to move towards the middle.

When you flip the phone like that, there are two ways the phone can rotate. Along the horizontal (pitch) and the vertical (roll) axes on the screen. It can't spin along the plane of the screen (yaw), for obvious reasons. The phone has a much larger moment of inertia around the pitch axis than the roll axis. Since angular momentum is Iω where ω is the rotational velocity, the smaller the moment of inertia, the faster something spins given the same momentum (like a figure skater). Thus the phone is very sensitive to rolling and very insensitive to pitching, meaning a tiny torque in the roll axis will send it spinning while a great torque in the pitch axis can barely turn it.

Kind of an old video to be commenting on like this, but here's my text wall anyway. I don't know if any of this has already been said since I don't see anyway to search youtube comments?

(1) As you move your fingers inward, your brain tries to maintain the balance by subtly changing the speed of each finger. You can kinda see him doing this. (3) Hmm, honestly I always believed the water was attracted because it was polar, like you said. I feel like I remember hearing that static electricity has a very strong gradient but I don't know.
(4) Most cereal has dietary iron added to it, but it is actually just very small iron filings. If you blend cereal up, put it in water in a clear container, and touch a magnet to the bottom, you'll see a small pile of iron filings. So that's why it's attracted to a magnet.
(5) As the tea bag burns it looses mass. Once enough, or all, of it has burned it is light enough to be picked up by the small current of heat created by the flame.

The center-of-mass demonstration with the cane is not a physics phenomenon; it's a psychological phenomenon. You can't do it in "one shot" because your brain cannot accurately estimate the distribution of mass across the length of the cane. But you can do it by moving your two hands inward because you are successively computing, re-computing, and adjusting; as you move your hands you get visual and tactile feedback that lets you correct as you go.

With the chemistry one, with the cup and water, it's is because the cup is charged. The cup is either positively or negatively charged. I'm not sure which, but that doesn't really matter, lets just say it is positively charged. The sub-atomic particle that cause charge are protons and electrons, protons have a positive charge and electrons a negative charge. The cup (with its positive charge) has more protons than electrons. Protons are found in the middle of each atom and the electrons are on the outside. When the cup is near the water the positive charge of the cup attracts the electron in the water (because opposite charges attract). The electrons in the atoms in the water are closer to the cup than the protons in the same atoms (because they are on the outside of the atom). The attraction between the water and the cup is bigger than the repulsion between them because the electrons are closer than the protons and because of the distance squared effect the water is attracted to the water.

The reason you can't flip your phone end over end is because the heavier battery is not in the center of the phone, causing the center of gravity to be offset, and the phone to flip on 2 axis at once.

About the first trick. When your fingers start at the ends, the force of the stick being pulled down acts upon both fingers close enough to equally. As you move your fingers together, the force acting on the finger that is further away from the sticks CoM increases, to the point where it is greater than the force acting on the other finger. Because friction acts on the finger with the most resistance i.e, the one with a greater force, the other finger will start to move. Neither finger will ever cross the CoM, as the closer it gets to it, the more force acts upon the finger, until the other finger starts moving again. The flip-flopping between each finger's movement results in each finger ending up next to the other, roughly aligned with the Centre of Mass.

Explanation for the phone flip:

When you flip it in the 1st way, the phone will spin just fine, in a straight circular way (aligned), and the same thing will happen with the 2nd way, just as you explained; but the 3rd phone flip (end over end), does not spin "randomly". The 3rd flip actually spins both frontways and sideways at the same time (you could say it spins over both 1st and 2nd axis at the same time), and with the same speed. The phone seems to spin randomly, but it is actually going around "cleanly" both frontways and sideways at the same time.

I have spinned my phone many times, and you just have to spin it with the right force, for it to give 1 spin forwards and 1 spin sideways at the same time (or 2 spins or 3 spins, etc), and it will fall to your hands in the same position as the one you tossed it in. You can also spin it with less or more force to give "1 and a half" or half a spin, and it will land neatly backwards on your hands. By backwards, I mean pointing down (if the screen was pointing up when thrown), and the top end will be where the bottom end was when you tossed it.

The phone flip thing: The phone has three primary moments of inertia that are located on it's primary axes. There is minimum, a maximum and a intermediate. The reason why the phone flip won't work is because you are trying to flip the phone around the axis with the intermediate moment of inertia. This is unstable. The phone will want to either spin about the axis of minimum inertia or the axis of maximum inertia

I suspect the cane thing works because, seeing that the center of mass is not at the center, there is an imbalance of weight on your two fingers which means that the coefficient of friction is greater for the heavier end than the lighter end.  Provided that your fingers move at the same speed, there will be less resistance to the finger on the lighter side of the cane moving than there will be on the finger on the heavier side so the lighter-side finger will move faster and the heavier-side finger will move slower.  If the center of mass was exactly halfway between your fingers, the weight on your fingers would be equal making the resistance to move equal which would cause them to come together at the same speed.

Here is what I think happens in the cane experience:

Each finger supports a fraction of the cane's weight.

The closer the finger is to the cane's center of mass, the higher the fraction of the total weight it supports.

At the same time, there is friction between the fingers and the cane, and this friction is proportional to the weight on each finger. The closer the finger gets to the cane's center of mass, the higher the friction.

So, every time one of the fingers gets closer to the center, it will see its friction increased on itself and reduced on the other finger, which will in turn start moving towards the center, thus compensating the advantage of any one finger over the other. They will eventually reach the center of mass at the same time.

(I am pretty sure this can be explained with fewer words, but my English is not good enough to achieve it.)

its interesting to see how things we would expect to happen or be the reason are not always correct, like with the cane. And what seems counterintuitive is actually correct.

1: the finger more "at the center" (of gravity) at each moment has more friction (because it carries more of the cane). So it leaves the other finger sliding, and that makes you converge to a symmetric (=balanced) configuration. If you put oil, it won't work as well, because friction won't be proportional to weight ("dry" friction).
2: hmmm, probably turbulences and more initial spin from the throw (and thumb inacuracy) that act more strongly than in the other orientation.
3: you said it, in an homogeneous field plus and minus would get attracted the same. But it's not, it is stronger toward the glass and plus does get closer and thus does feel a stronger force than the minus a tiny bit further away. If you used a gigantic glass, it wouldn't work, because the field would be close to homogeneous
4: there is iron in it (in a ferromagnetic form)
5: convection current (hot air moving up fast), drag the very light leftover with it.

people are getting #1 wrong. The reason that your fingers always end up at the centre of mass is simple: its because if they didnt, the cane would fall to the floor.

Think about it, you could easily move one finger inwards, but not compensate with the other finger - the end result being the cane falling to the floor.

So the actual reason why your fingers always meet at the centre of mass is simply because they HAVE to in order for the cane to remain balanced

OOPS!  You actually can't go any speed with the "fingers under the CG" thing.  With a more massive and offset CG, the inertia of the object messes it up.  In this case, the object must move 'off center' for you to get to the CG.  If you go "too fast" the object doesn't move enough.  A large push-broom demonstrates this better.  Its CG is further off center than that cane and must move to your center, but won't if you move your hands in really quickly.
Moral: Don'forget Newton; he doesn't forget you.  In this case, Newton #1.

Problem with the cane is that you're not moving the finger closer to the handle at the same rate as the other finger, because you consciously know that the heavier weight of the handle will pull the lighter end, so it's not a phenomenon in the slightest.  The problem with the phone is also not a phenomenon as the wind resistance affecting the phone is what turns it.  In regards to the water and the cup, it is due to magnetism.  When anything that is magnetic is brought to something that isn't magnetic normally, it causes the normally non-magnetic objects poles to temporarily align.  Not really a phenomenon.  Cereal is magnetic since it has mass.  Anything with mass produces a magnetic or gravitational field.  The cereal isn't very dense, but the screw is.  So the field of the screw is stronger than the cereal and voila', it pulls the cereal.  Not a phenomenon.  The teabag rocket is just hot air rising.  The same principle is used for hot air balloons, predicting weather patterns, and indeed the heating and cooling of buildings.  Hot air rises, cold air sinks.  Not a phenomenon.

#1) Your fingers always end up at the center of mass, which on earth we can safely say in also the center of gravity because of friction. A finger closer to the center of gravity will support more the cane’s weight. So we say it has a greater normal force on the cane than the other finger. The greater the normal force the greater the maximum static friction that exists between your finger and the cane. So the finger that is further away will have a smaller maximum static friction with the cane because of its smaller normal force. When you move your fingers together while both touching the cane, something must slip. And since the finger further away has a smaller static friction threshold with the cane, it will slip first (assuming your fingers are moving at the same rate relative to the cane). And this finger will continue to slip until it is closer to the center of mass/gravity. Then the other finger will slip and so on. You can see when he moves his fingers slowly, that the fingers alternate slip until they both reach the center of mass. I guess my college statics class was good for something… :)

The first one isn't so much a physics thing more then a human psychological and cognitive function involving reactions, the immediate attempt is a perceived center of mass, the second one is an adjusted movement over time.

In the second one, the phone is not a solid mass of equal density, the components vary and some sections are heavier, the heaviest part likely being the battery.  On some other phones it may be able to do it end over end, but perhaps not side over side due to component placement.

The third one could have other aspects to it, but the magnetic attraction aspect is still the most powerful force in play.  The water also likely has other minerals and elements in it, iron and some other metals for example.  But the water is also not a solid, it is a liquid and thus molecules are much more easily rearranged to magnify to conform to a nearby gravitational field influencing it.

In the fourth one, most cereals contain some content of iron and other trace amounts of metallic substances that occur naturally and usually are a required nutritional substance.  Many other materials that could be attracted by magnetic force that aren't even metallic in nature.  Theoretically almost every element has a degree of magnetic attraction and ability to produce a magnetic field, the contents of the cereal are simply influenced by a powerful magnet.

And the fifth, with the teabag, notice how the remnants are still burning as they float up.  It is lifted off by a change in air pressure due to the flame heating the air.  This is very similar to how a hot air balloon is able to float, the hot air drafts upward, and it carries the very lightweight remains of the teabag with it, accelerating exponentially as the mass decreases and the heat increases until the fire runs out of fuel.

For the cain, it has to do with moment. Moment is equal for force times distance. If you were to draw a free-body diagram of the set up, the vertical forces would amount to the weight of the cain (mass times gravity) acting downwards on the center of gravity of the cain and two normal forces opposing the center of gravity at both points where the finger contacts the cain. In the horizontal we would have the friction forces acting opposite to each other and also opposing the motion of the fingers getting closer to each other. Additional information needed to solve this system is that the frictional force is equal to the coefficient of friction times the normal force. Now, as one finger slides towards the center of gravity, the distribution of the force acting down on the cain, resulting in an increased normal force required to maintain vertical equilibrium. as the normal force increases, so does the frictional force opposing motion. the finger will slide until the frictional force is too great and the finger stops sliding and the other finger begins its journey to the center of gravity. This balancing of the normal forces "protects" the cain from gaining too much weight on the outer sides of the fingers, and thus keeping the cain from falling as the fingers approach the center.

Simple: 
-The sum of the normal force between both fingers on the cane equals the cane's weight, but don't have to equal to each other
-The friction force on one finger is proportional to the normal force (Friction = Normal * μ)
-The normal force on one finger is proportional to the distance from the cane's center of gravity (COG); the closer to the COG, the stronger the normal force
-The finger with the LEAST normal force, and thus friction, will be the one that moves along the cane
-Therefore, the finger that is farthest away from the COG is the one that moves closer to it until its no longer the farthest away. Then the other one will move. You can notice the "role changing" in the video
-This continues until both fingers reach the COG at the same time

Here's my best guess on all the phenomena:
1. The cane trick doesn't work if you just place your fingers under it, because it's extremely hard to simply guess the exact point of balance. However, if you start from both ends and move in, your body feels the shifts in the balance, and can compensate.
2. The phone flip doesn't work because of the simple matter of human error. With the other two, it's pretty easy to keep the forces even to keep the phone on one axis; four fingers move as one body and a thumb the other. This is different for the last flip because each one of your fingers is being used simultaneously to generate torque on the phone. In case you didn't notice, it is virtually impossible to move all your fingers at the same time and with the same force, so when you flip your phone there will always be some variation. 
3. Like you said in another of your videos, water is usually pretty neutral. But, you also said that there will always be some variation in charge of the water molecules. The cup pulls on some of the more positively charged water molecules, and due to water's cohesive nature, it pulls the rest along with it.
4. Several cereal brands boast of their cereal's high iron content. This is the very same iron we use to build things with, but it just very tiny. There were actually some girls who gathered iron from cheerios for a science fair project. The reason it only works in water is probably because the cheerio is so freaking light on its own, and the iron is even more light and small. The water removes a lot of the friction normally experienced and allows for movement.
5. The teabag rocket works because of the nature of its shape and mass. As the teabag burns, it creates a sort of tunnel of hot air above it. As it burns lower, it loses more and more mass in the form of smoke and other debris until the very last remnants of it burn enough mass off to rise with that stream of hot air. If you ever look at a campfire, you will notice the same thing going on with the sparks that float up and occasionally land on you. The waste after burning the teabag looks bigger, but it only has a really tiny mass.

The first two are not 'physics phenomena'.  They are 'human phenomena'.  Physics doesn't 'lead' your fingers to the center of mass, you, the person, changes the movement of your fingers to maintain balance.  And a phone IS physically capable of spinning along any axis, you, the person, simply doesn't have the skill/touch to apply the correct forces because the margin for error is very small.  The last three are the only 'phenomena' that occur due to physics as opposed to human involvement.  In a video meant to bring physics education to those currently without it, be a little more careful.  People walking around with misconceptions like 'its not physically possible for a phone to spin a certain way' instead of 'its not easy/likely for a human to spin a phone around a certain axis' is a Pandora's box of ignorance.

The iPhone is full of unbalances inside of the device. Even though the phone's external appearance may look symmetrical, the internal perspective is just everywhere. The big battery pack is on the left, the mother board is on the right, there are many different things in odd and different places scattered within the phone. When the phone is tossed in the air and spins, there is no center to rotate on. So, gravity takes a hold of the other things in there to rotate on and that's where the phone spins unevenly. If you were to open your iPhone (Not alone but by a professional phone repairer) you would see that the phone has many sections of electronics inside. Everything in there is divided from the cameras, to the battery, to the mother board and so many other things under the mother board you can't see, there is no exact axis to spin on. But, even if you spin your phone in any other way, it still doesn't have an even axis to rotate on. It may look like it but, gravity isn't completely even.

If you move a positive + charged rod close to water:
1. The water molecules would orient themselves so their oxygen atoms would point towards the rod
2. Like charges attract, and water is bended towards the rod.

If you move a negative - charged rod to water, the same thing happens, but this time the hydrogen would point towards the rod.

Without having read any of the comments below or watched the solution video, these are explanations from the top of my head:

1- Every time you move the "supporting points" (fingers) the cane rebalances itself. You'll be moving your fingers towards each other only in the measure the cane allows you to...it actually "controls" your movements by the simple act of rebalancing itself.  For instance, the finger that's closer to the center of equilibrium will experience slightly more friction because the cane will be pushing against it the hardest, that will result in your other finger being able to move more easily (thus, faster). When the situation gets reversed, the other finger will then move faster and this process will go on until both fingers are at the point of equilibrium. It's all about balancing and friction.

2- This is due to friction too. The phone will try to move in the most efficient way (the one that requires less effort, that is). Since that kind of rotation involves the larger area of the phone, there's too much air friction for the rotation to be maintained as it is, so the phone eventually "surrenders" to friction and starts tilting so air can pass through more easily.
It stabilizes on the other axis because it's the more efficient one... I guess...

3- LOL...I'm going to say friction again! Well, air currents, to be more exact.
As the water stream moves, it pushes the air around it. When you put the cup close to it, you are creating a "wall" that blocks the air's path as it gets pushed by the stream of water. Perhaps that creates some sort of air current that circulates, making the air slightly less dense on the cup's side. That means that the air on the opposite side of the water stream will push harder against the stream than the air on the cup's side and that will make the stream come closer to the cup....
I'm saying this because that's what happens with shower curtains. They move inside the shower and stick to your body because the air within the shower is less dense (since the water stream of the shower is creating an air current).
Maybe I'm wrong, but this explanation is damn good, LOL

4- The cereal thing...I'll say that when it contacts water it becomes polarized.

5- That's an easy one. The convection currents created by the mix between hot and cold air are lifting what's left of the bag.
It doesn't start levitating until the end because that's when it becomes light enough for the convection currents to lift it.
Let's say that the twr (thrust-weight ratio) is too low until the bag turns completely into ashes (which are extremely light), then the twr equals 1 (or more) and so the ashes are lifted....much like a rocket. I guess that, in the end, that can also be considered friction, LOL

1) Statics/Friction. As one finger moves it gets closer to the center of mass the larger the normal force, therefore, more friction. The finger that slides is the one that is farthest away.

2) Center of mass. The phone has different weighted parts in different locations from the axis.

3) Electric Fields. The Cup is a "charged particle" and has energy levels that get lower as you get farther from it. The water is not pulled toward it. It instead follows the same energy field around the cup until the force of gravity pulls the water down and away.

4) Minerals/Magnetism. There are minerals in the cereal that our bodies need to stay healthy. One that is magnetic in particular is Iron.

5) Air Currents/Fluid Mechanics. As the tea bag is burning it is drawing air in and heating it up. This causes a decrease in density causing the air to rise. This motion causes a drag force upwards on the tea bag. When the drag force exceeds the weight of the tea bag it takes off.

We know that objects moving away from us exhibit red shift from the Doppler effect and we see that everything that is far away exhibits a red shift proportional to the distance away. We then assume that this means that everything is moving away from us. Since things that are far away appear to be moving faster, we assume that space everywhere is expanding in all directions. Extrapolating back grime the current rate of expansion we then come to the conclusion that there was a beginning point, where the universe was infinitely dense, thus, the Big Bang. At this point, the laws of Physics fall apart and science cannot fully explain the beginning. The half-answer is that nothing was before the Big Bang because time did not exist. However, all of these conclusions hinge of the assumption that red shift is exclusive to expansion. However, this is not necessarily true. Suppose light degrades over long distances - not through absorption (which would cause a light amplitude decrease as a percentage of photons are wholly absorbed in the particle sense and we account for this by identifying reference markers that produce a theoretically known output), but through a form of photonic evaporation. A photon traveling through space may interact with neutrinos or other subatomic particles that do not absorb or deflect the photon entirely or even defract the wave, but may interact with the energy of the photon causing it to red shift. This effect would be very small and only detectable over incredibly long distances (such as the observation of light from distant galaxies). It would also compound and become more apparent in further galaxies. With this hypothesis, the need for an expanding universe theory becomes obsolete, as does the need for a Big Bang or any beginning of time. While it is true that objects moving towards or away from us exhibit blue or red shift, the fact that things far away are red shifted does not necessarily mean that they are moving away and a universal red shift observation is not sufficient grounds to establish an origin of the universe hypothesis. It's simple logic. If A then B does not necessarily mean if B then A.

#3, you are partly incorrect. While it is true that the polarity of water is not large enough to result in the water drops changing course, there is an overall attraction caused simply by polarization--otherwise you wouldn't be able to pick up bits of paper with a charged plastic comb, and you wouldn't be able to stick a toy balloon to a wall. While it is true that the opposite charges are attracted and the like charges repel, overall the like charges are slightly farther apart than the opposite charges they are paired with. Since there IS a gradient in the electric field due to the inverse square law, the opposite charges are attracted with slightly more force than the force of repulsion of the like charges.

1:  Your fingers end up at the center of gravity because the finger that is closest to the center of gravity will bear more of the weight, while the other finger bears less of the weight.  The finger with less force is the one that moves in relation to the rod.  Theoretically, the finger with the least force will be the only one to move.  If the force is exactly equal, both will move.  In practice, that's really close to what actually happens.  Variations in the coefficient of friction and the angle of the force make it less than exact.

2: Theoretically, you can flip it end over end if you do it absolutely perfectly.  Since you can't, the fact that rotating end over end is an unstable configuration means that any small imperfection is going to cause the rotational axis to rotate.  (Does that make sense?  heh)

3) The stream of water is attracted by electrostatic forces the similar to the way that a ferromagnetic metal is attracted to a magnet.  The same thing works with a rubber comb and bits of paper.  It's simply a matter of different electrostatic charges attracting each other.

4) The cereal is very slightly magnetic because it contains tiny bits of iron.  The iron is added by the manufacturer as a food suplement.  It is listed in the ingredients as reduced iron.

5: The teabag rocket is more of a hot air balloon.  What really happens is that the heat of the fire causes an updraft.  The rising air carries the light ash along with it.  It is something that you see in pretty much every campfire.

Love these questions!!! Reposting Marcin Szczurowski's answers:

1) When center of gravity is closer to one finger, the force related to gravitational pull is greater on that finger. Therefore friction is greater and when it's great enough, it becomes static friction. Finger which is further away from the center of gravity now moves closer to it until it will cross the balance and stop and so on.
2) If phone is rotated along axis perpendicular to the screen, momentum is greatest. Greatest force is needed to actually change rotation direction. Aerodynamic forces are the weakest in that configuration. Second most extreme case is rotating it as you show it. Momentum isn't that big and aerodynamic forces push it out of balance easily. Then you have precession and nutation...
3) Polar nature of water molecules actually contributes here. Keesom force is ~1/r^6 so it wouldn't work in that distance. It looks like plain electrostatic force caused by electrostatic induction.
4) Cereal contain magnetic particles. I guess no special tricks here ;)
5) Tea bag is very light. When it burns it gets even lighter. Also, flame causes hot air to go up, which is direct cause to convection. The rest of teabag lifts on convection current. It should be even easier to show when you burn it on some kind of wire net or strainer. Air would flow easier.
Cheers!
~Marcin

I can't see how the video is right about the water-cup case.

-> It can't be because of a net charge in the water because the expt works on distilled water droplets.
-> You could argue that it is the separation of OH and H ions, but the video seems to argue the effect happens even in uniform fields.  Whether the polarization of the water occurs due to change water orientation or due to ion separation, there would be no net force in uniform fields. In either case, the effect can be explained as due to polarizability of water, though the origin of the polarizibility is a little different.
-> The video argues that a nonuniform field's gradient is too small on the scale of the molecule... but this doesn't matter: In polarizable media the net charge appears on the medium's surfaces (so a few mm apart here), not within the medium. So I still think even a non-ionizing polar liquid would be attracted.
-> Can't be due to inductive effects cause there's no magnetic field and it works on distilled droplets.

The cereal can be pulled around because there is iron in it. This can be proved by crushing cereal into small bits and using a strong magnet to attract it. As for the cane trick, when you apply two parallel forces to the ends of the rod, the forces applied on one side are countered by the weight in the middle, which is back countered by the force on the other end, so the rod is stable. yet when you move one finger towards the middle, the weight on the end that the finger just left has no counter, so a torque is generated, which can make the rod tip and fall. In order to counter that, your finger moves toward the center of mass. The phone explanation is fairly simple. This works much like the spinning disk trick Derek showed on his channel. The phone, when flipped on its screen, has largest air resistance, which works no different than friction. This slows the torque in one direction and caused torque in a second direction, causing the unbalanced center of mass, which is at the top for most phones, to be off center to the contact, which causes more turning, in which gyroscopic momentum takes over causing the phone to spin in multiple directions. The other two I do not know.

As to #1: The cane exerts a force onto your fingers due to gravity. The closer one of one's fingers is getting to the center of mass, the stronger is the exerted force on the particular finger thus more weight being on it and hence is it easier to move the other finger near the center of mass until it is closer as the other. This goes on until both fingers are under the center of mass.

To #2: Either the mass is not balanced thus forcing the spin along another axis, or more energy is required to spin along the intended axis (perhaps due to traction between object and air), so the object is reorienting  itself along an axis wich requires less energy to spin around.


To #3: Despite you saying that water it is not attracted due to it being a polar molecule, the polarity of the water, and partly, too, due to the dissolved ions in it, is responsible for the deflection/attraction. I conclude this because Petroleum, a non polar/not as strong polar molecule as water, is not affected. However, substances and solvents which are, such as water, highly polar or have a lot of freely moving charges are affected. Water is a special case because it forms Hydrogen bonds due to the high difference in electronegativity of 'H' & 'O'. The clusters of H2O-molecules are orienting themselves internally according to the applied electric field. Due to the originally form of those molecule clusters and their reorientation in the electric field, the water stream is bent.

To #4: Water has magnetic properties; however, I rather think the serial contains some substance with better magnetic properties.

To #5: Hot air rises; this causes the very light remains of the tea bag to rise with the hot air.

As for the water one, I believe it is because tap water has a semi-significant amount of ions in solution inside it. Thus, the negatively charged cup polarizes the water (the positively charged ions move on average towards the cup, and vice-versa for the negatively charged ions). This polarization leads to the positive charges being closer to the cup than the negative charges, which induces an overall force towards the cup on the water. A way to test this would be to take deionized water, and see if it exhibits the same phenomenon.

Note that I haven't done any back-of-the-envelope calculations on this -- this is purely a humble scientist's speculation.

I can figure out two, but the others leave me confused.

1) We subconsciously move one finger more than the other when we notice the cane is about to drop on that side. The others might be right about friction, but that seems like it's not enough to cause this. I say it's all in our heads. When somebody else is holding the cane, you can't feel it falling one way or another and you can't compensate.
2) Let's call X, Y and Z the length, width and height of a phone. It seems the longer the axis you're trying to rotate it, the harder it is to get a good flip. I think it might be because the center of gravity is closer to the margin along the Y axis than around the X. I observed that when flipping along the Z axis, the center of gravity stays almost in the same place, so it's very stable. When flipping along the Y axis, it moves more. But flipping along the X axis, the center of gravity moves the most, therefore you create the most instability in the system. And it wants to quickly stabilize itself and it's easier to do this by flipping the phone on the Y axis just as it's about to reach the tipping point along the X axis. If you don't put enough force to tip it over the X axis, it'll just flip along the Y. If you do put enough force, it'll flip along both, but in a way that stabilizes it faster (rotating along the diagonal is faster at spending that extra energy you put into the system than rotating end over end).
3) Actually, I think you might be wrong. It must be the polar side of the water. I'm thinking when I pull a magnet with another magnet (let's say I'm holding on to the negative side and I'm using the plus to get close to the other magnet). Unless I push perfectly against the other magnet's positive, it'll flip and the negative will stick to my positive. Even though the positive side of the magnet is still being repelled by my positive, the magnets will still pull each other until they connect. That's because the magnetic lines are only ever straight going perpendicular to the poles. Get in from any other angle and I hit a magnetic line coming from the other pole (negative) which will pull on the negative side along that line, rotating it (especially as I'm pushing the positive side at the same time in the other way). Water is basically the same, just weaker. But as soon as you rotate one molecule, it is now facing with the negative away from the cup, thus attracting with its negative side another molecule's positive side (in addition to the cup's negative). This results in a chain reaction that bends the water towards the cup.

3 - i consider the case of a molecule first. Let's assume the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms have "turned towards the cup (the electric field generator)" due to attraction, and the oxygen is "facing away" from it. That means that the oxygen is slightly further away from the cup than the hydrogen atoms. Since the force of attraction is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the objects attracting each other, there will be infinitesimally less force of repulsion on the oxygen than will be force of attraction on the two hydrogens together, therefore the net force on the molecule will attract it towards the cup. Then this example can be extrapolated to an entire stream of water molecules.

I'm no expert, but I'll try my take on this:

1) The finger near the top of the cane is closer to the mass, so it must support more weight than the finger near the bottom of the cane. Therefore, it experiences a greater normal force exerted by the handle, and would experience a greater frictional force as well, slowing it down sufficiently as the two fingers approach the center of mass.
2) The first two spins are easier to perform because they have a much lower moment of inertia, and take less work to spin at a certain angular speed. Furthermore, they have more structural stability due to its shorter lever-arm radius, the pivot axis is located in the center of the phone. But the harder spin is less stable because the pivot axis is at the edge of the phone rather than the center.
3) This is a tough one. I still think the explanation provided in the video is enough. But since Veritasium insists that's not the answer, I'm guessing it might have something to do with the properties of water when exposed to an electric field, or what effects an electric field has on the hydrogen bonds of the water molecules. Or perhaps the orientation of the water molecules still have an effect on the path of the stream of running water.
4) Cheerios have a small amount of iron, a ferrous and magnetically attractive metal.
5) When the rest of the tea bag is burned, hot air is formed above the remaining pieces of the tea bag. Since the hot air is less dense than the surrounding air, it exerts less pressure on top of the remaining piece, and the air pressure on the bottom of the pieces generates sufficient lift.

So probably not the specific terminology but
#1: so your fingers are moving towards each other and one finger stops sliding until the other finger moves towards it, and so on until the two fingers are one fulcrum. The reason why one finger stops is because the other finger is holding more of the canes weight up due to the directional force of gravity over it. This weight, along with the moving finger, move toward the static finger until the force (f=ma) of the moving side overpowers the force of friction on the static side allowing the two fingers to begin moving toward each again until one finger stops again, repeating the process until there are equal amounts of (cane) weight over the two fingers, which have now become one fulcrum.
#2: the flat side of the phone presents more surface area and is pushed off its axis due to surface tension between the surface area of the phone and the oxygen and the molecules in the air.
#3: (I'm really guessing on these 😜) the oxygen molecules in the air surrounding the charged cup become negatively charged and are pushed away from the cup creating an atmosphere that is less dense allowing the water to be drawn to the outer "shell" of the charged air due to the polarity of the oxygen molecules in the water and air. The water doesn't move entirely to the cup due to the inner sphere of the charged object being less dense and allowing the water to fall.
#4: the cereal has iron in it; part of daily minerals and vitamins.
#5: this is coming very close to the laws of thermodynamics I think, but: once the material of the tea bag is burned and converted into smoke or ash, the remaining weight that is still burning is light enough for the heated oxygen around it to overcome the force of gravity and lift it off the plate. Very much the same reason how hot air balloons have lift off.

Explanation for the cane phenomena:

Upon the finger closer to the center of mass rests a higher weight (law of the lever), thus there is more frictional resistance between the cane and this finger than for the other finger. The cane will therefore only slide on the other finger when moving both fingers towards each other - until the finger where the cane slides on gets closer to the center of mass than the other. This continues to alternate until both fingers meet at the center of mass.

1) Balacing the stick - Its our brain (cerebellum) which is responsible for that balancing act. No matter where you start, how fast you move your finger, the brain actually determines the rough COM (centre of mass)and stops your fingers from moving once you are close to it. Guessing is difficult because our eyes cannot determine the mass distribution of the stick. But due to continuous feedback from our finger about the mass distribution of the stick, the brain adjusts the position of our fingers. if you notice clearly, the finger while trying to balance, also moves slightly up and down to balance the extra torque. The final answer is that the fingers move to balance the torque on each finger. (even up and down till the two fingers meet at the COM)
2) Whenever a 'free' body is given a torque, it always rotates about its center of gravity (since the earth's gravitational field is almost uniform at this scale, COM and COG coincides). so we can also say that it rotates about its COM.Due to the asymetric distribution of mass, it tries to re-orient itself to the axis which has a symmetric distribution. Thus explaining the seemingly irregular rotation of your iphone. (and hope you didnt break it in the fall :P) If you want a further technical explanation, the extra mass due to a component of its weight, causes a torque and since the phone is rotating already, this causes a tilt, (conserving angular momentum) similar to the explanation of conservation of angular momentum of a gyro. and this tilt is oscillating because in every tilt, the weight component of the heavier part increases and decreases causing the peculiar rotation.
3) The deflection of the water stream is due to the turbulence of air created by the magnet. There are tiny dust particles which are magnetic (may be due to intrinsic or induced magnetism) which are attracted towards the cup. this movement or technically - Entrainment of air between the cup and water stream cases the water jet to deflect. The curvature of the cup also plays an important role.  And try to do the same with a flat surface - say a plastic square dice or plate . Ths effect is extremely neglible or doesnt happen. This deflection due to the cup happens even when the cup is not charged. This effect is called coanda effect and is practically used in fluid logic gates and STOL aircrifts.( this effect is more rpofound in streamlined flow) The main physics behind the coanda effect is still under research.

1: (Cane Balancing)
As you pull your fingers together the cane unequally applies a contact force to each finger. It just so happens that when it does become unbalanced, the finger furthest away from the centre of mass (COM) will experience smaller contact force, meaning less friction and allowing that finger to slide whereas the closer finger will experience a larger contact force, meaning it slides less (or stays in place) due to more friction, allowing the further finger to slide closer.

2: (Phone Flip)
It's all about the moment of inertia around each axis. In the case of 1:13 (spinning on short-axis), the intended axis of rotation has a low moment of inertia compared to the other axes. But in the case of 1:18 (flipping end-over-end), you intend to rotate the phone where the moment of inertia is much larger. However, it's still very sensitive to rotating on the short-axis where the moment of inertia is much lower, meaning it takes much less effort to accidentally spin it. It's possible that the unevenness of the air would cause this, whereas spinning on short-axis (1:13) is much less affected by it.
In the case of 1:09, it's still sensitive to short-axis torque, but it's thrown a bit like a frisbee, which is easier to control and experiences less unevenness in the air.

Phenomenon 2: The centre-of-gravity of the iPhone is off-centred on the horizontal axis, but it is centred on the vertical axis. The battery is the heaviest component of the iPhone, and it is toward the left of the phone, hence the iPhone tends to rotate to the left as it is thrown along the vertical axis, but not when you throw is along its short axis or sideways.

Let me try to explain it with Math. Say you have an X and Y axis, with (0,0) being its neutral position. The top of the iPhone is (0,10), the bottom of the iPhone is (0,-10), the left side of the iPhone is (-5,0) and the right side of the iPhone is (5,0). The centre-of-gravity would be at about (-2.5,0). So when you flip the phone vertically, it will tend to rotate to the left.

1. I do not think this is a phenomena of physics, so much as phenomena of psychology. As you bring your fingers closer together, you will feel the shifting of the weight in one finger or the other, and reflexively adjust accordingly. It's not like you're determining the center of mass with your fingers. Notice how his fingers end up in the same spot each time.

2. Fairly simple. In the first scenario, you are flipping it in a fashion such that the phone has very little surface area for air resistance as relative to the force vector that is causing it to spin. In the second, you are flipping it very close to its center of mass. However, in the third, you are flipping it with a wide surface area for air resistance, and from a point that is as far from the center of mass as possible. This gives you a very wide margin for human error, which in the end I believe this comes down to. Even an "almost perfect" flip isn't actually perfect. There's just too large of a margin for error for most people to make a perfect flip.

3. Not sure on this one, but I am pretty sure that the answer lies within insulation/conduction, rather than polarity. We know that water is more conductive than air. This is why electricity runs through it easily, and why humidity has such a large effect on temperature. We also know that plastic is a great insulator. I can only speculate that insulation of the plastic cup and the conductivity of the water would cause the electricity to be more attracted to the water, thus causing the deflection.

4. Not sure on this one, either. My speculation would be that the cereal itself isn't actually magnetic. I think this relates more to the water that the cereal is in reacting to the magnet, not the cereal itself. 

5. Again, not really a clue. Only thing I can guess is that tea might have mild explosive properties.

Remember, this is all just speculation. I don't have much education in physics outside of highschool. This is probably just me trying to sound smart. :P

1. The finger closest to the centre of mass between the 2 will have more distributed weight than the other finger, which means more friction.  The finger further from the center of mass is free to move closer. This repeats until both fingers are under the centre of mass.  Try this with a cane that has 1 side much rougher than the other.

2. When you flip it any direction, it wobbles on the other axes. There are 2 reasons, imbalanced mass, and the bigger reason, the air in the room.  This wobble would be virtually eliminated in a vacuum.  As for why this effect is exaggerated when flipped end over end?  It's because this end over end orientation has the largest amount of surface area so it wobbles to show a surface with less surface area (less work).

3. It would be very easy to say water is just water.  There are contaminants which play a role but this effect is largely due to the fact that even distilled H20 is a mixture of H20, OH- and H+(all three at the same time unless the pH is perfectly balanced).  The H+(small) is actually drawn to the cup, the OH-(large) is pushed away, this leads the the bend you see.

4. I actually had to think about this one for a few minutes.  And then I realized how obvious it is.  Cereal companies add iron (and other minerals) to cereal, it actually IS magnetic but can only be observed when a lot of friction is removed.

5. The channel of air within the teabag is heated which decreases its density, less dense object float.  As you reach a certain point, the updraft of hot air exiting the top of the column pushes against the walls of the column eventually pushing the object into the air.

1. Because the stick does not rotate, we know that the sum of the moments of the forces applied by the fingers (relative to the center of mass) is zero. This means that the finger furthest from the CoM applies a lesser force. With that lesser force on the stick the furthest finger experiences less friction and slides inwards until the other finger is furthest etc.
2. The rotation around the axes of largest and smallest moment of inertia are stable. The rotation around the axes with moment of inertia between the other moments of inertia is always unstable (try it with a book held shut with an elastic band)
3. The electric field is not uniform (there is a gradient because of the cup's shape) . A non-rubbed cup does not bend the jet, so Bernouilli's effects by air entrainment is ruled out as explanation.
4. Cerial contains iron
5. Hot air rises. The upward flow is strong enough once the teabag is small (light) enough to drag it along upward.

For the cane to stay flat the anticlockwise and clockwise moments need to balance. The finger that is further from the center of mass will have a lower reaction force on it so that it generates the same moment as the closer finger. As there is a weaker horizontal for on the more distant finger, there is a weaker frictional force. Therefore the more distant finger slides more easily towards the center of mass. The process repeats until you get to the center of mass.

In terms of the phone phenomena, I'm guessing that the weight of the parts inside a phone are distributed in such a way that when flipped along the short, flat axis the motion becomes unstable.

In terms of the water phenomena, water might get attracted to charged cups because oxygen itself is magnetic.

In the cereal case, cereal manufacturers add iron to the cereals. So what you see there is the iron in the cereal being pulled by the magnet.

In terms of the teabag rocket, the teabag is very light. So, when it's ignited a little bit of air right above it gets displaced by the heat provided by the flame. Thus, the teabag rushes to fill that void. Heavier objects wouldn't do this.

I hope I'm not too late for comments. The cell phone rotation is most likely related with the moment of inertia. For the same angular velocity, a bigger the moment of inertia will "create" a bigger the angular momentum. The force applied to start a rotation will apply a torque since it's unlikely to be aligned with the center of mass. A stronger angular momentum will reduce the precession and therefore keep the phone rotating on the same axis. My guess is that with enough time  (e.g. floating in space) then we would see the same effect in both axis, although one would be faster than the other.

2) This one hasn't been covered much so ill cover it. This phenomenon is do to a thing called moments of inertia about and axis. In objects like a sphere all axis of rotation have the same moment of inertia. An object like a rectangular prism however have three distinct axis of rotation and and so three different moments of inertia which are not all stable. In general there is a primary axis of rotation and a secondary axis of rotation calculated by using Euler angles and matrices which is beyond the scope of this answer. There is also a intermediate axis which is inherently unstable. The phone does not flip end over end because it is on this intermediate axis.

1. It's not exactly a physics phenomena. It takes it's essence in neural reflexes of the human body. When you start "holding" the cane from the end with your fingers, your arms and hands are put under a constant amount of tension. Your arms and hands are then "locked" in that equilibrium state, and every time you move your fingers along the cane you unconsciously adjust the position of your fingers so that the amount of weight they're feeling is always the same, thus counterbalancing the torque put on the cane because of the distance between the equivalent push point and the center of mass of the cane.
When you put you fingers right from the beginning at the center of mass, your arms and hands do not put the same amount of force to counter the weight, thus producing torque which causes the cane to fall.
2. The phones have their weight adjusted along the long axis and normal-to-screen axis because they are important to the feeling of adjusted mass when in our hands. The short axis however is not important because we have our fingers all around the most important direction of weight distribution (the long axis of the phone) thus counterbalancing the torque that'll make it turn along the short axis. It's linked to the shape of the weight distribution matrix with the intertial products being equal to zero for the well-balanced axis thus not producing a torque when spinned along that axis, and not equal to zero for the short axis, producing a torque in other axis. That's why the rotation isn't "clean" when the phone is spinned along the short axis.
3. It's not because water is polar, this trick works with every material if it can moves along two axis of gap-closing between the material and the electrically charged object. For conducting materials, "free" electrons are pushed to the farest place from the charged object in the conducting material, thus attracting the closest part of the material from the charged object, towards the charged object.
For non-conducting materials, i have two theories. The first being that water has a pH of 7, which means that hydroxide ions and their ionics water-type ions are present in water. With the electrical field, tha negatively charged ions are pushed away from the charged object, and the positively charged object are attracted toward the charged object, thus attracting the water toward the charged object.
My second theory is that the shape of the atoms, desinged by the electron's orbits of every atoms are distorded because of the electric fiels, and makes it possible to the now atoms with a nucleus close to the charged object and the electrons away from it attracted toward the charged object.
4. For the cheerio, the argumentation is the same, but there's a subtle difference. The cheerio is full of water, and the ater inside of it is attracted toward the magnet. The waterless part of the cheerio floating above the surface, and being relatively light in comparison to the water it's full of, is being moved around by the attraction of the water inside of it toard the magnet. You could possibly do the same thing with an electrically charged object.
5.When you burn the teabag in that shape, you produce hot and light air which wants to go up (giving the flame it's shape). The thing is, when the fire comes to the bottom of the teabag, the teabag is light enough for the flame to pull the teabag upward with it, and this movement accelerate because of the constantly reducing mass of the teabag and the constant pull of the flame. It only works in this configuration because there's a higher surface of chemical reaction (more flame) for every unit of mass of the teabag (the "chainmill" of fabric is spread wide enough for the final flame fueld pulling point to happen before the teabag is entirely consumed), and because there's an air column hotter then room temperature accumulated inside the teabag tube, thus giving pressure (hot air column) under the teabag, and depression over the teaba (the flame).

1. That's a beautiful self-calibrating system (other stuff going on, but same result as with railway wheels - you could cover that topic once, it is really fascinating!). The moment one finger gets nearer to the centre of mass than the other, there is more gravitational force onto that finger than on the other, increasing friction, which means the other one moves faster. It "overtakes" the first one, thus becoming the closer one, thus becoming the more loaded one, thus becoming the more braked one, so the first one slips faster... etc. Thus a limitation of the demonstration: It only works with roughly constant coefficient of friction. Would it be rubber on one and steel on the other side of the centre of mass, the self-calibration would not work any more.
2. I would guess that's an aerodynamic issue. The slightest instability (and since the object's movement through air is creating turbulence, there always is instability no matter how exact you may start off) makes the object turn slightly around the long axis - and once this has happened, the surface isn't perpendicular to the vector of movement, resulting in a sidewards force by the air which leads to further tilt, throwing the whole thing off course. If you flip it around the long axis, you also have the same effect; but in this case the object turns much faster (since the mass is nearer to the axis) resulting in much higher resistance towards changes to the movement (same effect which keeps bicycles stable), so the rotation is subdued to slight slingering only instead of being completely destabilised.

5. The flame creates hot air, which is going up, thus creating a pressure drop which sucks (cold) air from the sides towards the flame resulting in an eddy (that suck of air towards the fire is the very same effect on which the principle of fighting fire with fire is based). With the tea bag burning it becomes lighter and lighter till its gravitational force drops below that eddy's upwards suck on the object.

For the cane: each of your hands are trying to balance the cane as they are moving closer to each other, as you move each side independently of their speed towards the center you are also pacing them without realizing it. Try doing this with 2 robotic arms, my guess is that it will not work the same way unless of course calculated.
For # 3 Flowing liquids create static charge.

The cane: The distance from the center is relative to the force placed upon the finger. If you consider the cane a lever, the center acts as a fulcrum, and the fingers as forces upon the lever, the closer the finger is to the center (fulcrum) the less force it places on the lever, and the more force is placed upon the further finger, the reason the finger's slip like they do in a jerky motion is because they only move after the other finger has advanced to a point at which static friction is over come by the energy you're placing into the system.

The phone flip: The precision required to keep the phone in a stable spin via equally imparting energy on each side in this manner is too great, and the force you impart is seldom even, so it's a good model for the butterfly effect. If you think about how narrow it is, the distance from the edge to the center is very small, so there is very little resistance on this axis to prevent it's spin from changing.

The cup: Because cup was designed to hold water, and as such, they place heavy magic in every cup to hold the water down, obviously.

The cereal:There is iron in the cereal, it's a good thing. Much like early compass, the resistance to movement while floating atop the water is very little, so it's not going to work while placed under the water, you might notice he's using bucky balls which are very strong magnets, the force is very little, so it needs this strong magnet to work as the iron content is very small.

Tea Bag rocket:The updrafts caused by the flame lift the tea bag up once enough of a draft has formed, and enough of the mass has left in the form of CO2 for the draft to productively move the tea bag with just the thrust provided by the friction from the air.
