Just gonna go on logic and guessing without research lol:
1. When your friend is holding the cane, you'd have to know exactly where the center of mass is to correctly place your fingers. When you're doing it yourself, the finger on the lighter side (outside of both fingers) of the cane will move more easily toward the center of mass than the finger on the heavier side, due to less friction. Once both fingers are an equal distance from the center of mass, they will both slide together with equal friction toward the center of mass.
2. I really don't know, but I would guess the Earth's rotation might have a slight effect. Once the length (forward and back relative to the phone-flipper) of the object exceeds the width (left to right relative to the phone-flipper,) the rotation of front end over back end becomes subject to the Earth's rotation because of the object's shorter axis of rotation.
OR (after writing the whole comment this occurred to me. lol)
When the length of the phone (forward to back) is shorter than the width of the phone, the effects of gravity on each end of the width (longer side) are sufficient enough to straighten or correct any uneven force you may have given to each side of the width of the phone when flipping it, or the inertia in the flipping direction would be greater than the inertia over the different axis of rotation that is caused by our human error to apply the force evenly on both ends of the phone while flipping it. This would straighten the phone to flip end over end. But when the length of the phone is greater than the width, the uneven force given to each end of the width of the phone (on the left and right relative to the phone-flipper) while flipping causes the rotational inertia over the axis caused by your uneven flipping to be greater than the rotational inertia around the shorter axis of the intended flip. I think this would be because when you have the longer side flipping end to end (front and back to the flipper,) there is more mass moving in the direction of the flip than the direction of the uneven applied force, whereas when the shorter side is flipping front to back, there is less mass moving in the direction of the flip than in the direction of the uneven applied force. Causing the longer axis to win out over time. 
*If the Earth's rotation doesn't come into play, I think the phone could theoretically be flipped perfectly if the force applied to each end while flipping is exactly equivalent.

had a go at the first one to see if it did depend on friction. Found out it does depend on friction.  As the one side moves, the work required for it to continue moving is limited by the friction that opposes it.   The frictional increase is a function of the increases in distributive mass.  *Needed some edits*

designed a datum math technique which is kind of new (consider our year system 2014 AD, or 2014 BC) and in some ways more natural, and models the problem from the perspective of the center of mass. Its value lies in the fact that all quantities have magnitude and don't depend on direction or negative math. I don't know if it has any use anywhere, this was more an exercise in accounting.  I'm posting it anyway because someone might want to use it.  

let the cane have the datum y such that its length is x + z and the mass M_1 is distributed over x, the mass M_2 is distributed over z, then total mass M_t = M_1 + M_2
y is located at the center of mass, so x is the positive distance from y, and z is the positive distance from y.  Note the datum y (center of mass) has the characteristics of unit length when used in equations, but since its a datum it also has the property of additive identity y+z=z so initially it carries only point magnitude. (Note; magnitude of y can be modified so that the distributive mass remains constant as z & x -> 0, but someone else play with that).  

let g be gravity

then the distributed forces involved are
F_1 = gM_1y/z = gM_2y/x = F_2 and the fingers/fulcrums are located at x and z

Let r, a, elements of length allow us to shift the finger on one side where a is the distance of movement then consider just one side of the equation

F_1a_p = gM_1ya_pr/(zr-za_p)  where a_p is the parallel component of a to F_1

if the problem was frictionless, then there would be no work since these distributive forces are perpendicular to the motion, so friction has to be used

let u be the cane friction coefficient that scales the distributed forces 
then the variable friction coefficient u_1 = ugM_1r/(r-a), (note "a" is parallel to u_1 by design.)

the distributed perpendicular force F_p opposing u_1
W_1 = F_pa = u_1M_1ya/z (note this is a static solution)

and if we introduce the scale modifier s such that sa = b

then 2nd variable friction coefficient u_2 = ugM_2sr/(sr-b)

thus the equality of simultaneous scaled movement would look like

W_1 = u_1ya/z = u_2yb/x = W_2

and under the shift of one side only we have
W_1 = u_1ya/z > u_2y(b=0)/x = 0

so where u_1y/z > ugM_2y/x movement cannot continue... therefore friction is needed.(this is ambiguous and needs refining since there is a static limit that isn't accounted)

This hasn't been vetted by anyone, so improvements and refinements and probably needed, are welcome.

First Phenomena
A combination of sum moments and friction - since the sum of moments dictate that if the object is not rotating, the moments effecting the rod must cancel out.  That said, the distance from the centre of mass of each finger multiplied by the force of each finger holding the cane up is the same for each finger.  If one finger is further away from the object, it will have less of the weight of the cane to carry, therefore it would have less normal force compared to the other finger and less friction.  This leads the finger further away to more easily move closer to the centre of mass until the moving finger becomes the finger closer to the center of mass and the effect is flipped on the other finger which is now further from the centre of mass.  This repeats over and over again until the fingers both meet at the centre of mass.
Notes:
-This works only for objects with relatively uniform surfaces.
-The jumps between the fingers taking turns moving to the centre are due to changes of kinetic and static friction (as well as slight differences in friction)
-One could move just one finger towards the other, the phenomena should still work!

1. I am particular interested in this one. first of all, this trick will not succeed without friction, since then the two fingers can slide to whatever position they like. This also means that this trick is not accomplished by "keeping the COM between two fingers" manually.
Now, First, the stick is not rotating. we can then write down(after some derivation from the equilibrium condition) f1*L1=f2*L2 where L1, L2 are the distance to the COM and f1 and f2 are the frictions. this is a rather naive equation since we are assuming that the static and kinetic coefficient of friction are equal. What happens when they are not equal? then the trick simply fails occasionally. 
At the beginning of the trick, f1 and f2 are not equal, therefore, only one hand moves until they reach the same distance from the COM. then, f1 and f2 should be equal to each other, and they close in to COM together. 
The fact that you have two hands moving alternatively is due to the difference between static and kinetic coefficient of friction.

I teach physics in Bangladesh for O & A levels. Here are my propositions (Immeadiate reaction, without googling it!!)

1. Friction. Heavier side of the cane applies more friction on the finger and allows the other finger to move. If in any side a sticky coating is placed or finger is coated round with a sticky coating this experiment won't work.

2. Behavior of gyroscope. If it were a cube, this behavior would be experienced for all three axes. Now, for smooth auto rotation stabilization, the length of the axis of rotation needs to be either too large or too small compared to the distance of the center of masses on the opposite sides of the object. whenever these two become nearly equal, spin becomes bit haphazard [not too confident explanation, but that's pretty much what I recall!!]

3. Ions present on the tap water. It's not the bipolar molecules which are mostly responsible, the positive & negative ions of the dissolved materials in tap water make the stream polarized as whole.

4. Eddy current & polarity of water particles which soak the cereal, experiment not possible if a piece of solid plastic is used OR the magnet not pulled away, i.e. held steady near the cereal from the beginning.

5. Convection current in air & the base becoming hot by the last part burning. The hollow cylindrical shape of the empty tea bag give rise to a strong swirling convection current. The tea bag becomes lighter as it slowly burns. At the last stage, the convection current of air is strong enough to push it off the surface.

I've worked on some of these phenomena, and this is my explanations for some of them:

Number 1:
While moving your fingers toward the center of mass, there are two forces acting on your firngers in its motion: the Normal force- caused by the rod's weight, and fricion- caused by the Normal force. Also, the rod is horizontal, so we can say that it's total moment is zero.
The moment is dependant of  the Normal force and the distance to the center of mass. While moving your finger toward the center of mass the total moment has to remain constant at zero to keep the rod balanced, so the normal force acting on this moving finger increases. At the same time, the weight on the other finger is reduced, until there is so much weight on the first finger so that the friction simply "stop" it's movement, while the second finger starts moving. 
This shifting between the fingers would go on until both fingers are very close to the center of mass, in which the moment is no longer relevant.

Number 3:
when the water is robbed with the pixy when it passes through it, therefore it is charged with "static electricity".

My explanation for the center of mass phenomenon: if one finger is further away from the center of mass than the other finger, then this finger experiences less force than the finger closer to the center of mass. So the finger with less force acting on it will move at a greater speed toward the center of mass when you move both fingers towards each other because it experiences less friction when its moving. You will end up with both fingers under the center of mass, because the finger closer to the center of mass gets “delayed” because of more friction when moving, because it experiences a higher load on top of it.

Phone “Trick”: You are not introducing the force to start the spinning movement in the exact middle of the short side of the phone and also your fingers supporting the underside of the phone are not completely identically placed on each left and right sides of the phone. So this imbalance causes it to spin around 2 sides because you give it the momentum to do so and the spin around the short side doesn’t need much force, because all mass is located relatively close to the center of the axis.
If you try to flip it over the long side (like holding it in landscape mode), then you can more accurately place your finger in the middle of the long side, so the momentum to start spinning around the second axis is much smaller, and because it is the long side of the phone, it has mass located further away from the center, so it would actually need even more force to start spinning around long side. 

Short answer for the cereal magnetism: Cereal contains small amounts of iron and a strong (neodymium) magnet can create a visible effect on it like you’ve demonstrated in the video.

Moving the water stream: The electric field of the cup creates an effect on the movable electric charges inside the water (i don’t mean the rotation of the molecules or the molecules themselves).
These charges opposite to the charge of the cup accumulate on the closer side the stream, whereas the equally charged particles get pushed away. So you create an charge opposite to the one of the cup in the water stream which causes it to move towards the cup. By movable electric charges I mean free electrons, impurities in the water stream, such as ions of different elements and so on…

Tea bag rocket: When you burn it, you oxidise the tea bag and leave a skeleton of carbon after it is burned. This carbon skeleton is extremely light, depending on how dense its structure is, it can even be lighter than nitrogen and oxygen which will cause it to “float on top of the air”.

The phone has three axes, with three different moments of inertia: large, medium and small.  You can derive that oscillations around the axis with the middle moment of inertia - the one that is not the largest nor the smallest - are unstable. So a tiny deviation in the phone's motion about it's middle axis will grow exponentially until the phone is rotating about a different axis. I don't have a simple hand-waving explanation, but we did derive this at one point in mechanics. - vzapf

The water stream is attracted to the cup for the same reason that a magnet is attracted to a refrigerator. If dipoles could only ever experience torques and not forces, then magnets would never be attracted to each other.

An (electric or magnetic) dipole in a SPATIALLY UNIFORM field only experiences a torque... but a dipole in a SPATIALLY VARYING field experiences a force. The "Faraday" force of a dipole in a spatial gradient field is one of the fundamental forces that derives from Maxwell's equations. 

- vzapf

# 1:  Static Friction vs. dynamic friction.  As you begin moving your hands towards the center, notice it is very difficult to get them to move together.  Usually, one finger moves a little, then the other as they gradually come to the center.  For your fingers to move, they have to first overcome static friction.  The finger supporting the most weight experiences more static friction.  Assuming equal force is applied to both fingers, the one with less static friction moves first.  As that finger moves toward the center it begins to carry more weight, thus the dynamic friction increases.  Once the dynamic friction is more than the static friction of the second finger, the first finger stops moving and the second finger begins to move.  This balancing act continues until the two fingers meet in the center of gravity. 

# 2:  Angular momentum.  Calculating for angular momentum using a hypothetical device, flipping the device with the first method experiences the most angular momentum. The second way experiences the least angular momentum.  The end over end rotation is unstable since its calculated angular momentum is less than the first and more than the second.  The device "seeks" a more stable plane of rotation, ideally the one with the least angular momentum. 

# 3:  London dispersion forces.  As Derek says in the video, "if you have a uniform electric field..."  The electric field is not uniform.  Electrons do not exist in neat orbits, rather they exist in a probabilistic state.  All atoms/molecules experience London dispersion forces; they are so weak (the weakest of the Van Der Waals forces) they are hardly noticed.  If we were to use a non-polar fluid instead of water, we should expect to see a similar result.

#4:  Magnetism.  On the back of the cereal box there is a list of all the vitamins and minerals.  One of those is iron.  Yes, there is elemental iron in your cereal.  It is necessary to support the immune system and production of red blood cells.  Iron is magnetic.  It is attracted to the "strong" magnet...slightly.

# 5:  Bernoulli's principle.  As the tea bag burns the hot air above the teabag moves much quicker thus exhibiting less air pressure on the tea bag than the surrounding the tea bag.  Throughout the entire process the tea bag experiences this "lift".  However, the force of the lift is too small to have any effect until the tea bag is almost completely burned away.  Once the mass of the tea bag is small enough, the resulting lift force lifts the tea bag into the air.

I guess number 3 (the thing with the water), is due to electromagnetic force, which is one of the four forces carried by force-carrying particles.

The other three forces carried by force-carrying particles are:
1. The gravitational force
2. The weak nuclear force
3. The strong nuclear force

If it is indeed due to electromagnetic force, this means that virtual particles (they are called virtual because they cannot be detected directly, but we know they exist) are being emitted from the cup, and absorbed in the water, changing the course of the fall of the water, and giving resistance to the person holding the cup.

These virtual particles will have spin 1, and be photons, since we are talking about electromagnetic force. In the case of for example gravitational force, the particles wouldn't be photo's, instead they would be gravitons.

This spin actually only tells us two things:
• That the virtual particle is kind of like an arrow, if you turn it around 180 degrees it won't look the same to you anymore, but if you turn it around another 180 degrees (so that in total you have turned it 360 degrees, a complete revolution), it will
• That the particle is a force-carrying particle. All particles in the universe can be divided into two catagories:
1. Matter (All 1/2 spin particles)
2. Force carrying particles ( All 0, 1, 2 spin particles)

And since the spin is 1, we can know it is a force carrying particle, but actually we already knew that because I told you

Btw, this is all quantum mechanics, which is a theory that was first proposed in the 1920s, and that was based on the uncertainty principle.

The Phone Flip.  The phone is always trying to rotate around the center mass during the flip.  My I-phone 4s' center mass is located just inside the upper right quadrant as you look at the screen. The phone will progress around that location as it flips end over end.  This is illustrated with a hammer flip as well.  Hammers flip stably until you try to flip with the head horizontally aligned.  With each flip the hammer and claw will exchange direction.  Count your flips and you can get the phone to return to the starting position.  My 4s requires four full flips to land in my hand in it's original position.

Re water attraction to charged surface.  Polar molecules are not the point.  The old experiment of torn-up paper bits (non-polar objects) are also attracted to a charged surface.  The main point is that the charged surface is of a significantly different charge than the paper bits or the water so that there is a delta voltage (charge).  That delta V then causes an attractive force.

Well the water getting attracted to the cup is a basic phenomenon in aerodynamics. It is due to the viscous nature of the fluids (air and water). As water flows down, it pulls air down with it and the air forms a kind of moving 'boundary layer' around the water. This essentially happens as flow transitions from a laminar to more turbulent flow. Some forces creep in which forces the flow to reattach.

1) at all times, more weight is on the finger closer to the centre of mass. This means it has more friction, so it pushes harder on the cane than the other finger. This results in a net force  moving the centre of mass to the midpoint of the fingers. If the friction is strong enough, it will end up at this midpoint when the fingers meet.

2) the 3 principal axes of the phone are described in the video. Rotation around them is governed by conservation of energy, (angular) momentum, and any small perturbations caused by interaction with the air. If we keep the energy constant between flips, and just look at momentum, then we can see that the long axis has a low angular momentum, since the mass is close to the axis of rotation. Any rotational axis significantly different from this axis would require a large increase in angular momentum - not possible.
Likewise, the short axis has the highest angular momentum, and any rotation with a comparable angular momentum will be very close to that axis.

The medium length axis though, flipping end over end, is between the two. An equal angular momentum can be achieved by a combination of the long and short axis rotations. Because of this, small perturbations can make the axis of rotation drift away from the original axis, and cause the phone to flip.

3 is tricky. At first I thought there would be an ionic gradient; that salts ions in the water would reposition themselves to make a net attraction. But nope, this works equally well in distilled water. Then I read that it works in some non polar liquid, and also in uniform electric fields, suggesting an actual charge. This could be the case, with current flow in the stream, and net charge on the droplets, but it sound farfetched. I'm going to wait for his explanation for this one.

4) Iron in cereal? I didn't believe it, but apparently so. They add powdered iron to your meal, not iron salts like I had thought originally, so the cereal is actually ferromagnetic.

5) Hot air rises. When the paper is light enough and hot enough, the air currents make it fly. This happens if you just burn a piece of tissue, it doesn't need to be that shape.

Regarding the tea bag: Once most of the bag has burned, the left part is very small, and therefore has a very small mass. The fire at the top creates air vacuum above what's left of the bag, and causes it to float upwards.

1.The center of mass of an object always tries to remain in the same position. So as your fingers move towards the center, the stick tends to move as to maintain the center of mass directly above them. This same phenomena is the reason boats move as you move on them.
2.The primary axis of rotation for flipping it horizontally is much larger than the secondary axis. The farthest any piece of the phone gets away from the primary axis in this case is probably only around 2.5 cm (1 in.). Therefore, the phone will mostly move the way that you forced it to.
However, when flipping it vertically, the primary axis of rotation is smaller than the secondary axis. The farthest any piece of the phone gets away from the primary axis is probably up to 7.5 cm (3 in.). Therefore, any small forces on this secondary axis will easily cause it to move. Whether it be air resistance or a human error (not flipping it perfectly)
3. In physics, Coulomb's law states that F (force) = (k (constant) * q1 (1 charge) * q2 (second charge))/(r^2 (distance between the two charges)). Initially, the water molecules align themselves as to make the positively charged side closer to the negatively charged cup. So since the positively charged side of the molecule is closer to the cup than the negatively charged side, we can use Coulomb's law to find that the force on the positive side is larger than the force on the negatively charged side(due to their distances), thus causing them to move.
4. Cereal typically has lots of iron. Try getting two types of cereal with different amounts of iron in them and see which one moves faster!
5. When you heat up the tea bag, the air inside of it gets warmer. Warm air rises. So as this tea bag is being burned, the warm air is constantly moving upwards. Also, over time the tea bag loses mass because it is being burned. When the tea bag is at a very low mass, the force from the warm air moving up is enough to cause the tea bag to fly.

1) When center of gravity is closer to one finger, the force related to gravitational pull is greater on that finger. Therefore friction is greater and when it's great enough, it becomes static friction. Finger which is further away from the center of gravity now moves closer to it until it will cross the balance and stop and so on.
2) If phone is rotated along axis perpendicular to the screen, momentum is greatest. Greatest force is needed to actually change rotation direction. Aerodynamic forces are the weakest in that configuration. Second most extreme case is rotating it as you show it. Momentum isn't that big and aerodynamic forces push it out of balance easily. Then you have precession and nutation...
3) Polar nature of water molecules actually contributes here. Keesom force is ~1/r^6 so it wouldn't work in that distance. It looks like plain electrostatic force caused by electrostatic induction.
4) Cereal contain magnetic particles. I guess no special tricks here ;)
5) Tea bag is very light. When it burns it gets even lighter. Also, flame causes hot air to go up, which is direct cause to convection. The rest of teabag lifts on convection current. It should be even easier to show when you burn it on some kind of wire net or strainer. Air would flow easier.

Just some reasons that I've thought of, please don't blame me for any incorrect answers :/

1. Main difference between the two cases lies in the senses used to judge the position of the centre of mass of cane. First case (receiving cane from friend) involves the brain making an intuitive judgment simply out of sight, rather than touch, so the centre of mass is determined simply by a very rough estimate of how heavy each end of the cane is, perhaps by their relative sizes. Second case (feeling cane by oneself) involves the brain receiving numerous signals channeled through the central nervous system. Notice that each finger inches towards the centre of mass in an alternate fashion, in quick succession regardless of the absolute speed of each finger. One finger sends signals to the brain that its end is heavier, causing the other to move further inward, before the roles are interchanged. Process repeats until centre of mass is found. Of course, accuracy of this method decreases proportionately to how fast the fingers move towards the center, as shown in the video whereby the cane 'wobbles' around until it comes to a stop.

2. This is possibly due to the fact that the weight distribution within the phone is uneven, especially so when considering the plane whose axis of rotation lies in a direction such that the phone flips from end to end. In mid-air, weight imbalances within the phone itself result in non-equal magnitudes of torque acting on each end of the phone, thus causing its direction of rotation to alter repeatedly, such that the flipping motion seems to be 'unclean'. While weight imbalances would probably exist when considering other axes of rotations as well, the difference in torque established by these imbalances would not be as significant (imagine flipping phone along its long end. While phone spins in mid-air, the left end and right end of phone have almost identical weight acting on them, so the direction of rotation hardly changes)

3. Not too sure about this one but here goes. Rubbing the cup on a rough surface releases negative charges, ie. Electrons, which accumulate on the surface of the cup. Now, consider an extremely small area along the surface of the stream at the molecular level and let time come to a pause. Placing the temporarily electron-rich surface of the cup sufficiently near to the stream instantaneously attracts the water molecules which, at that instant, have their oxygen ends facing away from this surface. At this same instant, molecules which have their oxygen ends facing towards this surface are repelled away by a small extent and move away from the layer of 'positive charges'. Molecules which have their oxygen ends facing in a direction parallel to this surface remain unaffected and continue moving downwards under action of gravity. This differs from the misconception that all the water molecules simply 'flip' around instantaneously. Now, as we move on to subsequent time frames, given the fact that the molecules are after all moving in a stream with a steady input of water molecules, more and more molecules whose oxygen ends face away from the cup surface are generated from the tap, as the stream continues flowing down. Eventually, more and more molecules then find themselves attracted to the cup surface (ie. 'Positive charges' accumulatr) such that the bending of the water stream becomes significantly visible. The same phenomenon produces diminished effects as the flow velocity increases, since the net downward force acting on each water molecule significantly outweighs the electrostatic forces of attraction between stream and cup.

4. The magnet-induced motion is due to existence of ferromagnetic substances in cereal. One might argue that if this is indeed true, then an entire box of cereal would 'fly' towards any magnet that comes near it. The key to what is shown in the video is that there was only a single piece of cereal floating on the water. This differs from an entire box of cereal in terms of weight (duh), ie. If the same magnet was used against a box of cereal, the magnetic force would essentially be too weak to overcome the weight acting on the cereal box. Besides, the same phenomenon would not be observed if the cereal was placed on a solid surface, say a table, because the magnetic force would be too weak to work against friction. Friction between cereal and water surface is significantly lower, and thus can be overcome by the magnetic force despite its weak nature, thus the floating piece of cereal freely moves around under the control of the magnet.

5. Lift is generated due to the temperature gradient between the flame and the ambient surroundings (ie. Hot air rises). Teabags are made of highly porous material so that its contents can diffuse easily in aqueous medium, and therefore its density is relatively low. So much so that once a small percentage of the original teabag is left, the small amount of lift generated is nevertheless sufficient to propel the teabag upwards.

I think that cereal isnt magnetic. It's the same phenomena as with the charged plastic cup.

1) Friction and different lever effect of the weight of the bar. Since you are pushing together your fingers, and the bar stays (approximately) still, you are applying two equal and opposite forces on the bar in the horizontal direction. In the vertical direction the closer you are to the center of mass, the higher is the force you need, thus the higher friction will be present. Then two situation can happen: the first is that you overcome the static friction, and that will be on the farther finger from the center of mass, so that finger will move. The second situation will happen when you push so hard that both fingers lose contact. In that case the forces will distribute in such a way that you will reach the center of mass. If not so, in the case you go over the center of mass with one finger, that finger would stop and the bar would fall down. Anyway it might not work if the two materials have very different friction coefficients.
2) I think the main reason is conservation of angular momentum. Friction of the air might contribute but it should not be that effective with such a heavy object. Due to the initial unbalancement of your fingers you give also a little spin on the direction of the lowest rotational inertia (the long semiaxis of the phone). Any initial unbalancement will anyway try to bring the object to spin along its axis of maximum inertia (the axis perpendicular to the screen). Since the friction of the air is low, it will keep this periodic precession oscillation. The air friction could play a role in a very long drop. I suppose that the object would align laterally, sliding through air.
3) It is not due to some air pressure effect. I think the main reason could be the presence of some ions in the water (minerals, salt, hydroxyl) thus allowing the water to conduct. If water conducts, then the distribution of the ions (positive near the cup, negative far away) is enough to create a pull force also with such a low gradient due to the elctrostatic field of the cup.
4) It should be due to the pure iron into the cereals or due to the paramagnetism of the components of the cereals. Anyway it is a really small force, and the water allows to see better the effect of this tiny magnetic force. Since paramagnetism is really extremely weak, I guess it's for the iron.
5) It is heating the air around and within the paper pipe creating convection of heat and therefore a flux of air. When the weight of the remaining is less than the force of the flux of air the remaining goes up.

I decided to figure these out before I went to bed, but I was too tired to figure out anything past two, so here are my explanations for problems one and two:

"Cane Center Of Mass"
This trick must be accomplished with an object that generates a lot of friction with the cane shaft. That is why skin and not smooth glass will work. As one moves his or her hands closer together, the shaft will begin to teeter. This is because it will loose it's grip on the finger, or fulcrum, that is supporting the lesser weight of the cane, allowing it to slip closer to the center of mass while the fulcrum that is still in contact with the cane pushes it over the first fulcrum. This action swaps the weight distribution on both of the fulfrums and the process begins again on opposite sides. This continues until one cannot push his or her fingers any closer to one another or the center of mass goes beyond the fulcrum and the cane falls off.

"Phone Flip"
After sitting around for awhile, experimenting with different objects, I concluded my hypothesis: "The closer the mass is to an axis of an object, the faster that object can spin about that object without having requiring too much energy and collecting less drag about it's rotational volume. This is why the phenomenon does not occur in objects with a rotationally-symmetrical face." I would like to point out that this type of thing occurs in objects with a center of mass that matches it's circumcenter and objects that don't match, assuming that the perspective is isographic and pointing directly at the face being measured.

-Jonathan Bryce O'Dell

My hypothesis on 3:
The oriented water molecules act as tiny dipole magnets, creating their own magnetic fields. As they fall they experience an increase in electric field, and so they induce a magnetic field in the charges on the cup, but in the "opposite" direction, thus causing a repulsive force. On the way down, they feel a decrease in electric field, so it works in the opposite direction, causing the water to attract.
Note: you could look at it from the cup's perspective and say it's a changing magnetic field, and the force is from an opposing induced electric field. Same thing, actually.

Let's see...

1. The fingers will move based on torque and friction.  A finger that is closer to the center of mass will more trouble moving because of the balance between torque and friction, and the finger farther away will have less trouble moving.  The result is you often end up with them both at the center.

2. Air resistance is higher when you flip it that way because of the radius of rotation is larger.  As a consequence of aerodynamics (and possibly the Coriolis effect as well), the phone gains another component of rotation because of this high air resistance.

3. Water is a polar molecule, which means that water molecules stick to each other.  As they rotate to align with the electric field on the cup, this causes a net movement of the molecules as they are dragged to follow the rotation of their neighbors.  (I'm not 100% confident in this answer, but it's the best I've got)

4. It could be iron in the cereal, or it could be an interaction between the water that has been absorbed into the cereal and the magnet.  (not entirely certain)

5. Easy, convection!  When the mass of the bag gets small enough due to combustion, we see the movement of air from convection (hot air rises and cold air moves in to replace it) move it into the air.

My thoughts....

1) You're constantly weighing it with your hands to balance it and find the center of gravity.
2) The lateral weight of the phone is evenly distributed on 2 axes. On the 3rd axis, the battery causes imbalance, which causes gravity to change the direction of the phone's rotation. If you spin the phone fast enough in ANY direction, it will wobble: the imbalance is just far greater on that one axis.
3) The water is grounded, so it's negatively charged. Pouring water next to a positively charged cup has no effect.
4) The cereal is not magnetic. You're changing the magnetic field of the water, which affects the water's density, which pulls on the very light cereal.
5) The heat creates convection. At the end, the teabag becomes light enough to be a victim of the convection created by the heat.

My explanations:

1. The reason you always end up with your fingers on the center of gravity is because of friction. As experimenter moves the fingers together one of the fingers is bound to be closer to the center of gravity and hence will have more normal force acting upon it increasing the force of friction. This in turn causes the other side to slide easier, making sure the center of gravity stays in the center. This can be proven by using a stick with half of it lubed up.

2. I think the reason behind the phones flipping weird is the presence of gyroscope in the new smart phones, the gyroscope causes the rotational axis to deviate from initial path. I currently don't own an old phone without a gyroscope so I cannot test this theory :/

3. Even though the dipole is too small for the effect to be visible, the water molecules self-dissociate when introduced to electric field fluctuations caused by the realignment of of the dipoles. This creates hydrogen ions (H3O+) and hydroxide (OH-) ions which are collected on the opposite sides due to the electric field creating a much bigger dipole which is easily attracted by the already present electric field.

4. It is not the cereal that is magnetic but the water. Water is diamagnetic which means that when it is introduced to magnetic field it creates a magnetic field opposite to it, simply put water is repulsed by magnets. This effect is not very strong but strong enough to to slightly decrease the water level close to the magnet casing the cereal to fill that void.

5. I think the reason behind the lifting of the last bit of paper is its cylindrical shape. When paper burns, it expels hot "gas" which is lighter than room temperature air, but inside the cylinder the fumes are trapped since the flame is constantly expelling this "gas" leaving only the bottom of the cylinder for it to escape. This causes a concentration of the "gas" inside the cylinder which is finally released when all the paper is burnt causing it to float up with the light remnants of the paper.

3) Induced dipole moment. So you charge the cup with let's say a negative charge. The water also has charges in it but they are equal parts positive and negative so water is neutral. But lets say you bring them (the cup and water) close together. The negative charges in the cup get drawn to the positive charges in the water and the negative charges in the water repel the negative charges in the cup. The only difference is DISTANCE. Since the attraction is closer than the repulsion the  NET force will be greater between the positive water molecules and the negative cup than the negative/negative repulsion. Thus an attraction.

1) The cane is constantly losing balance - as it starts to favor one side, the opposite finger will experience less friction (because the cane is leaning the other way) and thus will slide more easily.  This goes back and forth until your fingers meet.

2) The phone is not balanced perfectly about the exact center.  All three spin directions will have flawed spins, but the last spin direction succumbs the most to the non-uniform distribution of mass.  This has nothing to do with air resistance - the phone is not spinning fast enough, nor long enough, for air to sufficiently modify the phone's motion.

3) The water coming out of the tap has a slight charge on it already.  This is the same principle as with the "Kelvin Water Dropper" (lots of youtube videos to explain it).

4) The cereal has little bits of iron in it.  Bill Nye actually showed this in one of his Science Guy videos, where he poured a bunch of cereal into water and agitated it (to break the cereal up) and then used a magnet to find the iron bits.  Floating the cereal on the water just makes it more more easily - there is likely not enough iron for the cereal to be moved on a solid surface without a significantly huge magnetic field.

5) Just a guess for this one... The mass of the teabag goes down as it burns.  Eventually the mass is low enough (when most/all has burned) to the point where the residual heat in the teabag remains is sufficient to warm the air around it and cause it all to lift up.

Let's begin...
1: the frictional forces holding the cane in contact with your fingers are dominated by the normal force exerted by the cane. As each finger slides, it constantly rebalances the weight of the can in concert with the other finger. Ergo, unless you really try to drop the cane, your fingers constantly jockey the cane until they arrive at equilibrium under its c.g.

2: the self-weight moment of inertia of the phone about the short thin edge and through the center oF the screen are very small, because the center of those spins pass very close to the overall c.g. However the moment of inertia through the long thin edge is the farthest from the cg and carries the largest moment arm, therefore the diff between the spin axis and the inertial axis results in not only a tumble but a spin.

3.nice red herring. The electrostatic field on the surface of the cup combines with the moving water to induce a very weak em field in the flowing (note: the flowing is important because that imparts additional induced energy) water as a result of the interaction of the static field and the moving water... 2. A moving fluid imparts momentum on any other fluid in contact with it. In this case, the falling water imparts movement in the air around it, and as anyone who has ever paid any attention to how a wing works will know that the higher the air velocity, the lower the air pressure. This results in a partial vacuum between the water and the cup, and as the pressure against the water on the opposite side is higher, the water is pushed towards the cup. This can be proven by placing an identical cup in a mirror position on the opposite side of the water. The water will fall straight again.

As the air is a fluid, it is impossible to flip the phone by hand perfectly straight, and mass differences within the phone, an uneven vacuum is created and the phone starts to rotate on more than one axis. The phone begins flipping unevenly (with respect to the rotated axis) when there's high air resistance due to a large affected surface area and high edge velocity, and that happens when it's flipped the long way. Rotating it via the narrow way has a much lower surface area, so there's much less air resistance and much less "unevenness". Rotating it sideways reduces edge velocity instead of the surface area, but it's still less uneven.

1. The total force between the fingers and the cane equals the weight of the cane, but the weight on each individual finger depends on its distance from the center of mass. This is most easily seen by analyzing the rotation, or lack thereof, of the cane. Since it isn't rotating, the net torque is zero. Since torque equals r cross F, the further one finger is from the center of mass, the smaller the fraction of the weight that finger will have to hold. Since the force between the finger and cane is smaller, the friction is as well, and the finger further from the center of mass slides more easily.

2. The "phone flip" phenomenon arises because of how moments of inertia operate. It turns out that an objects total moment of inertia can be represented with an ellipsoid. The ellipsoid for the phone would have 3 axis of different lengths. "Inflating" a sphere from within and marking lines of intersection at a given sphere radius, we can map various rotation paths. If you do this, you'll notice that you'll get circles around two of the axes of the ellipsoid. On the third, however, you won't. The lines will "run away" from this axis. This shows that you can have stable rotations around two of the axes, but not that third one.

3. Got me there. I always took the polarized water answer for granted. I can't think of a viable explanation that doesn't run into the same issue. Guess I'll find out next week!

4. Cereal has iron in it. Iron is ferromagnetic.

5. The upward travelling air (from convection, caused by the heat) pulls upward on the tea bag. Eventually, enough of the material is consumed, and the remaining portion of the bag is light enough to be lifted by this air current.

Let's get this over with...
#1 is quite easy to explain:
A short look at the angular momentum gives the answer. The finger closer to the center of mass has a slightly higher angular momentum resulting in a slightly higher friction which makes it 'harder' to move. This repeats until both fingers experience the same angular momentum (approx. zero) - In other words: you reached the center of mass.
#2 is a bit harder:
First you need to know, that there is a thing called 'moment of inertia' or 'angular mass', which can be understood as an analogy for mass in rotation. The second thing...you need to accept that in physics things tend to assume extremal values which are stable or 'metastable'. This happens when you rotate along the shortest or longest axis (which seems to be obvious) but as you rotate along the 'middle axis' the whole system becomes unstable resulting in a strange rotation (which you can in theory calculate....but it's rather annoying). Maybe there is an easier way to explain it...
I am not quite sure about #3 but it should work like this:
Let's assume that the cup's charge is negative.
As we learned in school our model for electrostatics says that all charge somehow 'gathers' at the surface (the explaination involves more talking about extremal values).
So it should look like this:
C(n)   A (p)>>>>>>>>>>(n)
U(n)   I   (p)>>WATER>>(n)
P(n)   R (p)>>>>>>>>>>(n)
We know think of the Coulomb force which goes with 1 over r squared (r is the distance between the charges). We see that the attracting force (lower r) is a tiny bit larger than the repelling (higher r). With the cohesion within the water in mind, the water slightly moves towards the cup.
An other possibility: The water moving could cause a more stable state. In other words: an extremal value of the electrostatic energy.
As I said before this could be wrong. I really don't like classical electrostatics.
#4 appears to be an easy one again:
Cereal contains a small percentage of iron. Iron is ferromagnetic. Applying a 'strong' magnetic field forces the magnetic dipoles (N---S) to align according to the applyed magnetic field resulting in a slightly magnetic cereal.
let's keep #5 simple and maybe not entirely correct:
As you ignite the teabag the surrounding air gets warm and thus less dense resulting in a upwards movement of the warm air. The teabag itself gets lighter while burning down. At some point the teabag is light enough so the force applyed by the upmoving air can counter the effects of gravity and lifts the teabag up into the air....into space....and far beyond.

1) It's just friction. If you are closer to the center of mass, you get more friction between the finger and the stick, than on the other finger. This can either make the less frictional finger slide more easily or can even carry the stick on the more frictional finger.
2) Just a guess on air resistance. In the first case, you have a great radian, in the second one you have a great cross sectional area, but in the third case you have them both, so they probably even multiply.
3) This is about electrostatic induction. By rubbing the plastic cup on your hair, you're removing some of the cup's atom's electrons. This generates a positive electric field around the cup, which is trying to pull (negative) electrons towards it. This causes the former neutral water to become a dipole, which means, that the electrons within the water get pulled towards the cup's side. So there is one half of the water stream, that has more electrons than normal (negative pole) and another half is missing them (positive pole). Then the water bends, because the negative pole is more attracted by the positive charge in the cup, than how positive pole is repulsed by it
4) Just easy magnetism. The cereal contains iron (it is considered as being healthy, like you need minerals and stuff), which can be magnetized, by a permanent magnet. This is the case: you get close to it with a perm. magnet, the iron gets magnetized, now there are simply two magnet attracting each other.
5) Also kind of friction. When the teabag is burning, it generates heat. The heated up air becomes lighter and ascends. Fresh air flows repetitive from the sides towards the teabag and ascends, as it also gets heated up. During that process, the air column drags on the paper, which also ascends, when it's light enough (almost burnt down).

Most of the other questions have been sufficiently answered, but #4, why water bends hasn't been well addressed yet I don't think.

The moving water dipole moments create an electric field, and that creates a moving magnetic field.  And charged particles experience a force when in a moving magnetic field.  In this case, you're holding the charged cup stationary, and the force is acting equally between the water and the cup, so the water moves.

The movement of the water is the key to the trick, if the water doesn't move, then the magnetic field doesn't move, and if the magnetic field doesn't move in relation to the charged particles then there's no force.

Try it, charge up a cup, and then hold it next to a few drops of water on an insulated plate.  Nothing will happen.

Although an equal amount of positive and negative ions are in the water (and thereby, the net force would be zero), the force of the electric field is strongest close to the cup, causing the stream to deflect: the ions attracted by the cup are pulled stronger towards the cup than the opposite ions are pushed away from it, since the attracted ions are closer to the cup.

1) Finding the center of mass of a cane:  As you slide your fingers toward the center, the normal force of contact between the cane and the finger closest to the center of mass is greater than force of contact between the cane and the other finger.  This results in greater friction on the finger closest to the center of mass, allowing the other finger to move faster...until it is the closer one.

2) Unstable phone rotation:  This is true of any rigid body rotating around it's intermediate principal axis.  (the middle of it's 3 principal moments of inertia), although I do not have a very intuitive way of explaining this phenomenon.

The other finger will now be able to move, because most of the force is one the other finger. This happens until the stick moves its force from the one finger to the other, which is the case if it gets closer to the center of mass than the other. The other finger will now again move towards the center. This whole process repeats until both fingers are at the center of mass.

Also the smaller area of side makes it easier to "concentrate" the force. A larger area wouldn't have equal force applied to everywhere.

3. Polarisation: By rubbing the cup, it gains extra electrons, which can't disperse through the cup, as the plastic it's made from isolates. Holding the cup against the water stream forces the electrons in the water to move away from the cup thus creating a positve side and a negative side of the water stream. As the positve side is closer, the electrons in the cup attract it stronger than they repel the negative side meaning the water stream moves towards the cup.

4. Same principle as in 3: The magnet polarises the water soaked in by the cereal which makes it float towards it.

5. Bernoli's Principle (I think): By lighting the tea bag on fire, it cause the air around it to heat up. As hot air rises, new air has to replace it's spot, causing a light air stream. When the tea bag is nearly burned up. it's light enough to be moved up by the air streaming towards where the hot air was.

OK - my explanation for the for the experiment with the stick and fingers. Let's denote the equilibrium point "E". The task is to find "E" by perturbation in a particular search space. What is the search space? The search space is the set of all configurations of the stick with each of the two fingers placed at a different point along the length of the stick (you can think of a point in the space as a tuple (p1, p2), p1, p2 are lengths). Now - balancing the stick at a particular point p is equivalent to choosing sample point (p, p) in the search space. This sample point may or may not be an equilibrium point. It is overwhelmingly likely NOT to be an equilibrium point as there is only one true equilibrium point (by basic physics) and this true equilibrium point is surrounded by an uncountable infinity of non-equilibrium points. HOWEVER, the true equilibrium point may be found by applying the physical equivalent of the "PINCHING THEOREM" of calculus - by find upper and lower bounds, and progressively modifying these to find the GREATEST LOWER BOUND and LEAST UPPER BOUND. As we progressively change the bounds, the error (distance p1-p2) comes down, and by calculus (if you work through it), you can always, given a particular maximum error desired, find a FINITE NUMBER OF STEPS (number of iterations) after which the error will drop below the given value. Voila :)

-The crane acts with the laws of dynamic: it accelerates towards the Earth at 1g. Being a long and narrow object, it basically stands on two points, being the fingers. I think we have friction to thank: when a "2 dimensional" object like a crane, which is long and narrow, stays on top of two fingers, its ends create two levers with the finger as fulcrum. As you move your fingers towards the center, the two sides change point of force, thus changing how they weight on the fingers, and pushing more on them, thus increasing their friction with the skin, so the finger on which it's heavier, makes it slide on top of the other, quickly balancing itself under the exact baricenter of the crane.

First one: The vertical force on each finger due to the weight of the cane is dependent on its distance to the center of mass of the cane. The finger furtest from the center of mass will have the lowest vertical force, and in the case that one finger is beneath the center of mass, the other will have no vertical force. 
The maximum friction force that resists sliding underneath the cane is proportional to this sliding force. The finger with the lowest resisting friction force will be the first to slide while the other sticks, and hence the finger furthest away from the center of mass will be the one that is sliding. Since it is always the one that is furtest from the center of mass, the fingers will meet under the center of mass.

Second one: This has to do with principal axes. The rotation of a rigid body is stable when you rotate it around its axis with the lowest or with the highest moment of inertia. It is unstable about the intermediate one, which in this case seems to be the end-over-end one.

Third one: By rubbing the cup, you are taking of some electrons making it positvely charged. This positively charged cup will attract electrons in the water a bit to the cup, and push away the positively charged nuclei a bit. Overall, this causes the water stream to be a bit negative on the cup-side, and a bit positive on the other side. Because the attraction force scales with the inverse of the square of the distance, and the negative side is closer, the water stream is attracted to the cup.

Fourth one: I think it is the iron in the cereal that is attracted to the magnet. It is only a small force, but since the cereal is resting on water, it only needs a small force to move towards the magnet.

Fifth one: the air inside the tea bag is heated by the flame and hence becomes lighter then the surrounding air, causing it to rise. When the bag is completely burned, the residu only weight a tiny bit. The convection current caused by the rising air is now enough to lift the remaining ashes.

My thoughts:

1) The first one seems simple, unless the simple explanation is misleading.  As you move your fingers together, the balance of the rod changes, tipping more around the finger that is closer to the center of mass, and thus reducing the friction acting on the finger that is further away, allowing it to slide in toward the CM.  The fingers alternate back and forth until you reach the CM.

2) The phone exhibits a sensitive dependence on initial conditions when spun along the long axis.  It is unstable.  Any tiny differences in the initial throw, or in the air currents around the phone as it spins, will "blow up" into large differences.  The interesting question is why this doesn't happen when spinning the phone along the other axes.  My guess is that when spinning along these axes, there are other forces involved that keep the phone steadily spinning on one axis OR the forces that cause the instability in the long-axis case are minimized.  Not sure which is the case.  I'll comment with further details if a particular explanation becomes clear.

3) A friend is running some tests for me involving magnets and ethanol.  This one is tricky, I'm not entirely sure what it is (although I'm starting to think it has everything to do with the shape of the water molecules combined with the orientation).  We've found out two interesting facts: (a) the trick does not work if you use a magnet in place of the charged object (another experiment will be run with a stronger magnet), and (b) the trick does not work if you substitute 75% ethanol for the water.  If anyone has any thoughts on this, please share.

4) This also seems simple, again unless the easy explanation is misleading.  Most breakfast cereal is fortified with iron, which is (of course) ferromagnetic.  On a table or other solid surface, the friction resists the cereal moving, but in water the resistive forces are far less, allowing the iron-fortified cereal to be pulled toward the magnet.

5) I imagine the heat from the fire creates a column of rising hot air.  When the fire burns down to the plate, this flow probably becomes turbulent, sweeping the (very light) remains of the tea bag up into the column, which lifts it up into the air.

Also, for all you would-be explainers: #2 works for perfectly symmetric objects in a vacuum.

1st problem: The bigger part of the cane's weight always rests on the finger thats closer to the center of mass, thus frinction is stronger there. So the finger with less weight on it, i.e. less friction slides easier and gets closer to the center of mass. This goes back and forth until both fingers are together.
2nd problem: A free object can only have a stable rotation along the axis where it has the most or the least amount of moment of inertia. The phone has three different moments of inertia along its three axes (2 axes along the plane of the display, one perpendicular to those). If you try to spin the phone around the axis with the "middle" moment of inertia, the rotation is unstable and will increasingly change to one of the other axes due to tiny disturbances like air resistance. If you did a perfect throw in vacuum where absolutely no other forces act on the phone, the rotation might just be stable a while longer.

For the 2nd phenomena, we actually did a simulation of it. From what I can remember in that class, rigid bodies have 3 principal axes of rotation. As for a solid rectangular prism like his phone, the axes run parallel with the length(longest), height/thickness(shortest) and width(intermediate) of the phone each going through the center of mass. The system tends to have stable rotation on the longest and shortest axis because they represent the maximum and minimum moments of inertia, respectively. Having the maximum or minimum inertia means that any slight perturbation or disturbance of the system will have very little to no effect to the rotation. However, a rotational inertia intermediate of that of max and min means that a slight perturbation will either shift it towards either of the two extreme states, thereby causing the instability or wobbleness of the system. iirc

1. Cane - Friction
    As two fingers move inward, one end of the cane will become longer than the other end, which exerts a larger downward force on one of the fingers, increasing the friction.
        Friction: (11) -----------|------------------------------|---------- Friction: (10)
    As a result, the finger with less friction will move inward faster, which increases the length of cane on its side, which also increase downward force and friction.
    This process will rinse and repeat until the two fingers meet.

2. IPhone Flip - Center of Mass (CoM)
    The CoM of the phone is not the geometric center of the phone.
    When the phone is flipping on its side, because of how thin the phone is, all of the mass lies on one plane. So it is unlikely to wobble.
    When the phone is spinning around the long axis, a lot of its mass is distributed near the axis, so it is also unlike to wobble even if the CoM is not on the axis.
    When the phone is spinning around the short axis, however, more of its mass is away from the axis, and the asymmetrical CoM distribution causes it to wobble a lot.

3. Bending Water Stream - Electrons & tetrahedrons
    The Static Electricity on the cup (Negative) repels away electrons (Negative) making the stream near the cup positively charged. (Because the water stream is moving so fast, we can IMAGINE it as a liquid metal, where electrons can travel freely within the water. )
    And since H2O is a dipole molecule, it tends to travel in a tetrahedral shaped GROUP, making bending water even easier.

4. Cereal - Iron
     Cereal has iron molecules in it, check the ingredients list. (Should do that anyways, avoid sugar & high cal for healthy living :D)

5. Teabag - Convection
     As most of the mass transfers into heat, and heated air exerts an upward force on the main fuel source, what is leftover gets pulled up with the heated air.

1. The closer the centre of mass is to one of your fingers, the greater the force of the cane's weight on that finger (specifically, if the two fingers are equally far away from the centre of mass, the force of weight on each finger will be the same). Less force means less friction, so the finger farther away from the centre of mass slides in faster than the other one. This continues until eventually the two fingers meet underneath the centre of mass.

2. I'm at a loss. I presume it has something to do with aerodynamics, though. A way to test this would be to try to flip the phone in vacuum. Not very feasible, unfortunately.

3. Yes, we would be hard-pressed to attract a single water molecule towards an electrically charged object. However, a stream of water is not a single molecule of water. The electrical charge does "only flip" some of the molecules in the stream, however, this increase in the amount of molecules that are flipped in a certain direction (as opposed to having equal probability of being flipped in any direction) in the stream causes the stream of water itself to become slightly magnetic. This then causes the stream to be attracted to the electrically charged object.

4. The same as 3, with an important additional note - the water absorbed by the cereal is brought above the external water level by the capillary action of the cereal. This causes the water inside the cereal to be closer to the magnet than the water around it, which means the force the magnet exerts on the water inside the cereal is greater than the force it exerts on the water outside the cereal, which is why the cereal moves. A very easy way to test this hypothesis is to try to drag the cereal around while holding the magnet under the water.

5. Again at a bit of a loss. However, this doesn't seem much different than pieces of burning wood floating off as the wood burns. The reason it doesn't take off immediately is obviously because it's weighed down by its non-burning bottom part.

Here are my initial reactions:

1. Whichever finger holds up the larger proportion of the cane has a larger force pushing down on it, and therefore has a larger friction force. The result is that whichever finger is furthest from the centre of mass will always do the moving, and so your fingers will tend towards the centre of mass.
2. When you spin the phone in this orientation, it has the largest cross-sectional area, and so aerodynamic forces are larger than for the other orientations. This means the aerodynamic instability of the phone's shape and movement are much more pronounced.
3. [very uncertain] The displaced charge on the cup sets up a small magnetic field. Water is a conductor, and as the water moves past the cup the magnetic field changes in its frame of reference. A changing magnetic field induces a current, but not perfectly (I realise this is vague; I'm greatly conjecturing), so the water experiences a force to satisfy conservation of energy.
4. A lot of breakfast cereals contain added iron to make them sound more nutritious. When the friction is reduced by floating a piece of cereal in water, the magnetic attraction of the tiny amount of iron can move the cereal.
5. The flame heats the air near it, reducing its density and creating a convection current. When the mass of the teabag is sufficiently reduced by burning, it is carried into the air by the current.

1) Friction force (x-direc)= coefficient of friction X normal force (y-direc): A relatively simple statics problem, the downward force of the cane has to be balanced by the upward force of the fingers. If the fingers are not equidistant from the center of mass, the closer finger experiences a larger normal force (can be solved using sum of moments equation) which in turn increases the friction force for that finger. The increased friction force means that it will be harder to move said finger relative the the other finger. 

2) My best guess is an imbalance in forces that cause a perturbation in the unwanted direction. This small perturbation in the initial condition is most likely because of the large upward force acting on a relatively small moment arm (half the length of the amount of finger in contact with the phone).

3) No clue. However, there is a branch of micro-fluid dynamics that deals with a concept known as electrowetting to move droplets of water using nothing but an electrocal potential difference.

4) The iron content in the cereal?

5) The rocket action is actually thanks to entrainment of air. Basically, the bouyant plume caused by the combustion of the teabag creates an imbalance in working fluid (air in this case). As the hot, bouyant plume moves upward, cold air must replenish at the sides and at the bottom. The force caused by the movement of air is relatively small and only manifests itself on the ashes, which can be as low as 1% of the original mass (known as the char fraction).

When you're moving your fingers along the cane, the finger with the least friction will move first. Each finger supports all of the weight of the cane from its contact point to the nearest end, and a portion of the weight between the fingers (half?). By moving a finger inward, you increase the amount of weight it bears. Friction is proportional to applied force, which is that weight, so the innermost finger won't move. (The friction force drops it below its static friction threshold, so it stops moving; if your fingers were wet or oiled or something, both fingers would move, but they would move proportionally to their distance from the center, so the end result would be the same.)

could aerodynamics play a part in the phone flip?

#1) This actually has a two part answer. First, it's a result of gravity and friction. As you begin moving your fingers inward towards each other, the side that holds less weight allows your fingers to more inwards at an easier pace. Second, because it's easier, it makes you, psychologically, move that finger further in response. Because our hands/arms like to make the same motion, at the same time, at the same rate, the psychological response with the force of gravity and friction makes you generally move straight into the equilibrium point of the object. #2  This is a matter of conservation of angular momentum...combined with a bit of air-resistance.   Challenging to explain without a page of math!  Involves things that you kinda need a gut feel for if you don't want to use a page of math.

In the rotation in the plane of the screen - air resistance is actually stabilizing the rotation.

Aerodynamic drag gets a LOT bigger the faster you're moving - from memory, the drag force is proportional to the cube of the speed.  Even a tiny difference in speed results in a HUGE difference in drag.  In the end-over-end flip, there is a lot more drag than in the side-over-side flip because for any given rotation rate (degrees per second) the ends of the phone are moving faster than in the side-over side flip...and the amount of drag it incurs is much higher.   Worse still, in end-over-end, the difference in drag between different parts of the phone is much higher.  That should stabilize the phone - but conservation of angular momentum means that the spin that you're reducing because of asymmetrical drag has to go somewhere - and that causes the increasing rotation about the other axis.

In the side-over-side case, it's the opposite, if either side of the phone tries to go faster, then it incurs more drag and slows back down again but because the moment of inertia is higher....

#1  If your fingers are not equidistant from the center of mass, there will be more weight (downward force) on the finger that's closest to the center than on the one that's furthest away.  Because the force of friction is greater where there is more force, the finger that has the least weight on it has the least friction. So as you move your fingers together, the one that's furthest away from the center of mass slides more easily...and therefore more quickly.   If the finger that's further away moves faster, then it'll eventually end up at the same distance from the center of mass as the finger that started off closest.   When they're at the same distance from the center, they slide equally easily and at the same speed - so they end up together at the center of mass.

Even better, if there is some unevenness in the cane that momentarily slows one finger down even the tiniest bit, then this effect adds weight to the other finger until the frictional forces are equal...so everything stays beautifully symmetrical no matter what.

This effect is called "feedback" and it's always cool when it just shows up in nature.

Phone flip conjecture:
a. Once released, the phone must rotate around an axis that passes through its center of mass (in x,y,z space).
b. The center of mass of the phone is not necessarily co-located with the physical center of the phone. (Confirmed by balancing my iPhone on a small eraser head: there is a slight offset from the center of the rectangular volume occupied by the phone.)
c. As a result, the portion of the phone to one side of the axis has a different surface area (normal to the direction of rotation) than its opposite side. [This must be considered in 3-space.]
d. (b) implies that air friction will operate slightly differently on the two halves.

Nomenclature:
   Designate the x-axis as one across the width of the phone, when viewed in its normal operating orientation. "Width" is the neither the longest nor shortest dimension of the phone.
   y-axis runs along the longest dimension of the phone.
   z-axis runs along the thickness of the phone.
   The last flip shown in the video is an attempt to flip the phone so it rotates around the x-axis.

Conjecture:
   Over time, the differential in air friction gradually shifts the rotation axis of the phone until an axis is reached in which the projected surface area NORMAL to the direction of rotation is equal on both sides of the axis of rotation.
   We see this shift occur more quickly with an x-axis rotation because the differential between the two halves of the phone on either side of the axis of rotation is centered at greater distances from the axis of rotation. The differential operates on a longer lever arm and thus can shift the axis of rotation more quickly.

Tests:
   1. Flip the phone in a vacuum. If the conjecture is correct, there will be no change in any initial axis of rotation. One can flip the phone from a corner, side, etc and the rotation axis will not shift.
   2. Flip the phone in air, but at significant height (off of a bridge or tall building). If the conjecture is correct, regardless of the orientation of the initial rotation (x-, y-, z- axis or any combination; e.g., by flipping from a corner), a gradual shift toward a specific preferred axis of rotation will occur... until the phone destroys itself at the end of the fall.
   3. Substitute any slab of material to replace the phone. Retest by embedding weight so that the center of mass is offset from the center of the slab. If the conjecture is correct, the behavior of the phone can be replicated... and altered by locating the center of mass differently. One can exaggerate the dimensions of the slab to amplify the conjectured effect of air friction.

Explanation for the Cane Phenomenon : 

The Friction b/n the cane and a finger is proportional to the contact force b/n them. These contact forces (N1) and (N2) satisfy :

(N1)(R1) = (N2)(R2) ;  [because the cane is not rotating net moment on the cane is zero]. here the R's are the distance of the respective fingers from the center of mass.

When you start moving your fingers, the finger farther from the center of mass starts to move first.[because larger R => smaller N => smaller friction].

It moves until the both the R's become equal. Then both R's are equal => both N's are equal => Frictions for both fingers are equal. So, they both move together until both R's approach zero(they reach the Center of Mass).

I have also observed that if the surface of the cane is rough, then it's a bit different. The first finger moves until both the R's are equal and then it moves small amount of extra distance(very little). Now it has lower R => higher N => higher friction so it stops. The other finger starts to move, both R's become equal again and it moves by by a small extra distance. This is goes on and on. It's essentially same as that of a smooth cane but the process is more discontinuous so that the two fingers never actually are moving simultaneously.

By looking at this math, the only way you can avoid ending up at the center of mass is to pick the starting positions of your fingers such that they both lie on the same side of the center of mass. but then the stick would fall down and you can't do it. But if you don't want the stick to fall down you have to try this in space(without gravity), Where you can make your fingers meet wherever you want... not just at the center of mass. But It would be kinda pointless though.

CANE TRICK: clockwise torque is equal to ccw torque. Also, since your hand + the cane are not accelerating up/down, the force exerted upwards by your hand on the cane is equal to the force exerted on your hand by the cane. NOW: Fd = Fd, so when your left hand is closer to the centre of mass, distance is smaller, so force exerted on the cane must be larger. This is also the normal force, which gives rise to friction. And as your right hand moves close enough to the centre of mass for it to have a larger frictional force, your left hand will start moving closer and closer, and they'll trade over and over until they meet in the middle. This is interesting, because this means that if you try it with two different objects such as a piece of wood and a piece of rubber, since the coefficients of friction are not equal, they will meet elsewhere.

1) Consider Derek and the stick as the system. There are three things in the system whose motion is to be described, they are, the left and the right hands and the stick. The initial momentum of the system of elements is zero. Everything is at rest initially. Since no external forces act on the system, momentum is conserved. This implies, the final momentum of the system of elements is zero. At the final configuration, the momentum of the left and the right hands is zero because they stop at the point where they meet. This leaves us with the stick, whose momentum has to be zero. The stick may possess both translational momentum and rotational momentum. Since the two momenta cannot be added( due to the absence of dimensional homogeneity ), both should equal to zero. Coming to rotational momentum or angular momentum, which is zero, there is no flipping or rotational motion. Since it continues to stay in that configuration( constant angular velocity that is equal to zero ), we say that the net torque about the pivot( Derek's fingers ) is zero. By definition, the net torque about the center of mass of an isolated element is always zero and in this case, the system as mentioned above is isolated. This implies that the center of mass of the stick rests on Derek's fingers.

3) The electric field created by the charged insulating cup is not uniform. To be clear, take a cylindrical cup( almost identical to the one in the video ) with its bottom surface missing and let it have a uniform surface charge density. On calculating the electric field intensity at any point in space( using Gauss's law for this special symmetric situation ), one will observe that the electric field intensity follows an inverse 'r' relationship where 'r' is the distance from the central axis of the cylinder. As a consequence, the net force on the water molecule will not be zero. The net force on the molecule causes it to deflect from its initial flow direction. There is another possibility. Also, tap water may contain salts. Now, some salts dissolve in water, they dissociate into ions( cations and anions ). In the presence of an external electric field, the ions rearrange themselves and since the field is non-uniform, the system( water + ions ) as a whole experiences a net non-zero force thereby, causing deflections.

4) Cereals are rich in Iron. Since Iron shows magnetic properties, the cereal grain is pulled toward the magnet under special conditions. The attractive magnetic force acting on the cereal grain is more than the friction force offered by the surface of the water. This is why the cereal experiences a net force toward the magnet and so it moves toward the magnet.

5) We know that on heating an object, its density decreases. When the density of the material making up the tea bag falls below the density of air, the tea bag rises.
