the cane one:

When you move you fingers along the cane towards its centre of mass, there is a friction force between you fingers and the cane. That friction force is proportional to the reaction force of your fingers on the cane, which in turn is proportional to the distance from the centre of mass of the cane. The closer to the centre of mass - the greater is the reaction force and hence the friction. There are two pivots (your fingers) in the system and the closer any one of them gets to the centre of mass - the greater is the friction it's experiencing and the opposite happens to the other pivot, while keeping the "total friction" constant. Simply put - the system balances out itself, keeping both pivots at equal distance from the centre of mass. Works even if you only move one of your fingers towards the other, while keeping the second one stationary, because at some point the friction the moving finger is experiencing will overcome the friction the stationary finger is experiencing and moving finger will just shift the cane on the stationary finger.

You cannot rotate the phone end over end because the axis along which it rotates is not the principal axis of the phone. In rotational motion, the concept of principal axis is very important and is related to the inertia tensor of the object. Thus, according to this principle, one can find three mutually perpendicular axes along which the phone can rotate freely. When the phone is flipped end over end, it doesn't rotate about its principal axis, thus it wobbles and tries to rotate around one of its principal axis.

I disagree with everyone's answer for number one--I don't think it's a psychological thing at all. In fact, I can't make myself not find the center of a long object like that even when willingly fighting it (given that I don't cheat and push it off my hand). I think it has more to do with the fact that the friction between two surfaces increases as the normal force between those surfaces increases. And when you move your fingers toward each other, it's basically the friction from each finger duking it out to see who is currently pushing the cane.

You can think of the cane as two levers stuck together, with the center of mass as the applied force and your fingers as the respective fulcrums. In a lever, the force on the load (the push on your finger) depends on the ratio of how far the force is from the fulcrum to how far away the load is. So as you scoot finger 1 closer to the center of mass, you're moving the fulcrum of the lever pushing on finger 2 closer to finger 2, so the force on it increases. And as the force goes up, the friction goes up, and eventually finger 2 is sticking to the cane more strongly than finger 1, and the process starts again in reverse. This process obviously balances right at the center of mass where the force on each finger can be equal, but neither finger can continue approaching the other.

The cane trick is due to the cane changing pressures on each finger. If say the left was closer to the center of mass, then it would have a larger pressure from the center of mass. Think if you had a German Shepherd on one end of a board and the other end of the board you had a pug as a more extreme example. This would cause that finger to experience greater frictional force, slowing down or even bringing it to a stop. Meanwhile the other finger is moving closer, also increasing the apparent downward force of the cane. These two forces cancel each other out, so it will form a a smooth transition of apparent velocity and acceleration.

The cane thing is easy - you can do it so that your fingers will not end up under the center of mass of the cane, but if you do this, the cane will fall off. The trick is that both of your fingers apply a torque on the cane, and these must cancel out, so at all times, if the cane is to stay on your fingers, they must be on each side of the center of mass - otherwise, the torques don't cancel out. So you have two fingers moving towards each other, and you know that there is this point which they cannot cross. So they'll meet there... If your friend holds the cane, the "letting go" can induce a slight torque that will set it off even if you do get it right under the C.M.

The phone flip thing is more complicated - so the moment of inertia of your phone measures the "resistance" of your phone to angular acceleration around an axis. On the phone, there are three main axes of rotation : one that goes through the screen, one that goes through the charging plug, all across the screen up to the power button at the top, and one that crosses the screen from left to right. The latter is the problematic one, and the reason why it is so problematic is that the moment of intertia of the phone with respect to this axis is significantly larger than that of the other two axes of rotation. This means that when you swing your phone, any torque around the other axes will be much more apparent. This has nothing to do with the varying density of the phone, either - this works with random pieces of wood cut to the right proportions...

I would have to guess that for the cane trick, the force of friction between the two fingers and the cane is different depending on where you place your fingers initially. Placing one finger closer to the centre of mass will cause a greater force being exerted on that finger, and in turn, a greater normal force will be applied to the cane. (greater normal force = greater force of friction). As your fingers slide, the finger with less friction force will move faster and/or more easily compared to the finger with higher friction. 1 - Levers Two major forces at play: Friction and Gravity The cane is supported by two potential fulcrums. One (Fw) supports the majority of the weight while the other (Ft) simply keeps the cane from toppling. As you bring the two supports together, frictional force increases on Ft AND decreases on Fw until their roles are reversed. The center of gravity stays between the two potential fulcrums regardless of how close together or far apart they are.
2 - Angular Momentum. The phone flips for the same reason a rolling wheel stays upright and helicopters can only go so fast. Centrifugal Force on a spinning object translates 90 degrees clockwise off-axis - the wheel is being lifted and the helicopter tilts backwards. Watch Dustin from Smarter Every Day's video series on helicopters or Veritasiums video on the hanging wheel if you're still confused. They're better practiced when it comes to explaining science.
3 - Elecrto-magnetism Running water produces an electric charge (you can check for yourself at any faucet if you have a voltage meter). By charging the cup with static electricity, you're creating a magnetic force between the two.

4 - Now with 13 essential vitamins and minerals!! Yep, there's metal in your Frankenberry. Thanks, FDA.

5 - Friction and Fluid Dynamics As the paper tube burns, it creates an updraft (somewhat because hot air rises, but mostly because it's expanding and has to go somewhere and the easiest direction is up). Gravity holds the tube down until its mass is low enough that the friction from the updraft is stronger than the force of gravity.

For the cane one, I would assume it's a combination of the following:

1) Each finger is applying one vertical point force on the cane, in addition to the weight of the cane (focused at the center of mass).

To keep it from rotating the moments at any point have to cancel out, so if we take the moments at the center of mass (negating the effect of weight) then it simply means that the finger closer to the CoM has to apply a greater upward force (due to FxD = M) in order to cancel the moment of the further one.

Therefore the FURTHER finger has less force, and therefore less friction acting upon it, making it easier for it to slide instead of the closer finger. It's likely that the closer finger will stick rather than slide as easily.

So the further finger will slide until it's about as close as the other finger, at which point they will both start to converge on the CoM.

2) Your instincts make you help balance it at least a little. (which would probably be hard to avoid as a human)

The cane works because:
Whichever finger is closer to the center of gravity will carry more of the cane's weight, and since it's carrying more weight, the cane is resting on that finger with more force than on the other. This increased pressure also increases the friction between that finger and the cane, allowing the other finger (where the friction is lower) to slide inward.
In other words, whichever finger is furthest from the center of gravity slides inward more easily, until they both meet at the center.

For the cane example.

1.) The ability to slide your hands down the cane is due to them achieving the inertia required to overcome friction. Your hands don't slide if they don't overcome friction.

 2.)As your hands move, they essentially form pivots for the cane to try and rotate around. The downward force exerted by the cane rotating over the pivot is altered depending on how close the pivot point is to the center of gravity. If the left hand pivot is farther, the right hand will experience a larger downward force.

3.) This increases the normal force acting on the right finger, making it harder for that finger to overcome friction. If both hands were applying the same magnitude of force in their respective directions, that increase in friction would at one point be too high for one finger to slide, so the other moves while the other remains stationary.

4.) As the left finger moves it creates new pivots closer to the center of gravity, reducing the downward force on the opposite finger. Eventually it will reach a point where the normal force acting on the right finger is low enough for that finger to once again to overcome friction and once again move toward the center. 

5.) This process will continue in smaller and smaller increments back and forth until both fingers rest under the center of gravity.

Most people realize that the first one is a result of friction and the fact that the finger closer to the center of gravity will have a greater frictional force and thus move slower, but I didn't really see any satisfying explanations of why the two fingers must meet at the center every time, even when begun asymmetrically. So here goes my attempt...

This can be explained one way by thinking of the limits of the problem. Each finger must carry a percentage of the weight (and thus feel a percentage of the downward force) of the cane. If a finger is dead center, it has 100% of the weight (force), and the other finger feels 0%. Zero downward force means zero sideways frictional force, so it would move unresisted. As the closer finger approaches the center, the amount of weight on the outer finger approaches 0, so it moves faster than the inner finger until they are symmetrically far from the center of gravity. If there is no other frictional force on the cane, it can't move with respect to the inner finger.

Applying these same physical rules, it's also fairly obvious that the inner finger could never move past the center of gravity, so they have to meet in the middle.

I got four. The first one is for the cane, as the fingers move closer towards the center of gravity, the length and mass on the exterior of the fingers are unequal. Not that gravity changes dependent on the object, but because one side is lopsided the finger has more "push" against the cane. And through multiple succession of this happening to both sides, the fingers end up at the center of gravity where friction is the highest force both fingers to meet up there.
The second one is for the phone. If you spin it like a ninja star the center of gravity is straight in the middle of the rectangle. The phone is free to spin around the center of gravity as if it is an axis. Throw it like a chocolate bar, the center of gravity is still in the middle, but the spin is not optimal. There is a greater amount of air friction when thrown in that style, than when like a ninja star. So the "phone", (more like the system, but I'm not sure if that word applies) wants to right itself into the ninja star orientation in order to get the least air resistance, so the phone wobbles. The path of least resistance does not only apply to water.
The third one is for the cereal. Cereal has iron in it. I don't think I need to explain much more.
The last on is for the tea bag. Heated air has a greater pressure than, for a lack of a better word, non-heated air. So as the flame travels the length of the tube, the insides and outsides of the tube has an increase of pressure until it finally burns through, at which point the pressure around the tube and inside the tube are no longer changing so the air all around wants to fix the differences in pressure rushing in to the space which the tube occupies. The result, the tea bag flies as a small wind is created uplifting the ashes.

The cane:
The torque on the cane about the finger closer to the CoM is smaller than about the finger that's further. ( T = r x F ) This means that the force acting down on the further finger is smaller. The maximum force that static friction can create is directly proportional to the force that pushes two surfaces together (normal force N).
( F_s = µ_s * N ) Since the finger further from the CoM is subjected to a smaller normal force than the closer finger, it can't create as large a frictional force on the cane to cancel out the other finger's; the further finger begins to slide and continues to slide until it becomes the closer finger. Soon after, it stops and the other finger starts sliding.
This explanation leaves a little bit out. (like kinetic friction, why the second statement is true, and the time it takes to accelerate the cane) It'd just take too long to explain.

1. As you move your fingers inward, the way the cane moves provides information to your subconscious mind, which automatically constantly adjusts the relative speeds of each of your hands to keep the cane balanced (Fairly confident).

The phone thing is due to Coreolis acceleration. As said by another answer, phones have accelerometers, which vibrate (small rotations) but I believe this is due to the hard drive, which has a higher mass, and then generates a more noticeable effect.

Coreolis works like this: If one object rotates in two perpendicular axes at the time, then it will be forced to rotate in a third axis. An easy example is a car in a curve. As the engine usually rotates around the left-right axis, and the whole car while taking a curve rotates around the up-down axis, then the car will tend to rotate around the front-back axis, generating the rollover force we are all familiar with. Watch this taken to eleven in racing cars or in movies.

In the phone this means that the rotation of the accelerometers (or the hard drive) happens in a perpendicular axis to the one you are rotating the phone, therefore the phone rotates in a third axis. Let's see this teory: The hard drive rotates around the front-back axis, and you are rotating it around the left-right axis. Therefore Coreolis would generate a rotation around the up-down axis. Exactly what we saw on the video.

Walking stick: as you move your fingers down the stick the stick exerts friction on your fingers. One end will usually have more "over the edge" of your finger and due to leverage will exert more friction on that finger which subtly lowers it's speed. At the same time the other finger will then be moving relatively faster than the "more friction" finger, resulting in this finger now having more of the walking stick "over the edge" and begin to move slower until the whole cycle repeats. Ultimately the very minor variations in speed, caused by shifting distribution of weight, friction and leverage result in both fingers reaching the centre of mass simultaneously where all the forces are balanced.

For the cane & center of mass, imaging an extreme example will help. Pick up a sledgehammer with one finger right next to the heavy head and the other finger way out on the end of the handle. As you (try) to move the finger under the heavy head towards the center the finger will not move, instead the entire sledgehammer will move with the finger. As you move the finger at the end of the handle, that finger WILL slide along the handle towards the center of mass.

As you slide your two fingers in towards each other there are four results that are happening simultaneously in different amounts: The cane moves right, The finger moves right, the cane moves left, the finger moves left. The amount of friction on each finger is proportional to the percentage of the cane's weight on that finger due to that finger's distance from the center of mass. As the fingers slide towards each other, the finger further from the center of mass has less friction and can slide more than the closer finger. The closer finger's movement will just move the entire cane more than the further finger.

The other commenter that said it works even if the two sides have drastically different textures (frictions) isn't right. Again imagine an extreme example. Cover one end and finger with velcro. It won't work.

When the flame reaches the bottom, there is no more "column air", and where the column was, there is now a "column" of hot air. The heavier cold air, pushes the lighter hot air upwards, but seeing there is still a lite flame and ashes, it pushes the upwards too (the ashes and flame are lighter than the cold air around, so it "floats" to find air of the same density or until the flame goes out).

1) to visualise this think of this: keep one finger at the center of mass (CM), slide the other finger. As that finger moves, there is no friction with the rod since the force exerted by the finger at the CM balances the force of gravity of the rod and there is no normal force. However, practically there may be a small force since CM is a point while the finger represents an area of contact. However, still this ok... all of this would translate to wobbling instabilities and thus at the worst case it will momentarily imbalance the rod and tilt it minutely so that there is realy no interaction force between the rod and the finger (the rod will be deflected away from that finger), therefore, the rod is not influenced by the finger sliding. While the rod deflects away from the moving finger, it will not deflect away from the finger at the CM, since its being rotated about that point and not move relative to the CM finger. Now, as the rod swings back to touch the finger sliding, this finger momentarily minutely imbalances the rod in the same way and the process is repeated until the finger reaches the other one at the CM. Thus, the rods CM position will remain stationary (ie the rod will be still save for slight microscopic swinging) as the moving finger reaches the first finger at the CM.
Now lets imagine one finger being stationary and at a certain position. The other is moving and starts of at a position opposite the CM from the first. As that finger moves the rod exerts friction and moves with that finger. The CM then approaches the stationary finger. Before the moving finger reaches the stationary finger, the CM has to reach there frist (since they start out on opposite ends of the CM) so when this occurs, the first case that i described above happens and both will meet at the CM.
The last case is if both start out at opposite ends and are moving. Again before the fingers join, the CM has to reach one finger. At that point let's assume the finger that reached the CM is stationary and its velocity is added to the second finger (we are now in that fingers frame). Again we get to the second case (second paragrpah). Or if you don't want to look at it in frames of reference :that finger at the CM interacts with the rod through friction always now (since any swinging of the rod does not deflect the rod away from the CM position since thats the point of rotation as in situation 1) but the other finger yet to reach the first causes the rod to swing away from it momentarily as in situation 1(or theoretically and not practically... there is no normal force exerted on the moving finger and 0 friction). Therefore, the rod will be stationary relative to the finger at the CM (move at the same velocity as this finger) and the moving finger will reach the other finger at the CM without additionaly moving the rod ..basically like situation 1 except the rod is eventually moving at the same velocity as the finger that reached the CM first ,when it reaches the CM.

2) This has to do with the moment of inertia. different axis of rotation have a different moment of inertia or ease of rotation. Ease of rotation directly translates to stability. 

3)Let's say that we have one charge distribution of negative charges and another positive charge distribution per molecule. This is true because of the polar nature of the molecule. Each distribution is localised and seperated from each other. Let's join a line from the center of charge of one distribution to the center of charge of the other (like center of charge is analogous to center of mass). While the forces on each charge distribution balances, in the coordinate frame of the line joining the two CC's we can resolve the force components into a component along the line (that cancels out) and two components in opposite directions but perpendicular to the line. These cause a Torque and the line spins (the two charge distributions start rotating about a point on this line (in this case lets assume the two distributions carry the same charge magnitude and look the same ie symmetric with respect to one another, then the point of rotation will be about the center of the line). Now, due to the random orientation of the molecules, this will cause half of the molecules in the region of interaction to rotate clockwise, and half of them to rotate counter clockwise. This would cause a magnetic field about the molecule that will align the counter and clockwise rotating molecules into a north pole and a south pole. Any magnetic force exerted on this bar magnet would cause an overall net force displacing the entire set of molecules that compose this overall magnet. The magnetic force comes from the electrostatically charged cup through the spin reorganisation in the cup due to this water bar magnet (also why energy is still conserved). The water molecules would then be attracted to the cup. becuase the south pole of the cup would want to meet the north pole of the water magnet.

4) can be explained by 3) almost. The water molecules are attracted to the bar magnet and push the cereal through surface forces. 

5)flow of air, hot air rises that causes pressure to build against the circular container. When the container reduces in length, the pressure is then sufficient to squeeze the container more inwardsat the bottom relative to the top(since there is a pressure gradient). This causes the cylinder to try and  turn inside out, therefore flapping and creating lift.

Here's my crack at it:

1: The finger closer to the center of mass supports more of the cane's weight, causing its friction to be higher. This mismatched friction is just so that the percent change of one finger toward the center of mass is the same as the percent change of the other finger toward the center of mass. If you try it fast enough, the friction won't be strong enough to move the cane and you'll miss the CM.

2: Moment of inertia. It takes much less torque to increase the angular speed of an object around an axis that has a lot of mass concentrated around it than around an axis where the mass is far away from it. Therefore the slightest displacement of force from the long axis will cause the phone to twist as it flips. PS I've gotten objects to flip without twisting.

3: My guess would be water is attracted to static because of the conducting impurities in it, and distilled water would not be attracted.

4: I have no intuitional response for this one, but I've seen others say that it's because most cereals contain iron, and that makes sense to me. It also could be something about the water, but I cannot think of any such reason.

5: The heat of the fire causes an updraft, which must be replaced by cool air from around the bag. Once the fire burns low enough, the cool air grabs the underside of the bag and lifts it.

Teabag rocket - as the teabag burns down, the gasses emitted by the fire (hot, therefore less dense than the air around it, therefore buoyant) produce an upward force greater than the last remaining mass of the teabag produce in gravitational force.

1. The downwards torque due to gravity is greater closer to the center of mass. Thus whichever finger is further experiences less torque and consequently less friction, and so has greater ease of movement. This dynamic ensures that neither finger gains a significant lead approaching the center of mass, so both fingers are always roughly equal distance from it.

2. That axis of the phone has the greatest surface area perpendicular to axis of rotation along with the longest moment arm. 1. Pivot physics - fingers initially need to surround the center of mass of the cane or it will fall (duh!). Moving both fingers closer to each other implies friction against the cane, it's relative to the distance to the center of mass for each finger. The closer the finger is to the center of mass of the cane, the higher the friction is against it and it won't "rub" as fast as the other finger when getting them closer to each other.
2. For a typical object, moments of inertia aren't the same for all axis. One axis may require more torque than another to change its angular momentum due to how mass is distributed in the iPhone. For the third axis as shown in the video, one of the other axis requires way less torque so a little push on one side or another and the phone starts flipping on another axis.
3. []As mentioned in the video, a water molecule is polarized due to its shape. Being in a liquid state, it can freely rotate, so when a charged object (let's say {+}) gets close, the {+} of water molecules are facing away from the object (repulsed) while the {-} of the molecules are facing it (attracted); {-} sides of molecules now being closer to the object than {+} sides, water is attracted just like iron would.[] Electrons jumping from one object to another, makes the object losing electrons positively charged while the object gaining electrons becomes negatively charged, hence why they start getting attracted to each other. Same thing happens when you rub a balloon against your hair and stick it to a wall.
4. Cereals contain iron (at least this nugget does). We need iron in our diet, that's what makes our blood red BTW. Iron gets attracted by the magnet but it's stuck in the cereal nugget, so the whole nugget is attracted.
5. Same as a hot air balloon. The shape of the tea bag helps because as it burns, the air inside heats up and gets less dense than the air outside the bag. Once it reaches the bottom, remaining (and lightweight) ashes are in a volume of heated air with lesser density, it lifts up because of the buoyant force exerted by denser air around that volume.

-The cane: as you move one finger (notice both fingers don't always move simultaneously) closer to the center of mass (COM), that side of the cane becomes heavier on that finger (weight is distributed inequally), thus greater friction keeps the finger from sliding. Thus the other finger "catches up" since friction is less under less weight keeping things in balance until they meet in the middle. so it is a matter of self correcting unequal weight distribution resulting in unequal friction keeping both sides balanced until they meet in the middle
-The phone flip: I believe the reason is wind resistance. the phone continuously tries to move into the wind (path of least resistance to motion) so, even a perfect flip will still leave the phone fighting the wind. As for why it spins flat when laterally, I imagine that the speed of the spinning phone is great enough to not be affected by the wind (that is to say longitudinally, enough of the surface area is contacting the wind to cause instability whereas laterally the spin is fast enough to make the instability inconsequential? my best guess.
-Water bending: I believe it is the same static electric charge acting on water as acts on a piece of felt or paper. It's not chemistry, its physics! :)
-magnetic cheerios: I think it is not magnetic at all but, the strength of the magnet is strong enough (relative to the frictionless water and lightweight cheerio) to induce a gravitational pull?
-Tea bag rocket (not to be confused with a bill introduced by Ted Cruze): I believe that this is the same phenomena that happens with a hot air balloon. hot air is less dense than colder air. the residual tea bag is light enough that the hotter air surrounding the strand is forced upward by the surrounding colder air. This is why it doesn't work until it burns mostly to a single strand as it would be too heavy to be lifted by the surrounding air.
Those are my guesses.

1. Friction - The heavier side of the cane, will cause there to be more friction between the cane and the finger on that side, causing it to move slower.*

2. Weight - Different components in the phone will have different densities, so certain areas will way more than others, causing the centre of mass to be in a place that is not along the axis that Derek tried to get it to spin around. This causes it to wobble towards that side.*

3. When you charge the cup, it acquires extra electrons and becomes negatively charged. Water has no net electrical charge, but the negatively charged cup induces a complementary charge in the water. The electrons in the water can move slightly. When the negatively charged cup comes near the stream of water, it repels the electrons, so that the side of the water nearest the cup then has a positive charge. The attraction between this positive charge and the negatively charged cup causes a net force on the water, bending the stream.*

4. Cereal has Iron "dust" in it. The water just helps it move with less friction.*

5. The burning teabag creates convection currents (in the surrounding air), as less of the teabag remains intact, it becomes lighter. When the teabag is almost completely burned. The remains become light enough to be lifted by the convection currents.*

*An alternative answer is 42.

1. When you put your fingers directly under (what you think is) the center of mass, you usually miss the right place and even a little mistake ruins the balance. But when you reach the center of mass by moving your fingers towards each other from the points on both sides of the center, then you constantly adjust the relative speeds of your fingers to keep the balance.

3. In tap water you have quite a lot of ions. The cup is negatively charged due to the electrons from your hair, so it attracts cations from water (H+, Na+, Ca2+, Pb2+ :D etc.) and repels anions (OH-, Cl- etc.). Because anions are repelled, they are further away from the cup than cations, so the repelling electromagnetic force is weaker and therefore the stream of water is slightly attracted to the cup.

Water and cup: When the cup is rubbed on the hair, an imbalance of charge is created on both the cup and the hair. I don't remember the right polarity in the hair-plastic case, so i'll assume the cup becomes positive just for the sake of argument. If you are insulated from the ground, the cup essentially acts like a capacitor with the earth, because the imbalance of charge induces a redistribution of charges into whatever object is near. Since the water is effectively connected to ground, the positive charges move away from the cup and so the water molecules are now actracted by the cup itself. This also works with any fine powder, and you can do the experiment by charging anything (The polarity is not important) and then waving it over sugar, dust or salt. Essentially the particles start 'jumping' to the charged object to collect the imbalanced charges and when they do, there is no more attraction to keep them up and they fall again.

For the water attraction, is it because water molecules are constantly breaking into HO- and H3O+ ions, which are repelled and attracted, respectively, by the negative cup. This causes positive H3O+ ions to be pushed to the side of the stream closer to the cup, and negative OH- ions to be pushed to the side of the stream further from the cup. Since the positive ions in the stream are closer to the cup than the negative ions in the stream, the net force of electrostatic attraction is toward the cup (same charge/lesser distance = greater force for positive ions than negative ions), so  the stream is deflected toward the cup.

Question 1)
Assumptions:
The 2 supports begin with the rod's CG in-between them.
The rod is free to translate and rotate.
The relative velocity of the 3 objects is "small".  (This guarantees that reaction forces have time to propagate through the system.  While kinetic friction is acknowledged, it is fair to think of the experiment w/o invoking momentum, shock waves, or other unpleasantness.)

In a suitable reference frame (obey Newton's 1st):
Once the experiment begins, the supports are forced closer together.  Invariably, one of them will start to slide.
As it slides, mass of the rod that was between the support and the CG is now beyond the support from the CG.
This increases the normal force (weight) on the sliding support, while reducing the normal force (weight) on the static support.  The friction force corresponds to the normal force, such that increasing the normal force increases the friction force, and vice versa.
With this picture (keep it in mind, we'll be back in a second), 1 of 2 things will happen:
1) The sliding support will eventually have a friction coefficient (kinetic) that is greater than the other support's friction coefficient (static).  When this happens, the sliding support will stop, and the other support will begin to slide.
We're right back where we started, only mirrored.  Physics doesn't change when we apply a mirror, so we go back to step 1 and keep repeating.

No matter how many times step 1 is repeated, we not that A) at no time does the CG move beyond the 2 supports, and B) we can move the supports arbitrarily close.

2) One support could (theoretically, given an infinite number of steps and infinitely thin supports) move to the exact CG, which would leave the other support holding none of the force.

Practically, it is enough to have shown that "At no time does the CG move beyond the 2 supports and we can move the supports arbitrarily close."

The water stream gets attracted to the cup because the cup has a net gain or loss of electrons (due to the friction from the rubbing), thus making it charged.  As the cup gets closer to the stream, the water becomes polarized (meaning the electrons either locally move towards the cup or away from the cup, depending on the cup's net charge).  This causes the end of the water stream which is closer to the cup to have a charge which is opposite to the cup, and gets attracted to the cup.

#1 The finger that is closest to the center of gravity supports more of the weight of the object and therefore has more friction at it's contact point.  This allows the other finger to slip as you pull both fingers together. The finger that's farther from the center of gravity is always the one that slides as you pull them towards each other.  Starting in the middle and pulling them in opposite directions will yield the result of the first finger to slide will be the only finger to side.

#2 Has to do with the moment of inertia that the phone has along the two different axis.  I don't know enough about this to explain it.

#3 Is due to the concentrated static charge(positive or negative not sure which) on the cup that causes the like charge in the water to be repelled resulting in the water having an opposite charge from the cup, and therefore being attracted to it.  The water is grounded to the earth through the plumbing allowing electrons to flow towards the cup if the cup is positive or away from the cup if it is negative. Perform this experiment and allow the cup to get close enough for water drops to splash against it from the attractive force of the static charge.  As water drops accumulate on the cup notice that the attraction diminishes.  Another way to test this hypothesis is to allow the water to drip instead of flow in a stream past the charged object.  If my explanation is true then individual drops that broke away from the stream before they entered the static field of the charged cup would fall past the charged cup without being deflected from their expected path.

#4 Most if not all cereal is fortified with iron in the form of iron filings.  These iron filings are attracted to the strong magnetic field of the magnet and the attractive force is large enough to move the bit of cereal around on the surface of the water.

#5 The flame causes an updraft from the heat of the combustion gasses.  As the tea bag burns it leaves behind a very light weight ash like residue that is susceptible to being lifted up with the hot gasses in the updraft.

my guesses:
cane balancing - as shown in the video, the hand closer to the heavier side seems to move more slowly to the middle than the other hand, probably a result of a higher amount of force from the cane and gravity on that finger, increasing friction, but slowly reducing it as you get closer to the center of mass. meanwhile, the other finger would get the reverse effect: less force from the cane and gravity, lowering friction, but slowly increasing it the closer you get to the center of mass. as a result, the two fingers would meet at a point where the amount of force on each finger is the same, the center of mass.
phone flipping - the phone has higher mass on one side, the side which ends up tipping downward when the phone goes off axis. this would be the result of the location of the pieces on the motherboard, or of the location of the camera. details of why the mass isn't perfectly spread out I don't know since I don't know the looks of the inside of a phone. however, since this imbalance of mass exists (most likely unnoticed by merely picking up the phone, but noticeable when under the effects of gravity), the heavier part of the phone is pulled by gravity a little more than the rest, sending the phone off of its axis. when flipping it the other ways, this imbalance of mass is not in the right spot to affect the phone's flip.
water bending cup - rubbing the cup that way (I learned to do this with a comb, but oh well) gives a static charge to the cup. the impurities of the water (being filtered/cleaned tap water, there will always be miniscule amounts of various compounds and elements mixed in) are attracted to this charge, bending the stream towards the cup. however, the power is not strong enough to do more than a slight bend.
cereal and magnet - there's iron in the cereal. fairly miniscule amounts, but it is still there. since iron is magnetic, a strong enough magnet would attract the small amounts of iron in the cereal.
rocket tea bag - the tea bag is extremely light, enough that the hot air from the fire is able to lift it when the tea bag gets that small. since hot air rises, and the tea bag is light enough for the hot air to lift, the remains of the tea bag rise as well. it is similar to how a hot air balloon floats, except to a much lesser extent

my first thoughts on all of them - 

#1: the net torque acting on the cane begins at 0, so as you slide your fingers you are not applying any new torques on it, nor are you applying any translational forces.  The torques being applied by your hands are the same.  There's less friction on the lighter side and it moves until the friction gets bigger, then the other side can move.  Basically the torques always balance each other so you have to meet at the COM.

#2: I would think it has to do with the offset of the battery.  When you spin it the first way, the phone rotates about its COM which is very close to the center of the screen because the axis is surrounded by mass.  When you spin it along the short axis, there is a low moment of inertia because all of the mass is so close to the axis of rotation.  When you spin the 3rd way, the moment of inertia is larger (I tried this very unscientifically over my bed by trying to approximate equal torques).  I'm thinking this offset of mass and the higher moment of inertia causes the axis to wobble and creates precession, like a gyroscope.

#3: The ions in the water from dissolved minerals migrate towards or away from the cup, similar to when you charge something by induction.  This is more of a separation of charge that allows for the stream to be bent, kind of like a charged comb picking up pieces of paper.  Charged always attracts neutral.  If I had DI water I would test this out.  Now that I think about it, if the water molecules being polar was the answer, you should be able to deflect a stream of water away from something as well as towards it, but that never happens.  

#4:  Cereal has iron in it, remember when you put Total in a blender in grade school and stuck a magnet in to pull out the iron?  The iron is influenced by the magnetic field.

#5:  There is an updraft created by the burning tea bag because the hot air is less dense than the air underneath.  When the tea bag burns up and all that is left is the ash, that leftover ash is so light that it gets caught in the updraft and rises up.

For the charged cup and the water:
The atomic weight of oxygen is ~15 and that of hydrogen is ~1. So on one side of the molecule the weight is 2 and the other side is 15. The charge of the cup only creates a rotation in the molecules making them spin in an anti clockwise direction around the geometrical center of the molecule but that's not where the center of mass is. This causes the molecule to shift towards the cup.

The teabag rocket:
The flame heats up the paper so the bottom of the paper is also heated which in turn heats up the air towards the bottom. This causes the air to rise and once the paper has burnt off almost entirely, it's light enough for the hot air at the bottom lifts the remains of the paper.

The cane:
When you slide your fingers you can still balance the cane by slightly raising one of your hands but with your friend holding it you can't do that since the stick is exactly straight.

For number 4: this one is really easy and there are many experiments about it. In the cereal, there are small fine amounts of iron. You may think, why is there iron in my cereal? Well you get really small amounts and they help your blood (I'm not getting into that). Don't believe me? Search up the cereal iron experiment.

Now for the third one. The electric charge is high enough to attract at least the partial positive hydrogen end of one water molecule. Once this happens, this water molecule, which has strong intermolecular dipole-dipole interaction aka hydrogen bonding, attracts neighbouring molecules through cohesive forces , which in turn attract their own neighbouring molecules and this keeps on going on until there are no water molecules left. Hence the stream of water deflects towards the cup.

Here's my go for the second one. If we observe then the moment of inertia of the rotational motion in the final case will be the maximum of all the cases. So we will be required to provide a greater torque so that the phone will spin around. The energy for motion comes from our hands, and hence when more energy is required, we can of course provide it, but there won't be much precision in our throw. 3. Thankfully, my physics teachers taught this one properly.  Rubbing the cup transfers electrons, leaving the cup negatively charged (and your hair positively charged).  When the cup approaches the running water, it repels the electrons in the water (away from the cup).  This leaves the close side of the water positively charged.  Positive water then attracts the water and the cup.  Hence, the bend!  If the water touches the cup, the electrons will jump to the water, and the effect will be lost.

1) Sum of the forces says the weight of the cane will be spread among your two fingers.  Sum of moments says the finger closest to the center of mass will receive more of the weight*.  Friction is proportional to weight (normal force), so sliding will begin easiest on the finger further from the center of mass.

* Consider the axis of rotation to be at the center of mass of the cane.  Since the cane is not rotating, the moments caused by the forces of your two fingers must cancel each other out.  The moments cancelling each other out means they are equal and opposite.  Moments = Force * Distance, so if the moments are equal, the Forces * Distances must be equal.  Thus, a force of 1 N at a distance of 10 cm would be balanced by a force of 2 N at a distance of 5 cm.  By this example we see that the closer finger (5 cm) receives twice the force, and thus, twice the friction.

1) In this case, we can assume friction is directly proportional to the normal force since the normal force is pretty low. When one finger is further away from the center of mass than the other finger, then the finger that's closer is carrying more of the weight of the cane, and thus has a greater frictional force being applied to it than the finger that's further away. Thus, the finger that's further away meets less resistance due to friction, and travels faster than the finger that's closer (assuming you're giving both fingers equal force). This continues until they both meet up in the center of mass of the cane.

2) I believe you said how this works in the video at 1:32- "instabilities grow until the phone rotates around another axis." It's nearly impossible to direct all the force you're putting on the phone perfectly on it's horizontal center of mass. Any minuscule offset from the horizontal center of mass would manifest itself more and more as time goes on. However, If you flipped it perfectly on the center of horizontal mass and assume ceterus paribus, I can't think of any reason why any amount of torque would be applied to the phone on any axis other than the one that you applied it to.

3) Perhaps the electrical field created by the cup causes the electrons to move up the stream of water onto the faucet, making the water molecules distinctively positive? Other than that, I have no idea.

4) I doubt the cereal itself is magnetic. My guess that it's being moved by the water underneath it. Why that water is moving, however... well, that's a different question. All the water molecules in that bowl are in constant motion- that's just the properties of a liquid. So, maybe the magnetic field generated by that magnet is influencing which direction they move in, giving the appearance that the cereal itself is being pulled by the magnet.

5) Fire is hot. Hot air is less dense than cold air, making hot air rise above cold air. The fire causes the air around it to rise, effectively making all the air around the tea bag to move upwards. Eventually, when the bag's mass is low enough, it gets carried away by the air moving upwards.

Oh and for flipping the phone, The Battery is your problem. Flipping on either Y or Z axis the mass is equally distributed along the phone. but flipping on X axis the battery is heavier than the camera side of the phone. and the mass is no more equally distributed. Your moment of inertia is disturbed.  Thereby resulting in an unequal revolutions.

Any time two electrons share the same orbital, their spin quantum numbers have to be different. Whenever two electrons are paired together in an orbital, or their total spin is 0, they are diamagnetic electrons. Atoms with all diamagnetic electrons are called diamagnetic atoms.
A paramagnetic electron is an unpaired electron. An atom is considered paramagnetic if even one orbital has a "net" spin. An atom could have ten diamagnetic electrons, but as long as it also has one paramagnetic electron, it is still considered a paramagnetic atom.
Diamagnetic atoms repel magnetic fields. The unpaired electrons of paramagnetic atoms realign in response to external magnetic fields and are therefore attracted. Paramagnets do not retain magnetization in the absence of a magnetic field, because thermal motion randomizes the spin orientations.

Alright, this is interesting...

1. When one finger is nearer to the centre of gravity, it supports more weight of the cane than the other finger, which also increases its friction (which incidentally can be proved by this - Place one finger under the centre of gravity and the other at any other point, then try to move them in turn. The finger under the centre of mass will never be the one to move), causing the finger to slow/stop and the other finger keeps moving until it is slowed down in turn. This continues until they meet.

2. The phone flip might have to do with aerodynamics... on flipping flat, of course it's very easily to give the right motion, it has good angular momentum, it cuts through the air neatly and keeps spinning. When spun around the long axis and tossed, the angular momentum is high enough to keep it spinning stably (like in case of a top), but when flipped end over end the angular momentum is so low that forces given by our hand in unintended directions come into play, and the phone tumbles.

3. I have doubts about this one. I suppose when the cup is close enough, all the molecules flip one by one (induction) so that a positive stream is towards the side of the cup and a negative stream diametrically opposite. The distance between them (the width of the stream) is enough to cause a difference in the force of attraction for the positive side and repulsion for the negative, so the stream bends. And the stream sticks together due to cohesion.

4. No idea. Doesn't work with other light objects so I suppose there has to be something magnetic in the cereal... not sure.

5. The burning column creates convection air currents as hot air goes up, cool air from sides come to take its place. When it's light enough, it gets carried away by these same currents.

The phone flip has to do with aerodynamics. On its thin side, you are presenting the lowest surface area towards the direction of movement through the air, so the effect of the air resistance is at its most minimal. I suppose there is also some stability gained by the vector created by the rotational velocity, but that should be fairly constant between the different angles since the mass and force applied by the throw are approximately the same.  In landscape orientation, the air resistance is more spread out perpendicular to the axis of the rotation, so there is less air resistance at any one point in the phone and it has more stability. In portrait orientation, there is less mass balanced away from the center, and so small changes in the initial conditions or in the air resistance build up quickly.  If you try throwing the phone in portrait mode but at a slower rate, so that it only makes one or one and a half rotations, you are likely to be successful with practice and a steady hand.

The experiment with the charged cup and the stream of water is due to the bipolarity of water molecules. The water molecules could be arranged so they they are either attracted or repelled to the magnetic field generated by the cup, if the cup is positively charged then those molecules arranged in more of a negative manner will be attracted to the system AND those with like charges will be repelled. 1) At any instant when the cane is in equilibrium on the two fingers, the C.G. must lie between the two fingers. If it is outside the torques due to the C.G. at the two fulcra ( fingers) cannot balance each other. Hence, in the limiting case when the two fingers come into contact they are on the C.G.

2) This has to do with moment of inertia (MOI.) which a system always tries to minimize. MOI is proportional to distance of the edges of the object from the axis of rotation, hence it is the largest in the last case making it the most unstable. This is similar to the case when a figure skater brings their limbs close to the body while spinning for stability.

Let's try:
1. The cane is unbalanced to begin with (has a knob at one end) an it sits on 2 (A and B) points. While this 2 points have equal friction coefficients (u), the friction forces (F) differs, as the normal (N, determined by the partial mass (m) resting on the point and gravity) differs. F(point) = u*N(point), where N(point) = m(point)*g. So, as you start bringing the 2 resting points together, the cane will slide more on the point where there is less partial mass. (In an ideal word this motion will be linear decelerated, but in reality is more jerky, as in the video). This will happen until the 2 partial masses equalize and will continue until A and B are brought together, at a point where m(A)=m(B), the cane's center of mass.

Based on this reasoning, I would furthermore state that you would not be able to see this effect with pure, deionized water.

1) With a greater distance between the finger and the centre of mass, there is a greater moment. This means a greater force upon the other finger, which causes greater friction and makes it move slower. The other way around, with the finger closer to the centre of mass, creates a smaller moment and therefore lesser frictional force, allowing the finger to move faster. This balances everything and ends up the fingers at the centre of mass by regulating velocity/force.

When it rotates along the smaller axis, there's not enough distance to create a significant moment - but when on a longer one, the non-uniform nature of the phone (the differing inertia across it) means that different parts of the phone are accelerating differently from the force of your hand, which means it won't spin uniformly.

Well, let's see, how much I might get right.:
1. The finger closer to the center of mass experiences a greater force from the mass of the cane, which results in greater friction (assuming, that the friction coefficient of the cane on both fingers is roughly equal). The greater friction in turn means, that when pushing the fingers inwards, the cane should actually move more on the opposite finger, until the friction on both sides is the same. If it is the same, then (all other things being equal) the downward force must be the same on both sides, which means, that the center of mass must be in the middle between the two fingers. It stays that way until the fingers touch in the center, as each imbalance would be corrected by the same process.

2) This happens for two reasons: for one, when you flip your phone the unstable way, imbalances in the force given by each finger, although slight, are magnified by the relatively large moment arm causing the phone to turn about the unintended axis, and overcoming the centripetal force pushing the corners away from the intended axis of rotation. #3 The water creates an electrostatic charge when flowing through a medium air/pipe, which is attracted to the charge on the cup.
#4 Many breakfast cereals are fortified with iron. (Crunch some up, put in bag of water, and let it soak. Then take a magnet and drag it around the outside of the bag and see all the black particles form up under the magnet.)
#5 As the paper burns, the air above it rises. This causes air to move in from below. When the paper/ash is light enough, the moving air is able to lift it.

1.The frictional force is given by F = u * N , where F is the friction between the two objects, u is a constant depending on the material, and N is the normal force or the force pushing the two objects together. In this case, N is the gravitational force since the cane is being pulled down onto his fingers. As he slides his fingers together, one finger will get closer to the center of mass and carry more weight. This will make N larger for that finger and the frictional force will get higher. Now the other finger will slide along the cane more easily and get closer to the center of mass. Soon you reach an equilibrium and both fingers slide perfectly into position.﻿
2.The insides of your phone are not homogeneous when you flip it with the wide end up, but they roughly are when you do it with one of the thin edges. So inertia affects different parts of the phone's body differently, which ends up translating into spin along another axis as well.

Experiment -1 
When the two fingers are placed apart and the center of gravity (C.G.) is somewhere in the middle and you start moving the two fingers closer.
Let x be the distance between first finger and C.G. and y be the distance between second finger and C.G. If mass of the cane is M, Normal force applied by finger1 is =M*g*y/(x+y) and by finger 2 = M*g*x/(x+y). Both fingers are approaching the C.G. from both sides. Now, the two fingers are in "relative" motion to each other, so its obvious that the cane surface cannot remain "relatively" stationary to both the fingers simultaneously. Initially when you start moving the fingers, friction will act and slipping between the fingers and cane take place UNTIL the time one finger reaches the C.G. first. Lets say finger 1 reaches the C.G. first. Therefore, the value of x becomes 0 at that time. Since, x=0, then normal force by finger 2 is also 0 by the formula I had stated above. Since, normal force by finger 2 is zero, the frictional force between the cane and the finger 2 is also zero.

Lets see what happens after this moment. Two cases are possible.

Case 1: The coefficient of friction is high enough that only static friction occurs between finger 1 and the cane. Since only static friction is in play, finger 1 and cane will have no "relative motion" and so C.G. always remains coincident with finger 1.
And friction between the finger 2 and cane will continue to be zero always. Thus, finger 2 will simply slip on the cane's surface without any friction or relative motion between them. After sometime, finger 2 meets finger 1 which is already at the C.G. 

SUCCESS !!!

Case 2: If the coefficient of friction is not high enough, kinetic friction comes into play between finger 1 and relative motion will take place between cane and finger 1. Finger 1 will move past the cane's CG.Now both fingers are on the same side of the CG and the cane will fall down due to unbalanced moment.

FAILURE !!!

So, most of the times the experiment will be a success (CASE-1). But if you accelerate the finger 1 pretty fast "near the end of the experiment" i.e. the force applied on the finger 1 by your bones/muscles is more than the limiting friction "near the end of the experiment" , the cane will fall down.
You end up at the center of mass because as you go unproportional mass would effect the rate at which you move slightly.

Here is what I am thinking. Hopefully I'm right on a few of these. First the short answers:

1) The finger farther away from the center of mass has a smaller frictional force than the other finger, so the finger farther away will slide more. This repeats until the two fingers have met up at the center of mass. (more detail below)

2) I think this one has to do with the phone being more difficult to rotate in some directions than others (has to do with its moment of inertia in different directions), making it hard for humans to spin the phone in the way shown in the video without also spinning it a little bit the other way. (more detail below)

3) The water molecules will rotate, but I would suspect this creates an overall difference in the distribution of charge in the whole water stream, which is a large enough distance to take advantage of the non-constant electric field coming from the cup (like how a neutrally charged non-conductor can be attracted to a charged object because it becomes polarized). I really don't know if there actually is a great enough difference in the electric field coming from the cup for this to work on individual atoms, but the electric field from the cup is not really that constant (more thoughts below).

4) Cereal has a lot of iron in it?

5) When the teabag is nearly all burnt, it has a pretty small mass, which can be lifted by the rising column of hot air it is sitting in.


Now, the more detailed explanations:

1) The finger closer to the center of mass has a higher normal force (net torque is zero, so both fingers exert the same torque. Torque is FxR, so the finger closer to the center of mass has has lower R, so it must exert a larger force to keep things balanced). This means that the finger closer to the center of mass has a higher force of friction because the force of friction is proportional to the normal force, so it will slide less than the finger farther away. 

2) . The phone has much smaller moments of inertia (smaller moment of inertia means easier to turn) when it is flipped with the axis of rotation going through the screen or lengthwise down the phone, compared to if the axis of rotation is going across the phone. This means that when you spin the phone with the axis of rotation going across the phone, it is really easy to mess up and get it spinning in another direction. I did a test where I put my phone on the edge of a table and then pushed it over, and the phone rotated perfectly with the axis of rotation across the phone, so I don't think there is something weird with the phone because it is possible to rotate the phone this way. I also tested similarly shaped objects like DVD cases (which have similar moments of inertia about the different axis because they're shaped similar to the phone), and they exhibited the same behavior as my phone both when I tossed them in the air and when I pushed them off the edge of the table.

For the book flip I originally thought that perhaps the phone was flipping because of variances in the phone's distribution of mass, but if this were the case than this effect would not happen in all rectangular prisms. Give it a shot with a book and you will find the same thing. In addition, air resistance is not the reason as the phone is moving too slow to really have much resistance at all and this still works in a vacuum. The real reason has to do with the properties of a rectangular prism, which is what your phone is. A rectangular prism has three axises parallel to its edges, one having the maximum moment of inertia, another having a minimum moment of inertia, and the third (unstable one) lying somewhere between the previous two. The unstable axis creates a disturbance when one tries to rotate about it. If one wants a mathematical proof of this look up "axis of rotation rectangular prism."

1: i think the answer is drag (and of course you magnificent brain): to sustain the cane at the opposite ends you have to produce some upward force, which produces a certain amount of drag between your finger and the cane when you try to slide it. let's say you have you fingers at point A and B (at the extreme ends of the cane). let's say you apply some force on your fingers to try and move them closer, and you put more in A then in B so A is the first to move. now that finger will move from A to C, closer to the centre: now the portion between A and C will create some downward torque which will translate to an upward torque on B which will counter the weight force in B. so, as the amount of upward torque in B increases as the finger is on it's the way from A to C, the finger in B will have to produce less upward force to counter gravity and that in return means that drag between the finger in B and the cane will decrease, proportionally. which means that now, with less drag, the finger in B will be capable of moving towards the centre as well. but now as this finger moves, a portion of the cane will be left un-supported and, basically like for the other finger on the opposite side, that portion will produce a downward torque which will counterbalance the other torque ( the one on the other side), so that now the finger that was in B (now moving) will have once again to sustain the full weight of the cane, which means producing more upward force which means creating more drag which will eventually stop the finger in point D. now repeat the process untill you reach the centre of mass, and you will because the beauty of all this is that the forces are all interdipendent, so that when one decrases, another increases proportionally an the balance is maintained. or at least this is my explanation.

2 - The phone flipping problem - This problem’s explanation has to do with the inertia ellipsoid (Poinsot's ellipsoid) and it’s three axis. Imagine three axis inside your phone. Axis M, S and L. Axis M goes from one side, through its center of mass and to the other side. Axis S goes through the center of the screen, through the center of mass and to center of the back cover. Axis L goes from the top, again, through the center of mass, to the bottom of the phone. The length of each axis in the ellipsoid is proportional to the momentum of the phone when it spins around the said axis. In this case, the biggest axis is the one that goes through screen and back cover. The rotation of almost any object around its middle axis (M) is always unstable. The same thing happens with Hyperion, one of Saturn’s irregular moons.

1.  The finger supporting more weight will have greater friction between the finger and the cane.  The finger with more friction will move slower toward the center than the finger with less friction.  If the faster moving finger moves too fast to the point it is supporting more weight than the other finger, it will become the slower finger.  It is a self-stabilizing system... as long as both fingers have the same coefficient of friction.  Put oil or grease on one finger and this won't work.

I think the second one has something to do with chaos theory.  When you flip the phone end over end, if you apply the slightest amoung of force to one side of the phone than the other, the affect compounds and makes the phone flip erratically as displayed in the video.  The phone will flip normally when you spin it, because there is much less surface area you grab onto thus leaving much less room for error (applying more force to one side).  In a way the phone acts like a lever, when spinning it, the lever is the same lenght, but has a smaller surface area, when spinning it lenthwise, the surface are is larger, but the lever is much shorter, and when flipping it end over end the lever is long and the surface area is larger, which ensures that some error will be made when trying to apply equal force to all sides, thus producing the erratic flip.  I am no physicist, so I could very well be wrong, but this seems like a reasonable explanation.

1. Coulomb friction.  F=N*mu, where F is the force due to friction, N is force normal to the surface, and mu is the coefficient of friction.  The finger with a smaller normal force (N) will always have a lesser resultant force due to friction, and will thusly slide until the force due to friction is balanced between the two fingers.  As you approach the center of mass of the crane, the normal force increases until it reaches a maximum at the center.  This "balancing act: between the two fingers will continue until both fingers reach the center of mass, where the normal force, and thusly, force due to friction is at a maximum.  This experiment can be derailed if (1) the dynamic coefficient of friction between the two fingers are different (put a glove on one hand), or (2), go slow enough one so that one of the fingers stops (where the static coefficient of friction overtakes the dynamic coefficient of friction, which is always less).  

2. Mass moment of inertia (rotataion moment of inertia).  Simply put, a mass will always prefer to spin upon a path of least resistance, that is, where the MMoI is least.  Spinning about it's flat orientation is an unstable energy level (similar to an inverted pendulum), especially at high rotataional velocities (where centrifugal acceleration is higher).  In theory if it were thrown perfectly, it would continually rotate about the flat axis, but the system is unstable enough such that this isn't really possible by hand--one can do a decent job by carefully spinning at very low speed.  

3. Water molecules have a strong tendency to form hydrogen bonds, which weakly bonds two or more water molecules, increasing the size of the new molecule, and the resultant net charge across it.  Thusly, the electrostatic charge affects the orientation of groups of weakly bonded water molecules, not just single water molecules.  Perhaps there are other reasons as well.  

4. Cereal has iron, which is attracted to magnets. 

5. Convection heat transfer caused by the fire causes the air immediately above the flame to rise, creating a weak low pressure zone in the vicinity of the tea bag.  Once the flame burns though the bag, you have ashes left, which are pulled into the low pressure zone.  Obviously, this doesn't last forever.

1) The frictional force resisting your fingers is proportional to the normal force of the cane on your fingers.  The finger that is carrying more weight will move slower because it has more friction resisting it, allowing the finger that's not carrying as much weight to move faster and catch up.  My guess is that if you could somehow make there be completely zero friction at all, the trick wouldn't work at all.

2) The phone doesn't have a uniform internal weight distribution.  After a quick Google search for pictures of the inside of an iPhone, you can see that the battery (which is a significant portion of the device's weight) is located off-center, which is why the phone likes to rotate along the long axis.  I think it's also important to note that the axis that it always likes to rotate about has a much lower moment of inertia than the other 2 axes.

3) Tap water has dissolved ions in it (probably sodium, calcium, etc.), giving the water a net charge.  If this is true, then pure, distilled water shouldn't respond to the magnetic field.

4) Many cereals contain iron.  The magnet is attracted to the iron in the cereal.  The attraction isn't strong enough to lift the cereal into the air, but when it's floating on water, it takes a much smaller force to get a noticeable effect.

5) The flame heats the air above the teabag, making this air less dense than the cooler air below the teabag.  When the remnants of the bag get light enough, it is launched into the air by this convection current.

1) Friction = Normal Force * Coefficient of Friction. As one finger moves closer to the other finger, the friction of that finger becomes greater with the cane, because the normal force is made greater by the fact that the center of gravity of the cane is being moved closer to that finger. Because of this, the friction between said finger and cane also becomes greater, so that said finger becomes unable to move, whereas the other finger becomes easier to move due to the same effect, but in reverse. This happens repeatedly until the fingers are at the center of the cane.

2) I believe that's just a simple butterfly effect. Because is is nearly impossible to flip the phone perfectly, as the phone rotates in the air, the imperfections of the beginning of the flip become more obvious to the point where the phone visibly goes off track. This doesn't happen as much when you flip it on it's short axis or on its side because then gravity has less effect on it at the beginning due to the way you hold it.

3) It's tap water, so it contains ions that react strongly to other charged particles.

4) Cereal generally has a decent amount of iron in it, which reacts to magnets. Plus the water reduces friction.

5) Hot air is lighter than cool air, so the air from the fire lifts the tea bag up as the cold air from the room rushes underneath and pushes it up.

1.) The center of gravity of an object in this case bares the highest gravitational force.  Since frictional force is given as Ff = mu*N, the frictional force increases as the finger approaches the center of mass, slowing it down, and eventually meeting the other finger.

2.) Flipping your phone end-over-end is analogous to flipping a half-empty water bottle end-over-end.  There is no axis of symmetry for the phone to rotate around, so it spins to compensate for this.

3.) The water stream is tap water, containing charged particles call ions.  These ions are hydrated by the water, so when they are attracted by the slight dipole of the cup, they drag water molecules along with them. (Expect to see a more drastic effect with salt water.)

4.) The cereal contains trace amounts of iron (a paramagnetic metal).  Since it is floating on water, there is practically zero frictional force to resist the magnetic attraction.

5.) Burning the paper creates hot gases above an area of cooler gas at a lower pressure.  When this front reaches the bottom (i.e. all the paper is burned up) the pressure is only at the bottom, now with the pressure differential being at the top.  Since the mass of the paper column has decreased so drastically, this additional pressure is enough to overcome the gravitational force, launching it upwards.

(Someone please correct me if I'm wrong!)

Alright, let's give this a shot...

1) Not actually a physics phenomena at all, your brain/hands can simply sense and adjust while you're closing your hands together, that's why you end up balancing in the end. When you're just taking the cane away from someone else, you have no sense of its mass when you place your fingers, so you have no way to adjust apart from an educated guess... which tends to be not accurate enough.

2) The insides of your phone are not homogeneous when you flip it with the wide end up, but they roughly are when you do it with one of the thin edges. So inertia affects different parts of the phone's body differently, which ends up translating into spin along another axis as well.

3) I'm not sure if this would actually work with pure water; tap water is not pure water it contains, amongst others, chlorine. Long story short, water has an electric charge to begin with, because it's filled with ions.

4) Related to the previous effect, you basically tug on the water itself, sort of creating a little wave that can move whatever is on top. Alternatively it's possibly the cereal simply gets soaked in water which, as mentioned previously, is not neutral.

5) I'm going to guess the fire heats up the air, which creates an upwards draft; once enough of the paper has burned, the leftover becomes light enough that this draft can lift it up into the air.

For number one, I know I've got it. The further from the axis of rotation (in this case the center of mass) you are, the more rotational force is being applied. With greater rotational force being applied to the finger near the handle of the cane, that increases the amount of surface force and therefore friction between finger and cane compared to the other finger. So, as long as both fingers are applying the same amount of force horizontally, one will have a slight variation in speed because it's working against a greater amount of friction. The effect of the rotational force of the cane decreases the further along your fingers go, until they both meet where rotational force is zero: the center of mass.

For number two I think I've got. This also has to do with center of mass. The COM of your phone isn't perfectly in the middle. Internally, there might a dense battery on the right, while there's some lighter circuitry on the left. So, in a perfect flip, if you apply the same amount of force to left and right, the left is gonna take off faster than the right. In doing so the phone is now rotating along an unintentional axis.

If magnetic field is constant, this effect is lost, but because the water is running, every second a new portion of water is undergoing this effect.

Number four, I'll take a wild stab at because I have to get to class, and say it has something to do with a dipole moment in water?

And number five I'll try and guess that it has something to do with either enthalpy converting heat into mechanical energy, or with the density of the bag after combustion being less than the density of air.

1. Friction. As you move your fingers together and say the left finger goes too far, the cane pushes down on that finger harder (more friction) than on the right one. So the right finger can be moved easier. As you tend to move your fingers together with roughly the same force this effect slows down the finger that went too far, thus balancing out the movement until they meet at the centre of mass.

2. Moment of inertia. In that direction of rotaion the moment of inertia is the highest, because the mass of the phone is distributed very inhomogenic around the axis of rotation. Also the distance of the masses is far higher than when you rotate the phone along the centre of the side with the charger connection and centre of the top side. With this high moment of inertia it is hard to get the phone to rotate along this axis fast enough to get a stabilizing gyroscopic effect. So even small deviations in the distribution of the mass from the perpendicular axis will produce moments around the other axes.

The two fingers finding the center of mass of a stick is an old one.  Forgot where I first heard it, but I've been using it as an analogy for teaching hockey players how to balance their weight on their ice skates haha.

My guess on how it works, I didn't sketch out a free body diagram but I believe it would be based off friction and moment forces.  Here is my solution, but first wee need some variables:
L = Left Finger
R = Right Finger
a = distance from L to center of gravity
b = distance from R to center of gravity
m = mass of object
g = acceleration of gravity

So the formula for how much weight is on each finger would be:
Fsum = 0 = Rforce + Lforce - mg
mg(b) - Lforce = 0
-> Lforce = mgb
and
mg(a) -Rforce = 0
-> Rforce = mga
And friction f = uN where N is equal to the normal force of each finger (or Rforce for the right finger).  So the larger the force on the finger, the more friction there is and the less likely it will slide toward the middle.

Here is the what the maths are saying and its very intuitive.  You have 2 fingers, each one has roughly the same coeficient of friction (a value which means basically stickiness or resistance to motion), the closer your finger gets to the middle the more weight it has to support.  And since the friction force is directly proportional to the normal force, or how much weight it is supporting, the finger with less weight on it (or farthest from the center of mass) will have less friction and will slide.  And if you do it really slowly and only move 1 finger at a time, you are now dealing with kenetic friction and static friction.  Static friction is always higher than kinetic friction, so you'll move one finger in until it actually experiences MORE weight than the other, then that finger will stop and the other will move until the kinetic friction is larger than the static friction on the other finger.
