1. cane
-------
When two figgers are placed anywhere on the cane and are still able to hold it up, that means the centre of mass lies somewhere between the two fingers. The normal forces on the two fingers will in general be different, as the centre of mass lies more to one finger than to the other. Since the amount of friction depends on the strength of the normal force, the friction experienced by each finger during the motion will be different for each finger. That at least partially explains the effect, but I suspect there is also a psychological factor at play -- you "want" to keep the cane up, so you (consciously or subconsiously) tend to move one finger faster than the other when it experiences less friction. It is the combination of these two effects that lets the fingers converge to the center of mass.


2. phone flip
-------
Basic rigid body dynamics shows that objects are rotationally stable when they rotate about an axis belonging to either their largest or smallest principle moments of inertia. But rotation about the axis belonging to the intermediate principle moment of inertia is UNstable and will quickly die out, transferring the rotational energy to the other two axes. 
The phone's long axis (from top to bottom) is the smallest principle moment of inertia, the phone's short axis (from front to back) is the largest. The 3rd axis is the intermediate one, so when rotating about that axis, the motion will quickly change to a combined rotation about the two other axes. 


3. cup + water 
-------
The cup has a net charge (usually negative). The water does not, or much less anyway. The net effect of this charge imbalance between the two is: 

 - the water molecules will rotate, putting the positive end of the dipole near the cup, and the negative end urther from it
 - the electron clouds around all atoms in the water molecules will deform slightly, away from the cup
 - any free electrons, negative ions, ect. in the water will move away from the cup, and free protons, positive ions, etc. will move toward it

Thus, overall, the water stream is (slightly) negatively charged on the side opposite the cup, and positively charged on the side nearest to the cup, while remaining electrically neutral as a whole. The distance of the negative charges in the water to the cup is therefore slightly larger than the distance of the positive charges in the water to the cup, creating a net attractive force between the water and the cup. Given also that the electromagnetic force is extremely strong compared to, say, gravity, this difference in distance causes enough force to cause a very significant deflection of the water stream. 



4. magnetic cereal
-------
Cereal contains iron, simple as that. Just a little, but enough to have an easily observable effect when the cereal is placed on a very low-friction surface, e.g., water.


5. teabag rocket
-------
The heat of the flame makes the surrounding air rise up. This will create a small updraft, which will drag the tea bag along with it when its mass has decreased enough. Note that the effect is much stronger when the teabag is lit at the bottom.

1. Assuming that the cane and your two fingers have a constant and equal value for the resulting coefficient for (static/kinetic) friction, then the finger closest to the center of mass (CoM) will experience a greater normal force than the other. This results in a greater friction force, which would have to be overcome to start the cane sliding over that finger. So, the finger further away from the CoM will start slipping first until it is closer to the CoM, when the other finger would start slipping. This goes on until the two fingers meet near the center of mass. One note though, if there is a big difference between the coefficient of static and kinetic friction (static is higher) there could be a slight imbalance, since this will mean that a finger will stop sliding when it is significantly closer to the CoM than the other (occasionally pause the sliding can prevent this).

1. The cane works because whichever hand is closer to the center of mass puts a stronger normal force on the cane. This is because in order for the sum of the torques to be equal to 0, the torques on either side of the center of mass have to be equal, and because the hand closer to the cane handle is closer to the center of mass, it puts a stronger normal force onto the cane to equal with the other hand which is further from the center of mass. Because the normal force of the hand closer to the center of mass is greater, it has more friction with the cane and therefore more inclined to stay on the same location of the cane. You will also notice that as the hands move closer the cane moves left and right, this is cause by the differences in the kinetic and static coefficients of friction. While the hand closer to the center of mass does not move because its frictional force is greater, the other hand moves because its kinetic frictional force is smaller. This occurs until the hand farther from the center of mass moves close enough that its kinetic frictional force equals and then surpasses the maximum static frictional force. This causes the hand closer to the center of mass to move, giving it a smaller coefficient of friction because it is now experiencing a kinetic friction force. This allows the other hand, now closer to the center of mass, to stop and the experience a static frictional force. This process causes the cane to move side to side until the hands meet at the center of mass.

2. The phone can never have a perfect flip in that orientation because the center of mass on the phone is not directly on center (On my phone it is slightly to the left). Because rotating objects prefer to spin around their center of mass, when they are not spun around their center of mass, their rotations become unstable attempting to find a more stable rotation. This works for a similar reason as to why your Spinning Disk Trick works. (In that trick it is forced to spin around an axis normal to the point of contact with the ground because of friction, but the center of mass does not stay above that point because the center of mass of that coin is lopsided so its rotation becomes unstable and it tries to find the most stable state for its rotation) The trick does not work when spinning it around the other axes because those rotations are stable.

3. The reason the water moves toward the cup is because of the dipoles, but not individually. In the same way that individual magnetic dipoles line up in the same orientation acting as one large dipole to give magnets their magnetic fields, the electric dipoles in water line up in the same orientation to give the water its electric field. The individual dipoles line up only because the cup is charged. This is an induced dipole force, which is always an attractive force.

4. The cheerio is just an example of a paramagnet, which experiences its own small magnetic moment when exposed to an external magnetic field. This is similar to the dipole induced force, but with magnetic forces, not electric. And similarly, it is always an attractive force.

5. The tea bag floats up because as it burns it becomes less massive (not less dense) and can be swept up more easily by its smaller mass. It is swept up by the air the bag is heating up, which is less dense than the colder air in the room, causing it to float up and sweeping up the burnt up bag.

water has various impurities in it. His tap water would have cations like Ca2+, Mg2+, K+, Na+, etc., anions like Cl-, CO3 2-, SO4 2-, etc. Even in purified water, H3O+ and OH- ions form spontaneously. Water also allows all of these charges to move around very freely unimpeded. Assuming the cup has a negative charge (as opposed to positive), that would cause the positive cations to be attracted. It would also cause the negative anions to be repelled, but since they are being repelled, they are farther away and therefore feel a weaker force than the cations. The net result? The water is attracted to the cup. Since the entire width of the water stream is available to the ions, and the entire width of the stream is being polarized, the potential gradient he mentioned doesn't have to be nearly as large as it would need to be for the molecule-polarization example he gave.
For the second one, google "Janibekov's effect".

Here are my hypotheses (I actually put time and thought into this and I feel pretty confident, hope it gets read):

1- There is friction between the tops of your fingers and the underside of the cane. The magnitude of the frictional force on each finger is related to the moment of inertia of the cane with respect to each finer (a larger moment creates a larger normal force between the cane and the finger). Let's assume they are initially positioned so that one finger will experience a lesser moment than the other, resulting in a lower normal force on that finger. The net forces on each finger must be equal, but since the normal forces on each are unequal, one will experience linear force + a kinetic friction force (let's call this one the moving finger) and one will only experience a static friction force (the stationary finger); this is using the cane as frame of reference. Since the moving finger reduces the moment arm for the moment acting on the stationary finger, this moment will steadily decrease. Eventually the moments will become equal, which will cause the roles of "moving" and "stationary" fingers to reverse. This cycle will continue, and each time the moments on either side of each finger will be balanced. (In an ideal case, I think these "role reversals" would occur infinitely quickly, basically making it so that the fingers both steady approach the cane at different rates; however, in reality, I think it is the inconsistent coefficients of friction throughout the material causes the more sporadic phenomenon we observe). In any case, these alternation cycles will continue until the fingers reach the same position at the center of mass, the final point at the the moments on either side are balanced.

2- I'm fairly certain that the batteries in iPhones are positioned closer to the left side of the phone (or possibly the right; to explain the phenomenon in the video, it doesn't really matter which). This makes the left side of the phone is heavier than the right, which throws off the center of mass slightly to the left of the center of volume. Therefore, in the third case presented, there is more angular momentum on one side of the phone than the other, inducing a torque perpendicular to the one used to flip the phone. In the first two cases, angular momentum was equal throughout the phone all along the axis of rotation, allowing only one axis of rotation.

3- This one really surprised me, I would have guessed the classic dipole explanation if you had not said it was wrong. It is worth noting that the static field around the cup is NOT a uniform electric field, and the same explanation is used for how statically charged objects can attract neutrally charged objects (e.g. a balloon picking up scraps of paper). Anyway, my best alternative guess is based on the assumption that the dipoles will orient themselves towards the center of the electric field, and that water is cohesive. So as a molecule passes from being at the same height as the cup (oriented vertically, with the hydrogen facing to the right) to being below the height of the cup, the molecule will rotate slightly counter clockwise. If you could snap a molecular picture of the stream, I believe there would be a pretty continuous gradient of angles pointing towards the center of the field as you look down the stream. This would make all the molecules behave like little arch stones - or maybe chains is a better visualization? The molecules at the height of the cup (facing right) would be fine if stacked vertically, but the molecules below the cup (rotated slightly CCW) would not want to sit vertically on top of each other since the oxygen would be directed more towards the hydrogen.

4- Water is dimagnetic, so it is repelled by magnets. My guess is that you are using a strong enough magnet to create a small divot on one side of the cereal, which causes the water on the other side of the cereal to push it towards the direction of the magnet.

5- The fire heats up the air around and within the cylinder. We all know hot air is less dense than cold air, which is why it rises. Atmospheric pressure causes cold air to flow into the space previously occupied by the hot air, which is then in turn heated up as well; the cycle continues, and viola, we have a upward, vertical convection air current. At some point, the mass of the cylinder will become so low that this current carries the cylinder up along with it.

[Ff = μ N]. the coefficient of friction, Ff  (amount of friction between two objects), is dependent on weight, N, and the static or kinetic friction of an object, μ. If one of your fingers has more weight on it than the other (more of the cane is bearing weight on it) the increase in the coefficient of friction will slow or stop its progress along the canes' surface until the other finger has transversed enough surface area to remove enough load off the other side, reducing its coefficient of friction and allowing it to move. Coefficient of friction is also dependent on the kinetic or static friction presented by an object, μ, so if you put a piece of velcro on one side this phenomena no longer works. You should try this!

About the phone problem: let's assume that all phone's mass is in its corners, while it rotates around fixed point in space - its center of mass. When it's tossed into the air, the velocity and position of each of the four corners differs slightly from what should be called ideal. That means that pairs of corners on the same edge should rotate around the point on that edge, the only question is how fast they do this. The amount of force that needs to be applied to corners so that they make the full rotation in some period of time grows, as I know, quadratically with the length of the side. On the other hand, the amount of force that commits to rotation decreases with the angle between the vector of applied force(to the center of mass) and the side of the phone. It means that most unstable rotation could be achieved if the side is short and  it's angle to the vector of applied force is close to 90 degrees. Increasing the number of points in this imaginary system would make its analysis more complicated, but the final result should still remain the same.

With regards to the cane and 2 fingers: if the centre of mass is on the left or right of both fingers, the cane will fall due to the moment and because the only force the fingers impart on the cane is upward. Therefore at any point in time, the centre of mass must always be in between the two fingers. As you close the fingers, you're subconsciously balancing the force of each finger so that there isn't a moment that causes the cane to leave contact around one finger and revolve around the other.

For the centre of gravity of a rod question.
------------------o----------------------------------- Rod
    F1                                                     F2
F1,F2=Finger 1,2.  O=center of gravity
F1 and F2 exert reaction force upwards, Reaction force by F1 is larger than F2 due to closer distance from centre of gravity.
Therefore Finger 1 experience a larger frictional force than F2.
Assume F1, F1 has same force toward the centre of gravity, F1,F2 therefore moves toward centre of gravity with difference velocitty.
If one finger comes to the centre of gravity, the upward reaction force of other finger disappears, therefore experience neglegible frictional force, and thus comes to the centre of gravity with no problem.

THE KEY OF THIS PHENOMENA, IS THAT ONE FINGER PROVIDES LIFT TO THE ROD BEFORE THE OTHER FINGER ARRIVES TO THE CENTRE OF GRAVITY.

Most have been answered, but here's my explanation for #3: it's the shape of the molecule. The electrostatic charge in the cup aligns all the water molecules in one direction, but the water molecules are not simple dipoles, they have a 2 dimensional structure of charge. While the cup aligns the molecules, this shape of charge will cause them to spread from one another as the hydrogen pushes against each other - this results in the curvature.

the cane: as one finger moves towards the center the cane the force on that finger increases and the force on the other finger decreases (the total force is always need to be equal to the weight of the cane). because of that, the one "furthest" from the center of gravity will have less friction. and once one finger is at the center, the other will no longer have friction with the cane.
the flip: the same reason why wind can turn a wind direction indicator. any object with wind friction will always somehow turn to the most favorable position (with the least friction). for a phone, that's sideways.
the water. this wouldn't work with pure water. it's the the other elements that are charged that pull it toward the cup.
the cereal: same as above you're moving the water. the cereal, having nothing else to hold it in place, will move with the water towards the magnet
the teabag rocket: ok I have only a slight clue on this, I guess it would be something like hot air rises? and it pulls the teabag remains with it (because they're really light)?

cane: let's assume it's not an unevenly weighted cane and instead just a rod. as you slide your fingers toward the center one side of the rod will end up being longer than the other. the side with the longer part of the rod from the finger will have more weight and thus will impart more friction onto the finger on that side. this makes the rod grip on that finger more than the other which either stops the rod from moving on that finger or allows the other finger to slide easier as it doesn't have as much friction. this goes back and forth until the fingers reach the rods center of mass.

cereal: most if not all cereal has an iron content. you can see this in the nutritional information label on the box. this means there are tiny tiny TINY iron filings inside the cereal which is small enough to be absorbed by the body but can still be attracted by the magnet. the water creates a friction-less surface which allows the small attractive force to be seen. The phone does not rotate in a stable manner about the axis shown as the object has three principal moments of inertia that are all of different magnitudes. The axis about which the intermediate moment of inertia exists is not stable in the short term and the object will tend to rotate about one of the two other axis. In this example the intermediate axis is the one running parallel to the top and bottom of the phone. In the long term, if the phone was left to rotate, with losses, it would eventually spin about the axis with the largest polar moment of inertia. This is the axis perpendicular to the screen, which is the lowest energy state.
This is to do with rotational stability, a somewhat advanced dynamics problem.
This is my understanding anyway, correct me if I am wrong.

Basically, all three axes he spun the phone around are principle axes, so theoretically he should be able to spin it around any of the three. The reason the first two work and the third doesn't is because the first and second axes result in the greatest and least moments of inertia whereas the third results in one in between, meaning [for some mysterious reason...] that it is unstable, so any small deviations from that axis will result in the phone wobbling out of control. Centre of cane: has to do with moments about the two fingers. If one finger is further away from the centre of mass than the other, than finger will experience less normal contact force on the cane and therefore lesser friction and thus you can shift towards the centre it more easily than your other finger.

There is a constant equilibrium reaction happening in water, some H2O molecules are turning into H ions (Positively Charged) and OH ions (Negatively Charged), and vice versa. When the charged cup is placed next to the stream of water, the OH ions are repelled away from where the cup is, while the H ions are attracted to the negatively charged cup and gather on the surface of the stream nearest to the cup. This makes the side of the stream nearest to the cup positively charged, and the other side furthest away from the cup. Hence the stream will bend towards the cup as the positive H ions are attracted to the cup and moves the  whole water stream towards the cup.

a possible explanation for the water effect

the individual water molecules do turn so that their dipoles align, but the water molecules are linked to eachother via dipole-dipole interactions, so if one turns, this causes the adjacent molecules to change their positions slightly, so that the dipole-dipole interactions maintain their strenght, over a large ammount of water, this causes the stream to bend.

Cane: I would say that it's psychological to keep the cane from falling, but since this is specifically about physics phenomena, I'll say that it's because of differences in friction between the two fingers from increased and decreased weight over the individual fingers.

Phone: Conservation of angular momentum I would suspect is playing at least a part in this. I think it's interesting that the phone seems to become stable at its apex, but during its ascent and descent is when it seems to become unstable. It's also worth noting that the ascent sees the phone spin around the long axis in the opposite direction when compared to its descent.

In the case of the phone, we not only have the angular momentum of the spinning phone, but also the vector along which the phone itself is traveling through the air which seems that it may play a role. I'm unable to articulate what the relationship is.

Cup & Water: Since create an abundance of electrons on the cups, there is going to be a difference in charge between the water and the cup. As such, when the two come close together, electrons are going to try their best to balance out between the water and the cup. Electrons start flowing from the more negatively charged cup to the more positively charged water -- a static discharge. Prior to the discharge itself, however, the two opposite charges will be attracted to one another.

Cereal: Most cereals are fortified with iron.

Teabag: The teabag is porous. As it burns, it is releasing lighter-than-air gases. When it reaches the bottom of the teabag, the mass left is light enough to be lifted by the gases that happen to get trapped in the remaining meshing.

1st phenomena theory

Once the fingers are brought closer to one another, the weight on each finger varies depending on which one is closer to the center of mass. Usually the fingers more one at a time. So when the moving finger is brought closer to the center of mass, it gradually carries more weight. The more weight it carries the more kinetic friction it experiences. Once the kinetic friction (which is lower then static) overcomes the static friction of the finger carrying less weight, it causes the moving finger to stop and allows the static finger to move. This will happen and repeat from finger to finger once they both approach the center of mass and are exerting equal force on the object held.

For the cane it's because if one finger is closer to the center of mass, there will be more of the cane's weight resting on that finger, increasing the friction between the finger and the cane. Due to that, the other finger then moves towards the center of mass faster, until the weight is balanced evenly on both fingers.

The Cane:

When one finger gets closer to the center of mass than the other finger, that finger will be holding up a larger share of the canes weight, increasing friction, allowing the finger furthest from the center of mass to move with more ease (faster).

Thus, allowing the finger furthest from the center of mass to catch up to the one closest to it.

(1) Differential friction on the cane. The more weight, the more friction, which allows the other finger to move closer to the center of gravity quicker. Equillibrium is maintained. (Probably completely wrong after looking at some other comments!)

(2) Wind resistance on phone. Objects tend to like to travel with the least resistance in an atmosphere. The very slight imbalances in the phone's movement are amplified by the wind resistance, causing it to go into self-oscillation.

(3) Wiping electrons off the cup causes a positive electric field. Water is slightly conductive (depending on how many impurities, of course). As the water moves past the cup, it is inducing current flow in the water (like copper wire moving past the pole of a magnet). Due to the resistance of the water, a voltage differential is created between the water closest to the cup (-neg) and the tap that is providing water (+pos). The water closest to the cup now has an abundance of electrons (provided by Earth through the tap) and is attracted to the positively charged cup.
2:12 - Electrons are actually wiped off the cup, causing a positive charge in the electric field.

(4) The cereal is fortified with a nutritional supplement called Ferrous Fumarate - an Iron containing molecule. The Neodemium magnet is strong enough to attract the small amounts of Ferrous Fumarate. It can also be done with supplements that contain Ferrous Fumarate to greater effect, since there's a higher concentration in the tablets than in the cereal.

(5) Teabag rocket: I would guess that an updraught is caused by the rising air, which is caused by the heat from the flame. The tube (created from the tea bag) would cause a focussing of the updraught. It has enough holes to allow air in, which is then heated by the flame, causing a pressure differential that sucks more air into the holes of the tube. Once the weight of the teabag has been reduced enough that it can be lifted by the updraught, it is taken up. Just a guess.

Making an attempt based on what I know.

1. I think I figured it out when Derek made asymmetric distance demonstration. The finger closer to the center of mass didn't move until the other finger got even closer. I know that frictional force relies on the normal force between the interacting objects (the cane and a finger). Normal force is derived from an object's mass if no other forces are acting on it. The farther a finger is from the center of mass/gravity, the lesser the normal force on it. When trying to move both your fingers closer to the center of mass, the one with the lesser normal force, and therefore lesser friction, will be the one to move. I suspect that when two fingers are symmetrically distant from the center of mass, that, even when converging at uniform speed, they will alternate (even if imperceptibly without sensitive measuring equipment) movement until they touch. Since the laws of physics are always in effect, even converging your fingers quickly will allow them to zero in on the center of mass.

2. I'll admit, I haven't got a clue, but I'll make an attempt. First, let's establish the axes of rotation in terms of roll, pitch, and yaw. Let's imagine that each of these axes pierce the phone, so in our imaginations it literally spins on an axis. The roll axis is the one that occupies most of the phone's insides. If you were to stand the phone up on the table so it stands tall and perpendicular, the roll axis is parallel to the phone, and perpendicular to the table. Let's establish the yaw axis next. Simply put, if this axis was tangible, it would crack your screen. It occupies the least space, and it never touches the edges of the phone, like the other two axes. Finally, the pitch axis goes through the phone across its width, occupying the second most amount of space of the phone's body. For visual aid, you can Google image search "roll pitch yaw" and imagine that the tail of the plane is where Derek uses his thumb to hold the phone before making the complicated flip.

The only way this phenomenon fits comfortably in my head is if I imagine those axes having mass and sticking out of the phone, as if the phone was stuck with metal rods. In Derek's first flip, the phone rotates in a way that the ends of the yaw axis don't travel, while the other two axes are whirling in mid air. The second flip Derek does has the phone spinning on the roll axis, while the pitch and yaw are the ones whirling through the air. The last one is the one that gets me. For some reason, rotating the phone about the pitch axis causes the other axes to want to take over. I can remember some of Derek's other videos on rotation, where he explains that figure skaters can slow down by retracting their arms, or speed up by extending their arms. Perhaps, the reason for our current phenomenon lies in the reason for the figure skater phenomenon. Perhaps making a rectangle like a phone rotate about the pitch axis requires more energy than spinning  about both the other axes combined. If the phone were perfectly square, then the roll and pitch axes would be indistinguishable, and maybe this phenomenon wouldn't occur under those conditions. But since the phone is rectangular, I suspect that it costs less energy to spin on both the roll and yaw axes, so trying to spin on the pitch would make itself shift to the less costly rotation (maybe the laws of rotational physics prevent the phone from rotating about the pitch axis at all, and Derek was only giving the illusion that he was, all the while rotating the phone about the roll and yaw axes from a different starting point. Although, I'm not too confident about my claim).

3. I feel like I've been lied to in school (not that such a thing is unheard of). You know, I think the fact that a polar molecule is more significant than what the molecule is. What I'm trying to say is, I don't think the fact that it's water means anything. Seriously, this could be done with balloons on cupboards, or plastic wrap on just about anything. Neither of those things are "magnetic". It's just van der Waals interaction. Why does that suddenly change when the molecule is in the water state at room temperature? I don't think it does. I'm going to go out on a limb here and say it's van der Waals attraction pulling the water to an electrically charged surface.

4. Similar to number 3. Actually, I can think of two possible solutions (and it might just be that one doesn't preclude the other). The first is that breakfast cereals tend to be porous, which means it absorbs some water. That water is then attracted to the magnet because of the water's polar property, as I explained for phenomenon 3 (I might be wrong about it, but no one can deny water's polar tendencies). Derek might have said to use a strong magnet because now there is a layer between the magnet and the water--the cereal--which means an electrically charge piece of plastic won't cut it anymore. Since the water is inside the cereal, the cereal, due to normal force (or, if I'm right about 3, van der Waals attraction), has no choice but to move along with the water.

The second explanation I can think of comes from what I think is fluid dynamics. Since the water is attracted to charged surfaces, it naturally wants to move closer to the magnet. If the water moves away from an area, it reduces the pressure from that area, and more water moves in to equalize the pressure. If the cereal is near the area, it will be moved to the low pressure area due to drag (and possibly van der Waals forces that tug the cereal when the water moves).

If this phenomenon works with a particle that is both less dense than water and not at all porous or absorbent, then the second explanation will more true than the first one. If the phenomenon fails to work with a particle that is both less dense than water and not at all porous or absorbent, then the first explanation is true, and the second one is false.

5. Similar to my second explanation for number 4--fluid dynamics (I think). Also, a gas law. Combustion reactions produce heat, and that heat warms the surrounding air. Charles's law states that as a gas's temperature goes up, so does its volume. A substance's density is simply the ratio of its mass to its volume. Since the air can't lose mass (law of conservation of mass), but its volume goes up, its density is decreased. When fluids mix, the least dense fluid rises to the top. In this case, the two fluids are room temperature air, and the warmer air that was heated by the flaming teabag. As the room temperature air gets warmer, its density decreases, and it travels upward. Since that air is out of the way, the pressure of the area it left is lower than other areas. The air that rushes to equalize the pressure difference comes from below, since it was unaffected by the heat and never flew up to create the low pressure. As the cooler air below rushes upward to fill the void, it creates drag as it rubs up against the teabag. When enough of the teabag is burned away the drag pulling it upwards overcomes the force of gravity pulling it downwards, and so it (surprise, surprise) moves upward. In truth, this teabag is a rocket as about as much as smoke, soot, and ash are rockets.

1. The cane rests on both fingers individually, parting it in three segments. The segment between them acts on both of them with identical gravitational force, but the two outer sections effectively only push down on the finger they are closer to, everything past that point actually gets lifted UP(slightly), lowering the force applied to the opposite finger.
That way the cane lifts itself up to allow the finger that lifts less to come closer to the center by reducing friction. This continues until they reach an equilibrium and from that point on they close in at the same rate, just slightly ajusting the balance because of errors caused by differences in friction coefficients in both fingers and along the surface of the cane. 

2. Think of the phone as having a ball of mass in both top and bottom half.
If you spin it in the plane of the screen those two balls act like two kids rotating holding hands, the centrifugal force keeps them moving in a circle and because the direction of that force is always in the exact plane of the rotation any changes that plane might take has to overcome that force that pulls it back into the plane. As the mass off to the side of the rotational plane is almost directly at the plane iself it can't really put up much force.
If you rotate the phone along the longer center you get a similar effect. But there is a large part that acts vastly different. In this case there is a lot of mass not along the rotational plane but along the center of the rotation itself. A large part of the phones mass is in the center of the rotation, making the influences of any other parts of the phone pretty insignificant. Also, because the other parts of the phone are close to the center themselves they only have a short lever sideways to unstabilise the phone, but a long lever in the direction of the center of rotation to counter any instabilities.
If you now rotate the phone along the short center both effects work in the opposite direction. A large part of the mass is far away from the center of the rotation leaving almost nothing to stabilize the center. There isn't really a singular plane of rotation, but if you think of two, one on each side of the phone, you've got some great levers there, where each little instability can do some great things to the other side. Also the mass is distributed everywhere and can't stabilise itself with a big centrifugal force in a single direction.

3. The static elecricity polarises the water and then pulls it towards it. The cup basically is an electromagnet inducing a current into the water that also creates an electromagnetic field. If you tried the trick with oure H2O it wouldn't work, because there would be no way for it to create an electromagnetic field.

4. Cereal has iron in it, as most food has. Cereal in water has far lower friction, thus moving more easily towards the magnet. I think some years ago a frog was levitated only with an electromagnet, because of the iron inside his body. And because the iron is basically everywhere it doesn't even rip him apart.

5. The flame burns away the tea bag which makes it lighter. And when it's become light enough it gets lifted by the gases created by the fire. The fire heats the gases, creating an area of lower density which ascends like air in water. The rising gases leave behind an area of lower air pressure which also sucks the air from below it upwards. In that updraft is the light tea bag, that needs only that much lift to fly up.

I'm no expert on this but these are my hypotheses on all of them:

Cane: when either finger gets closer to the center of mass of the cane, more force and thus friction is applied to that closer finger than the farther one. So basically the center of mass is affected more greatly by forces near it than farther away (and vice versa). Many things from moving stock to throwing in Ju-jitsu stress the importance of applying force as close to the center of gravity as possible for this very reason.

Phone: leverage and gyroscopic motion. When you flip the phone, force (and counterforces) is exerted on all 3 axes at the same time. In the 1st 2 flips the leverage granted to one axis far far exceeds the leverage placed on the others and can get drowned out, and the spin can be maintained through gyroscopic motion. However the amount of leverage on the third flip isn't strong enough to overcome the other axes (especially air resistance) and gyroscopic motion isn't attained on said axis.

Cup and Water: My guess would be Bernoulli's Principal. Similar to how moving air lifts a wing and how running water pulls a hanging spoon to it. This cup has generated an EM field around it and is generating more "pressure" on one side of the falling water than the other, so the water is "encouraged" to follow the pressure as much as it can. Even though the water is both attracted and repelled by this force, its a little resistant to changing its environment (leaving the field) and tries to stay with it for a little while.

Cereal: as someone said before, many cereal contains Iron which can be affected by magnetic forces. This is true, but in reality everything is techinally magnetic... to a degree. Its just that the things we see as magnetic are just hundreds of times more sensitive to it than other elements. In this experiment I believe its not just the Iron that is pulling to the magnet but the starch, sugars, and the water itself (again to a very tiny degree). due to it free floating in water we can observe the tiny degree to some extent.

Teabag: Alot of it has to do with the orientation of the teabag as it's standing and how light it is (and becomes as it burns). As hot air rises, cooler air rushes in from the sides  and rises along with it. and because it is standing like so, the cooler->warmer air can fully grasp all sides of the paper and lift it once it becomes light enough.

I'm surprised you said polar nature of water can't explain the deviation. A molecule of water is a pretty good approximation of what is called an "electric dipole". And the force experience by such a dipole (which we will call "p") is given by p times grad(E) (as you said, it's proportional to the gradient of the electric field). For water, we find that p = 1.8 D approx 6e-30 C.m. I don't know the electric field produced by the cup but I will assume it's order of magnitude is the 10 times as much as the one from the earth, that is around 100 V/m. It seems to be dropping over around 1cm away from the cup, giving thus grad(E) approx 1000/1e-2 = 1e5 V/m2. That way the net force experienced by a molecule of water is about 6e-25 N which is not much but the mass of such a molecule is around 18e-3/6e23 = 3e-26 kg so that the acceleration of the molecule would be around F/m = 6e-25/3e-26 = 20 m/s-2 (around 2g), totally in agreement with the observed deflection... What would you're  alternative explanation be ? I'm curious :)

No. 1: The cane is has roughly no angular acceleration, so the torque provided by either of your fingers must balance, and the force from friction is the product of the kinetic friction coefficient of your fingers (presumably the same) and the force acting perpendicular to the surface of your fingers (i.e. the normal force that's holding up the cane).

No. 2: Surprisingly complicated if you want the proper answer. The simple answer is that rotating an object around the principal axis corresponding to the 'middling' of the three moments of inertia is inherently unstable, and the rotation will tend towards either the smallest or the largest. The real answer involves Euler's equations of motion and energy surfaces, which explains the stability behaviour.

No. 3: My first order guess is that you're creating a net charge on one side of the stream with the field from the cup, but the water is moving with respect to the cup, so the cup appears to have a surface current in the frame of reference of the water, which is generating a magnetic field. Then I get stuck because we don't have moving charges in the water frame, so we don't get a Lorentz force (I'd also be surprised if it was such a large effect). Similar problem working in the cup frame. Still, can't think of anything else, so I very much look forward to seeing the real answer.

No. 4: As many others have stated, cereal has iron in it, which is ferromagnetic.

No. 5: Fire heats the air and creates a pressure gradient which moves the air up - it's a small effect so until most of the teabag has burned up it's not enough to lift the bag. Finally when most of the teabag has gone and there's the most air moving, the teabag gets dragged along for the ride.

1) As you slide your fingers along the cane, as one finger ends up closer to the center of mass (because of inertia) the cane ends up applying a greater force on that finger, which results in higher friction and consequently dragging the cane along with it more than the other finger, re-balancing the cane. (Try lubricating the cane and moving your hands together as fast as you can, especially very unevenly.)

2) (I'm srota guessing here.) More mass further from the axis of rotation and closer to the plane of rotation through the center of mass has a higher resistance to precession...greater moment? Think of a fly-wheel, or a bicycle wheel. There's also a small amount of wind resistance.

3) First off, that's not a uniform electric field, but that's irrelevant. Your demonstration is using what appears to be tap-water, which isn't pure water and generally isn't exactly neutral. Try measuring the resistance through that water.

4) I've heard this described as a result of the added iron still being ferromagnetic. Incidentally, none of my 5 favorite cereals float in water (wheat, barley, rye, corn and rice.)

5) As the carbohydrates in the teabag burn they break apart into hydrogen and carbon, with some other oxides as ash, but then oxidize into water and carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide. The sudden lift-off of the small remnant of paper is probably caused by combustion of condensed carbon monoxide near the surface of the water propelling the fragile carbon and ash structure of the remaining paper (which fractured off of the remaining paper structure under the water due to the thermal gradient near the surface of the water.) The hot combustion gasses lift the very light carbon and ash structure.

1.  Frictional force is proportional to the normal force x coefficient of friction.  The coefficient stays the same, but the normal force (force on each finger) is larger for the finger that is closer to the center of mass.  Thus, less friction on the finger further away, and that finger slides closer to center of mass. Keep repeating each time a finger slides, and the fingers will find the center of mass!

2.  There are symmetries involved with the moment of inertia of an object... for example, a sphere can rotate about any axis that passes through the center because it is symmetric!  Your phone, however, is shaped with different length, width, and height.  It turns out that the axes passing through the longest side and the shortest side provide stable equilibriums for rotation.  However, it's an unstable equilibrium if you rotate about that third axis, so you would literally need a perfect flip to get it to rotate about that axis, which is nearly impossible. (someone should explain this better tho, lol)

3.  I'm not very sure, but here's a good question to think about... does water behave this way when it's not in a moving stream?  I think that the moving water is like moving charges, and moving charges can create electric and magnetic fields, which would be affected by the charged cup.

4.  I might be oversimplifying, but I think that the cereal might have enough iron in it to be affected by magnets.  Iron gets an induced magnetic polarization and attracts to the magnets.

5.  Hot air molecules move quicker, and thus end up making a lower pressure above the tea bag.  Once the tea bag is small enough (and there's lots of hot air above it), lift is generated because cooler air below is more dense than the hotter air above it.  aka, hot air rises.

Cane:  Whichever finger is closer to the cane's CG will be instantaneously supporting more weight.  This can be proven by solving a statics problem of a beam with two pin supports.  Because this finger is exerting a larger normal force on the cane, it will therefore have a larger frictional force resisting its movement relative to the cane (F=uN).  Therefore, the finger that is farther from the CG will approach faster, reducing the difference in weights between the two fingers, and approaching equilibrium (this is a dynamically stable system).

Teabag rocket:  The laminar flame creates an air current from rising hot gases leaving the top of the rocket, and cool air being sucked into the bottom of the rocket.  Once most of the rocket is burnt, the remaining paper is light enough to be swept away in these residual air currents before they return to equilibrium.

Cane balance: as soon as one finger moves faster than the other in relation to keeping the cane balanced, the cane tilts slightly, decreasing the force it exerts on the other finger and reducing the friction it experiences.  Since this imbalance does not occur at the center of mass, the changes in friction tend to allow both fingers to come together at that point.

Cell phones have a mass balance in the plane of their screens and around their longer axis.  This makes them unbalanced when flipped end over end.  Maybe because their vibrate function motors are aligned in these planes or their motion sensors, perhaps.

I think the phone problem is due to different rotational inertias from the rectangular shape. The phone is difficult to flip well in the last example because the rotational inertia around the axis we want to spin it around, the long side, is much greater than around the axis on the short side. A slight imbalance in forces on the short side thus causes it to rotate significantly. However, this works in our favor when we rotate the phone 90 degrees-it is easy to rotate the way we want, and difficult in the way we don't.

When the phone is spinning like a frisbee, we can't apply an imbalanced force along the axis we don't want because the width of the phone is tiny compared to the other dimensions.

for the cane, when a person moves their fingers closer, one end of the cane will be heavier than the other as the distance between the fingers and the center of mass are different. The heavier end will push down on one finger causing more friction while the other, lighter end will apply less weight to the other finger therefore causing less friction. The finger with less friction will move closer to the center until the weight on that finger is heavier. At this moment, the other finger will start moving because it is now lighter and experiences less friction. This repeats itself until both of the fingers are touching each other, with a balanced weight behind each finger.

The iphone flip - actually all near perfect or perfect rectangular objects behave like this. 
The "flipping" is stable along the longest and shortest principle axes but becomes chaotic along the middle length principle axis. It is not due to the manufacture flaws on the object but rather an innate property of its shape. I cant intuitively explain why but one can always mathematically use Lagrangian to show this is the case along all 3 axes.

The phone problem is a matter of air resistance.. The aerodynamic properties of the phone's shape make the edges the least resistant side to drag effects meaning the phone will naturally 'beat' the air's friction in those directions more easily than it will on the face side.  What this means in practical terms is that the phone will tend to 'rotate' to bring the sides into the air stream created by the phone's rotation leading to the phone cart wheeling as shown.. Normally something moving so slowly probably wouldn't have a noticeable effect from this, but because there's such a large difference between the side's surface and that of the face it becomes quite pronounced.

Iron in the cereal

Cereal contains tiny particles of metallic iron as an added "mineral" nutrient. The reason they don't use other iron compounds (salts, etc) is because they generally taste horrible or would otherwise compromise the cereal's integrity, and your stomach acid is perfectly effective at dissolving metallic iron.

The static charge cup experiment is due to charge rearrangement on the macro scale - that is, droplets-size, causing either side of an entire droplet to become charged. The larger volume of accumulated charge also acts to shield the far side charge group from the field of the cup. This allows a far weaker gradient to still affect the stream. 

The burning tea bag causes an updraft of heated air, which causes cooler air to rush in from the sides to fill the vacated space. Once the tea bag has burned to ash, it is light enough to be lifted by the residual currents, and the localized heating from the last embers also reinforce this effect.

1. A stronger force of friction will apply to the finger closest to the center of mass, thus allowing the further finger to move inwards. This progresses until both fingers are able to converge close enough to the center of mass without tipping the cane.

3. Tap water contains ions of various salts, most of which are positively charged and attracted to a negatively charged mass. Distilled water would not display this property.

4. Most common serial brands contain large quantities of iron for nutritional purposes, enough where their magnetic presence is visible in a low friction environment.

5. The remaining mass of bag near the end of the burn eventually becomes light enough to be lifted into the air by the strong upwards current of hot air, similarly to a hot air balloon on a minute scale.

1. The Cane:
Because the cane isn't spinning, the sum of the torques acting on the cane are even. And this means the torque supplied by your left finger must balance the torque supplied by your right finger. As you slide your fingers inwards on the cane, the amount of net torque acting on the cane stays the same, at 0, until both fingers are acting approximately with zero radius at the center of mass.

1: The further your finger is away from the center of mass, the less of a frictional force because there is a smaller normal force. As your finger gets close, normal force increases making the frictional force increase too. So your finger will move easier when it is further away, and it won't move as much when it is close to the center of mass. This process continues, going back and forth until your fingers meet, at the center of mass.
